title: State v. Bell
description: In this criminal case, Bell appeals his voluntary manslaughter and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime convictions asserting the trial judge erred in (1) refusing to dismiss a juror who was asked by a daycare worker whether the juror was serving on the case where the daycare workerâ€™s cousin had been shot and (2) refusing to disqualify the Tenth Judicial Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office from prosecuting the case where a former investigator with  the Anderson County Public Defenderâ€™s Office interviewed appellant while with that office and later became an investigator with the Solicitorâ€™s Office.  We affirm.
text:
FACTS

<!--
.style1 {font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif}
-->



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Braxton J. Bell, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Anderson County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4251
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 4, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek of the South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry D. McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Special Assistant Attorney General Amie L. Clifford, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Christina T. Adams, of Anderson, for Respondent.
      
    
  


HUFF, J.:Â  Appellant, Braxton J. Bell, was convicted of voluntary manslaughter and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  He appeals, asserting the trial judge erred in (1) failing to disqualify the Tenth Judicial Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office and (2) refusing to dismiss a juror.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Braxton Bell was indicted for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime in regard to the shooting death of Jonathan Gambrell at the Newport Commons apartment complex in Anderson County.Â  The case proceeded to trial, at which time Bell presented a claim of self-defense.Â  The jury convicted Bell of the lesser offense of voluntary manslaughter, as well as the weapon possession charge.Â  The trial court sentenced him to thirty years for manslaughter and five years for possession of the firearm during the commission of a violent crime.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Bell raises two issues on appeal.Â  He contends the trial court erred in refusing to disqualify the Tenth Judicial Circuit Solicitorâ€™s Office from prosecuting the case because a current investigator with the Solicitorâ€™s Office was a former investigator for the Anderson County Public Defenderâ€™s Office who had interviewed appellant while with the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  He further maintains the trial court erred in refusing to dismiss a juror who reported she was asked by a daycare worker whether she was serving on the case where the daycare workerâ€™s cousin had been shot.
I.Â Disqualification of Solicitorâ€™s Office
The record shows that at the start of the case, Bell made a motion to disqualify the Solicitorâ€™s Office from prosecuting his case arguing there was a conflict of interest based on the investigator for the Solicitorâ€™s Office, Jimmy Penn, having previously interviewed Bell while Penn was an investigator for the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  Counsel for the defense stated it was his belief that â€œthere was information transferred from Mr. Penn to the Solicitorâ€™s Officeâ€ resulting in actual prejudice to Bell.Â  Counsel further asserted, even if the court found no actual prejudice, the Solicitorâ€™s Office should be disqualified based on â€œthe perception of a conflictâ€ in Penn â€œswitching from one side to the other.â€Â  Finally, counsel maintained failure to disqualify the Solicitorâ€™s Office would violate Bellâ€™s constitutional right to effective assistance of counsel because when Penn â€œswitched sidesâ€ it caused a chilling effect on Bell being able to talk to his attorneys.Â  
The trial court held an in camera hearing on the matter at which time the defense presented Bellâ€™s testimony.Â  Bell stated that on November 16, 2004, Penn came to the jail to talk to him about his case.Â  Penn identified himself at that time as an investigator with the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  Penn asked Bell some questions and Bell told him he was being charged with murder, that he and the victim had been arguing, and that someone else shot the victim and he, Bell, ran with the others.Â  This information was recorded on the bottom of an interview sheet.Â  Penn spoke with Bell for about fifteen or twenty minutes.Â  Bell testified that Penn only came to see him that one time, and sometime after January 1, 2005, he learned from other inmates that Penn had become an investigator for the Solicitorâ€™s Office.Â  Bell maintained that he felt betrayed when Penn switched sides and that when a different attorney appeared to represent him at his preliminary hearing than the one who had been to see him twice before, he felt betrayed again.Â  According to Bell, this created a difficulty in him discussing the case with his current attorney, and the first time they discussed self-defense was approximately two weeks before trial.Â  
The State then called Penn to the stand to testify in the hearing.Â  Penn stated that he began working for the Solicitorâ€™s Office on January 12, 2005, having previously worked for the Anderson County Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  Penn acknowledged it was his handwriting on the client interview sheet[2] dated November 16, 2004.Â  However, he stated it was routine for him to go to the jail and speak with clients and he would see approximately ten to twenty clients a week.Â  He did not remember what he had written on the document until defense counsel stated what the interview sheet included. Â Penn stated he remembered a bond reduction request form for Bell that had been faxed to him at the Solicitorâ€™s Office from the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  He recalled he brought the matter to the prosecuting attorneyâ€™s attention, who relayed to Penn there was no change of circumstances justifying a reduction in bond, which Penn then relayed to the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  His only other involvement with this case was to serve subpoenas on witnesses, which he did because the prosecuting attorneyâ€™s investigator was off work that week.Â  He further denied ever speaking to the other investigator about the case and denied talking to the witnesses he served about the case.Â  When asked if he had shared any confidential information with the solicitor that he learned from Bell at the interview, Penn replied, â€œAbsolutely not.â€Â  He further denied having any confidential conversations with anyone else involved in the matter.Â  
The trial court found there was no prejudice to Bell, noting he believed Penn did not even remember the interview and, even if he had, that information was not unduly prejudicial.Â  It found that Pennâ€™s service of subpoenas was a ministerial act and the evidence showed Penn did not take that opportunity to discuss the case with anyone.Â  It further determined there was nothing Penn did in response to the bond reduction request that would amount to prejudice to Bell. Â Finally, the court found any chilling effect on Bellâ€™s cooperation with his attorney was an unreasonable reaction.Â  The court therefore denied Bellâ€™s motion to disqualify the Solicitorâ€™s Office.Â  
On appeal, Bell contends the trial court erred in failing to disqualify the Solicitorâ€™s Office based on the fact that Bell initially denied to Penn that he shot the victim, and this denial was clearly inconsistent with the self-defense claim he presented at trial. Â He argues his right to effective representation was adversely affected by Pennâ€™s betrayal, that Pennâ€™s later participation in his prosecution created more than just an appearance of impropriety, and that there was no clear evidence that no actual breach of confidence occurred.Â  Bell also asserts Pennâ€™s participation likely led the Solicitorâ€™s Office to feel, because of Bellâ€™s initial statement to Penn, that Bellâ€™s claim of self-defense was not genuine, therefore adversely affecting the trial and any effort to plea bargain his case.Â  He thus maintains the trial court abused its discretion in refusing to disqualify the Solicitorâ€™s Office and he is therefore entitled to a new trial.Â  We disagree.
In State v. Smart, 278 S.C. 515, 299 S.E.2d 686 (1982), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991), our supreme court addressed the standard for disqualification of a Solicitorâ€™s Office where an attorney in that office had been employed by the Public Defenderâ€™s Office during the pendency of charges against the appellant.Â  There, the court rejected the standard of a presumption of betrayal from mere allegation of successive adverse representation resulting in a per se disqualification.Â  Id. at 518, 299 S.E.2d at 688.Â  Instead, the court adopted the requirement of a showing of actual prejudice to the defendantâ€™s case.Â  Id. at 518-19, 299 S.E.2d at 688. Finding no evidence that any secrets or confidences of Smart were revealed, the court affirmed the denial of Smartâ€™s motion for disqualification.Â  Id. at 520-521, 299 S.E.2d at 689.Â  Thereafter, in State v. Chisolm, 312 S.C. 235, 439 S.E.2d 850 (1994), our supreme court again articulated that an appellant who seeks disqualification of a Solicitorâ€™s Office must show actual prejudice.Â  Id. at 238, 439 S.E.2d at 852.
Bell attempts to distinguish Smart on the basis that the attorney involved in that case did not discuss evidentiary matters or trial strategy with Smart while working for the defense, whereas investigator Penn interviewed Bell regarding the circumstances surrounding the incident.Â  He argues that involvement with the defense, along with Pennâ€™s later involvement in the request for bond reduction and service of subpoenas while working for the Solicitorâ€™s Office, adversely affected the trial of his case and any effort to plea bargain.Â  We disagree.
In Smart, attorney DuTremble was assigned to prepare a brief on behalf of Smart while working for the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  Thereafter, attorney DuTrembleâ€™s work for the prosecution consisted of research on a narrow issue of law regarding admissibility of certain psychiatric evaluations.Â  Our supreme court, noting attorney DuTremble denied under oath that he personally spoke with Smart or that he discussed evidentiary matters or trial strategy with Smartâ€™s counsel, determined the facts failed to suggest betrayal of any secrets or confidences.Â  Smart, 278 S.C. at 519, 299 S.E.2d at 688-89.Â  While, in the case at hand, investigator Penn admitted the client interview document regarding Bell was in his handwriting, he denied remembering the contents of the document, stating he interviewed anywhere from ten to twenty clients a week when he worked for the Public Defenderâ€™s Office.Â  Further, his involvement with Bellâ€™s case once he moved to the Solicitorâ€™s Office was minimal, involving only ministerial acts.Â  There simply is no evidence investigator Penn was involved with any substantive or strategic prosecution work suggestive of betrayal of any secrets or confidences.Â  Indeed, Penn denied ever speaking to the prosecuting attorney or the other investigator at the Solicitorâ€™s Office or any of the witnesses he served about the case, and adamantly maintained under oath that he had no confidential conversations with anyone else involved in the matter.Â  Contrary to Bellâ€™s assertion, a thorough review of the record reveals no breach of confidence occurred and there was no actual prejudice to Bell.Â  
Additionally, we find no merit to Bellâ€™s argument that he was adversely affected in any effort to plea bargain his case.Â  First, we note there is no evidence of record that Bell ever attempted to attain a plea bargain.Â  Second, Bell has no constitutional right to plea bargain.Â  See State v. Chisolm, 312 S.C. 235, 237-38, 439 S.E.2d 850, 851-52 (1994) (holding, where appellant claimed prejudice because the solicitor failed to negotiate any plea agreement in matter where assistant solicitor had inappropriate communication with appellant during pendency of charges, appellant failed to show actual prejudice necessary to disqualify the solicitorâ€™s office, noting appellant had no constitutional right to plea bargain).
Finally, Bell cites the case of State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000) for the proposition that our courts will not tolerate â€œinterference or corruption into attorney-client confidencesâ€ and that a solicitorâ€™s office should be disqualified based on the damage such interference does to our entire criminal justice system.Â  Quattlebaum is clearly distinguishable from the case sub judice.Â  There, our supreme court found the solicitorâ€™s office should have been disqualified based on a violation of Quattlebaumâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to counsel, as well as to protect the integrity of the judicial system, where a member of the prosecution team intentionally eavesdropped on a confidential defense conversation.Â  The court held in Quattlebaum that a defendant must show either deliberate prosecutorial misconduct or prejudice to make out a Sixth Amendment violation of right to counsel, but not both.Â  Id. at 448, 527 S.E.2d at 109.Â  It noted that deliberate prosecutorial misconduct raises an irrebuttable presumption of prejudice.Â  Id. Â The court further held the solicitorâ€™s office should have also been disqualified because the deliberate prosecutorial conduct threatened rights fundamental to liberty and justice, calling into question the integrity of the entire judicial system. Â Id. at 449, 527 S.E.2d at 449.Â  Here, however, there is no such deliberate prosecutorial misconduct.Â  Because we have found no actual prejudice to Bell, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to disqualify the Solicitorâ€™s Office from the prosecution of Bellâ€™s case.
II. Dismissal of Juror
Following jury selection, the trial court informed the jurors the trial would not start until after lunch and they were to be back at 3:00 oâ€™clock that afternoon.Â  The court instructed the jurors that they should not talk to anybody about the case and if anyone asked them, to tell them they had been selected to serve on a jury but they could not even tell them the name of the case.Â  He told the jurors not to discuss the case among themselves or with anyone else.Â  Upon their return, the trial court informed the parties one of the jurors had reported someone talked to her about the case when she took her child to daycare and explained she may be late coming back to get the child because she was on a jury. Â The trial court then brought the juror in for questioning to determine whether she should be disqualified.Â  The following colloquy occurred between the judge and the juror:

  [Court]:Â  . . . I understand you had something that happened at lunch you wanted to inform the court about?
  [Juror]:Â  Yes, sir.
  [Court]:Â  Tell us about that, please.
  [Juror]:Â  I took my son to a daycare and was explaining to them why it was last minute, that they were squeezing him in, they didnâ€™t have room, but I had been selected for the jury, for jury duty.Â  Thatâ€™s all I said.
  [Court]:Â  This is not a regular daycare?
  [Juror]:Â  Itâ€™s an after-school type thing.
  [Court]:Â  I mean, is it one you regularly use?
  [Juror]:Â  Yeah, itâ€™s one I go to during the school year, but not during the summer because I teach.
  [Court]: All right.
  [Juror]:Â  And one of the girls in there said, â€œMy cousin was shot, and his trial begins today.Â  Are you on that jury?â€Â  And I said, â€œI canâ€™t talk about it.â€
  [Court]:Â  So you think her cousin was the victim in the case?
  [Juror]:Â  The victim, yeah, thatâ€™s the way it sounded.
  [Court]:Â  Okay.Â  And that was the conversation?
  [Juror]:Â  (Nodded head.)Â  And then she started to tell another child, and I left the room, and all I heard was, â€œMy cousin was shot.â€Â  She repeated that.
  [Court]:Â  All right.Â  Would anything about that incident cause you to fear your ability to be a fair and impartial juror to both the State and the defendant?
  [Juror]:Â  Not me personally.Â  I donâ€™t know if she thinks something, if she thinks that Iâ€™m on this jury - - I donâ€™t . . .
  [Court]:Â  But it wouldnâ€™t affect your decision?
  [Juror]:Â  No, it wouldnâ€™t affect my decision.
  [Court]:Â  Is she someone that you knew, that you regularly - - -
  [Juror]:Â  She was a former student of mine.
  [Court]:Â  Okay.Â  But it wouldnâ€™t affect your ability;Â  you could put that aside and make your decision based solely on what you hear in this courtroom?
  [Juror]:Â  Yes, yes.
  [Court]:Â  All right.Â  You did nothing - - you did absolutely right, number one in the way you handled it, and number two telling the bailiff as soon as you got back.Â  So weâ€™ll be ready to get started in just a couple minutes, so please retire to the jury room.Â  And donâ€™t discuss this with any other juror.Â  Thank you, maâ€™am.
  [Juror]:Â  I wonâ€™t, I promise.

The State had no objection to having this juror continue in service.Â  The defense, however, did, stating that if the juror was close to the daycare worker, â€œshe may lean that way unintentionally.â€ Â The defense further expressed concern that when she took her child into the daycare again, the juror might be asked something about the case and, even though she would probably indicate she could not talk about it, the juror would feel pressured.Â  It thus asked that the juror be removed.Â  
The trial courtâ€™s initial response was that it was going to excuse the juror stating, â€œIâ€™m going to excuse her, not because I think - - Iâ€™m just going to excuse her because I got two alternates, and hopefully weâ€™ll finish this trial by Thursday. . . .â€Â  After the State and the defense agreed the trial should be finished in that time, the trial court changed its ruling.Â  The court explained its decision as follows:

  I donâ€™t think sheâ€™s done anything wrong.Â  I was very impressed with the way she answered the questions.Â  Sheâ€™s a school teacher, sheâ€™s intelligent, she knew what to do.Â  She handled it properly at the time, she didnâ€™t discuss it, and she reported it immediately.Â  And so I . . . Iâ€™m not gonna excuse her.Â  I think sheâ€™s a qualified juror.Â  Had she answered the question in the same fashion as we were qualifying the jury, that she knew the cousin of the victim was working at the daycare, then I would not have disqualified her at that time.Â  Of course you [the defense] would have had an opportunity to strike at that time.

The defense noted its exception to the courtâ€™s ruling.Â  It further requested, if the juror remained on the jury, the court continue to question her in the morning about whether sheâ€™d had any further discussions.Â  The trial court agreed to caution the juror that she should not speak to anybody else about the matter and to report it immediately if anyone tried to speak with her.Â  The court refused to excuse the juror, however, stating, â€œBecause I think sheâ€™s qualified, I think sheâ€™s very honest when she answered the question.Â  Iâ€™m very impressed with the way she handled the entire situation, and so I think thereâ€™s no need to excuse her from this jury.â€ Â 
In its preliminary instructions to the jury, the trial court informed them they should not speak to anyone about the case, and told them to report back immediately if someone did try to speak to them about it.Â  When the court later recessed for the day, it again instructed the jury not to talk with anyone about the case, and if anyone attempted to talk with them, they should report it to the bailiff the first thing in the morning. Â After the jury exited the courtroom, the trial court stated, â€œLet the record note that I admonished the jury not to talk about the case and to report back in the morning of any efforts to contact her.Â  I looked directly at [the juror ], who was in previously, and she nodded to me both times.Â  So I donâ€™t think thereâ€™s any point of me singling her out;Â  she got the message and nodded both times.â€Â  The court further cautioned the members of the victimâ€™s family present in the courtroom not to contact the daycare worker who was the cousin of the victim.Â  When the trial resumed the next morning, the jury was questioned whether any of them heard anything about the case or were contacted by anyone in regard to it, and the court received a negative response.Â  At the conclusion of testimony for that day, the trial court again instructed the jury not to talk about the case, and again received a negative response when it asked the jury the next morning if any of them had been contacted by anyone in regard to the case.Â  
On appeal, Bell contends the trial court erred in refusing to dismiss the juror.Â  He argues the colloquy between the court and the juror shows the juror was apprehensive and uncomfortable about the situation.Â  He further maintains, even accepting the juror would not have been disqualified had the relationship been raised during voir dire, because this juror would continue to see the decedentâ€™s cousin who was caring for the jurorâ€™s child, this juror would have been removed by the exercise of a peremptory challenge. Â Accordingly, Bell asserts the trial court abused his discretion in refusing to replace the juror.Â  We disagree.
â€œA â€˜defendant has a constitutional right to be tried by competent jurors,â€™ which â€˜implies a tribunal both impartial and mentally competent to afford a hearing.â€™â€Â  State v. Hurd, 325 S.C. 384, 389, 480 S.E.2d 94, 97 (Ct. App. 1996) (quoting Tanner v. United States, 483 U.S. 107, 134, 107 S.Ct. 2739, 2755, 97 L.Ed.2d 90 (1987) (Marshall, J., dissenting)).Â  A decision on whether to dismiss a juror and replace her with an alternate is within the sound discretion of the trial court, and such decision will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Smith, 338 S.C. 66, 71, 525 S.E.2d 263, 265 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  More specifically, â€œ[i]t is within the discretion of the trial court to determine whether bias results from a jurorâ€™s reception of outside information concerning the case being tried.â€Â  Washington v. Whitaker, 317 S.C. 108, 118, 451 S.E.2d 894, 900 (1994).Â  See also State v. Ivey, 331 S.C. 118, 123, 502 S.E.2d 92, 94 (1998) (noting a jurorâ€™s competence is within the trial courtâ€™s discretion and is not reviewable on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence).
Bell relies on the case of State v. Stone, 350 S.C. 442, 567 S.E.2d 244 (2002) in arguing the trial court abused its discretion in refusing to remove the juror. Â In Stone, the defendantâ€™s aunt was called as a witness during the sentencing phase of the trial.Â  When the aunt took the stand, one of the jurors informed the court that she knew the aunt.Â  Although the auntâ€™s name had been announced at the start of voir dire, the juror did not know her name.Â  The juror had lived down the street from the aunt some five or six years earlier, and they were casual acquaintances only.Â  The State objected to the continued participation of the juror arguing it would be difficult for the juror to impose a death sentence on a former acquaintanceâ€™s nephew, and the trial court removed the juror, replacing her with an alternate.Â  Our supreme court reversed, finding the trial court abused its discretion in removing the juror.Â  Id. at 448-49, 567 S.E. 2d at 247-48.Â  Bell maintains, unlike the finding of the court in Stone that failure to disclose an acquaintance with a witness would not have been a material factor in the exercise of a peremptory challenge, the juror here would have been removed by the exercise of a peremptory challenge and therefore the trial court abused its discretion in failing to remove the juror.Â  In Stone, however, the court reaffirmed the following proposition:

  When a juror conceals information inquired into during voir dire, a new trial is required only when the court finds the juror intentionally concealed the information, and that the information concealed would have supported a challenge for cause or would have been a material factor in the use of the partyâ€™s peremptory challenges.

Id. at 448, 567 S.E.2d at 247 (quoting State v. Woods, 345 S.C. 583, 587-88, 550 S.E.2d 282, 284 (2001) (citations omitted) (emphasis added).Â  Here, there is no concealment, intentional or otherwise, of information by a juror.Â  Thus, the language from Stone regarding whether the information would have been a material factor in the use of a peremptory challenge is inapplicable to this case.
The record here discloses the trial court properly inquired into the jurorâ€™s exposure to outside information and the effect the information would have on her ability to be a fair and impartial juror.Â  Contrary to Bellâ€™s assertion, the juror unequivocally stated this outside knowledge would not affect her decision or her ability to be fair and impartial.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in allowing her to remain on the jury.Â  See State v. Ivey, 331 S.C. 118, 122-23, 502 S.E.2d 92, 94 (1998) (holding, where juror sent note to judge during trial that she knew individual who allegedly loaned murder weapon to defendantâ€™s accomplice, trial judge properly inquired into the effect jurorâ€™s knowledge of this person would have on her ability to be fair and impartial, and juror unequivocally stated such knowledge would have no effect on her ability to render an impartial verdict, the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in allowing juror to remain on the jury);Â  Washington v. Whitaker, 317 S.C. 108, 117-18, 451 S.E.2d 894, 900 (1994) (holding, where juror heard a radio announcement concerning the case on the third day of trial but unequivocally stated she would not permit broadcast to influence her decision, trial court properly denied motion to remove juror).
Based on the foregoing, Bellâ€™s convictions are
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR. 
[2] The client interview sheet is a form document wherein Penn recorded personal information about Bell such as his address, age, social security number, marital status and education.Â  At the bottom of the form was a section for notes wherein Penn handwrote the name of the victim and the location of the incident, and noted â€œ[Defendant and] victim had an argument at the apartment . . . .Â  Somebody shot him [and defendant] ran with everybody else.â€Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Hardaway Concrete Company, Inc., Respondent,
        v.
        Hall Contracting Corporation, Principal and Contractor; and Travelers Casualty
          & Surety Company of America, Surety, Defendants,
        Of whom Hall Contracting Corporation, Principal and Contractor is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Joseph M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity

Opinion No. 4252
Heard January 9, 2007 â€“ Filed June 8, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, 
REVERSED IN PART,
AND MODIFIED.


  
    
      
        M. Alan Peace and Donald W. Tyler, Jr., both of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        David M. Ratchford and Brian C. Gambrell, both of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  In
  this breach of contract action,Hall Contracting Corporation (Hall) appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s
  finding for Hardaway Concrete Company, Inc. (Hardaway) and awarding Hardaway
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and modify.
FACTS
The South Carolina Public Service
  Authority (Santee Cooper) sought bids for suppliers and contractors in the
  construction of a new power plant in Cross, South Carolina.Â  Initially,
  Santee Cooper sought bids from suppliers of the materials to be used in the
  construction process.Â  Hardaway submitted a successful bid to become the
  concrete supplier and entered into a contract with Santee Cooper.Â  The
  contract provided that Hardaway set up two on-site concrete plants: a primary
  plant with a rated capacity of 150 cubic yards of concrete per hour and a
  backup plant with a rated capacity of 100 cubic yards of concrete per hour.Â  The
  contract specified the concrete be delivered to the jobsite in a â€œtimely and
  continuous manner.â€ Â Hardaway would be paid by the concrete placement
  contractor, not Santee Cooper, according to the cubic yards agreed to on the
  batch tickets. Â Further, the contract required Hardaway to furnish
  â€œ[i]ce making and cooling equipment for temperature control during hot weather
  concrete placementâ€ and provided for the price per pound of ice Hardaway would
  receive. Â 
After accepting Hardawayâ€™s bid, Santee
  Cooper sought bids for concrete placement contractors for the foundation of the

  appeal.Â  Joubert v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs., 341 S.C. 176,
  192-93, 534 S.E.2d 1, 9-10 (Ct. App. 2000) (noting that the failure to provide
  argument or supporting authority for an issue renders it abandoned).Â  
CONCLUSION
The
  evidence in the record supports the master awarding judgment in favor of
  Hardaway and ordering Hall to pay the outstanding amount of $45,123.84 minus $1,874.50 for the provision of ice.Â  The master
  correctly awarded attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  However, we find the master
  erred in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees for the lost sanctions motion and reduce the
  attorneyâ€™s fees award by $5,377.50.Â  Accordingly, the order of
  the master is
AFFIRMED IN
  PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND MODIFIED.
ANDERSON and HUFF,
  JJ., concur.



[1]Â  Hall further contended in its brief that even if the
  contract was not governed by the U.C.C., Hardaway was estopped from objecting
  to the specifications in the purchase order and pour specifications.Â  However,
  at the oral argument of this case, Hallâ€™s attorney informed this court that it
  was specifically waiving its estoppel argument and was proceeding solely on the
  U.C.C. argument.Â  Thus, we need only address the U.C.C. argument.
[2]Â  Hardaway also asserted for the first time at oral
  argument that the ice issue was not preserved for review because Hallâ€™s U.C.C.
  and estoppel arguments were not ruled upon by the trial judge and constitute
  the â€œonly basis for appeal.â€Â  Although Hall raises U.C.C. and estoppel
  arguments with regard to pour specifications in its brief, it is clear from the
  separate ice argument that Hall is only referring to the wording of the
  underlying contracts.Â  The contract matter was ruled upon by the master, and it
  is preserved for our review. 
[3] The actual letters are not included in the record. Â 
[4]Â  Hall specifically references $125 of fees charged
  for the services of â€œdrs.â€Â  Although nothing in the record indicates who â€œdrsâ€
  is, Hardaway alleges that â€œdrsâ€ refers to its attorneyâ€™s law clerk.Â Â

title: Hernandez-Zuniga v. Tickle
description: The Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission found Andrew Tickle did not regularly employ four or more employees, thus the Appellate Panel did not have jurisdiction to award benefits to Hernandez-Zuniga.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Rocque Hernandez-Zuniga, Appellant,
				v.
				Andrew Tickle and South Carolina Uninsured Employers Fund, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4253
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 14, 2007

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Tiffany R. Spann-Wilder, of North Charleston, for Appellant.
				Terri Morrill Lynch, of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	


ANDERSON, J.: Â The Appellate Panel of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (â€œSCWCCâ€) found Andrew Tickle (â€œTickleâ€) did not regularly employ four or more employees.Â  Accordingly, the Appellate Panel did not have jurisdiction to award benefits to Hernandez-Zuniga (â€œClaimantâ€).Â  The circuit court affirmed the Decision and Order of the Appellate Panel.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Claimant sustained his injury on May 10, 2003 when he fell from a ladder while painting for his employer, Tickle.Â  He sought temporary disability benefits and medical treatment under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act (Act).Â  Tickle claimed he was not subject to the Act because he regularly employed less than four workers.Â 
 
At the time of his hearing, Claimant was a twenty-one year old Honduran with a sixth grade education who had been in the United States four years working as a painter.Â  He began working for Tickle some time in the spring of 2003.Â  Claimant worked eight hours a day and some weekends, earning ten dollars per hour.Â  Tickle paid him directly, once a week, in cash.Â  After commencing work for Tickle, Claimant worked regularly for approximately one month, until the day he fell.Â  Claimant believed he would have continued employment with Tickle had he not been injured.Â 
 
Claimant undertook three projects for Tickleâ€”one project painting beach chairs and two house-painting projects.Â  Two people, Claimant and Alle Hernandez (Alle),[2] worked on the beach chairs project.Â  Claimant, Alle, and Victor Valdez (Victor) began painting the first house owned by the Garretts.Â  Claimant and Alle subsequently went to the Hewitt[3] home while Victor purportedly continued work on the Garrett house.Â  Franklin Hernandez-Zuniga (Franklin) allegedly joined Claimant and Alle at the Hewitt home, the site where Claimant fell. Â Claimant believed Franklin began work the day before the accident and quit shortly after Claimant was injured.Â  Victor moved to the Hewitt project after Claimantâ€™s accident.Â 
 
Tickle left his previous employer, the Finish Company, in 2003 and started his own business as a painting contractor.Â  He claimed he initially arranged with Claimant and the other workers to supply all the paint for the Garrett house, get a draw each week, and divide the proceeds with them, in cash, without tax deductions. Â Ultimately he paid them weekly wages at an hourly rate. Â Tickle explained he hired the workers â€œproject by projectâ€ because he had not yet established his company.Â  Claimant and his co-workers provided their own brushes and caulk guns.Â  Tickle acknowledged he agreed to pay them a flat fee of $1000 to paint the Hewitt house. Â Claimant did not complete the Hewitt project because of his injury, so Tickle paid him hourly for work completed. Â 
Tickle asseverated there were never more than three people working for him in April or May 2003.Â  He thought someone helped finish up after Claimant fell but denied knowing anyone named Franklin working on the projects.Â  Beth Garrett, owner of the first house Tickleâ€™s crew painted, maintained she never observed more than three people working on her home.
Tickle obtained a business license on June 26, 2003 and established Tickle Tools in July 2003.Â  He declared he conducted no official business as Tickle Tools before July 21, 2003.
 
The hearing commissioner found:

	The evidence established that upon the jobs where the Claimant worked there were only two (2) individuals on the first and three (3) on the second.Â  The only evidence of employment of four (4) employees, which is conflicting, was for a day or two.Â  Therefore, the Claimant did not meet his burden of proving the Employer â€œregularlyâ€ employed four or more employees.
	

Accordingly, the hearing commissioner ruled Claimant was not entitled to benefits under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act because Tickle did not regularly employ four (4) or more employees as required by section 42-1-150 of the South Carolina Code of Laws (Supp. 2006).Â  Consequently, the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission lacked jurisdiction to address the claim.Â  The Appellate Panel affirmed the hearing commissionerâ€™s ruling and adopted his Decision and Order in its entirety. Â The circuit court affirmed.Â Â Â 
 
ISSUE
Did the Claimant demonstrate by a preponderance of the evidence that Tickle regularly employed four or more employees and was subject to the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act?
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Judicial review of a Workersâ€™ Compensation decision is governed by the substantial evidence rule of the Administrative Procedures Act.Â  Baxter v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006); Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  However, if the factual issue before the Commission involves a jurisdictional question, this courtâ€™s review is governed by the preponderance of evidence standard. Â Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 343 S.C. 102, 108, 538 S.E.2d 276, 279 (Ct. App. 2000) affâ€™d 349 S.C. 589, 564 S.E.2d 110 (2002); Kirksey v. Assurance Tire Co., 314 S.C. 43, 45, 443 S.E.2d 803, 804 (1994); Vines v. Champion Bldg. Prods., 315 S.C. 13, 16, 431 S.E.2d, 585, 586 (1993); Porter v. Labor Depot, Op. No. 4212 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Mar. 5, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 9 at 52); Cooke v. Palmetto Health Alliance, 367 S.C. 167, 173, 624 S.E.2d 439, 441 (Ct. App. 2005); Edens v. Bellini, 359 S.C. 433, 440, 597 S.E.2d 863, 867 (Ct. App. 2004); Simons v. Longbranch Farms, Inc., 345 S.C. 277, 280, 547 S.E.2d 500, 502 (Ct. App. 2001); Lake v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 248, 498 S.E.2d 650, 654 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Consequently, our review is not bound by the Commissionâ€™s findings of fact on which jurisdiction is based. Â Canady v. Charleston County Sch. Dist., 265 S.C. 21, 25, 216 S.E.2d 755, 757 (1975) A reviewing court has both the power and duty to review the entire record, find jurisdictional facts without regard to conclusions of the Commission on the issue, and decide the jurisdictional question in accord with the preponderance of evidence.Â  Id ; see also Kirksey, 314 S.C. at 45, 443 S.E.2d at 804 (holding this court can find facts in accordance with the preponderance of evidence when determining a jurisdictional question in a Workersâ€™ Compensation case); Sanders v. Litchfield Country Club, 297 S.C. 339, 342, 377 S.E.2d 111, 113 (Ct. App. 1989) (deciding where a jurisdictional issue is raised, this court must review record and make its own determination whether the preponderance of evidence supports the Commissionâ€™s factual findings bearing on that issue).
Workersâ€™ compensation statutes are construed liberally in favor of coverage, and South Carolinaâ€™s policy is to resolve jurisdictional doubts in favor of the inclusion of employees within workersâ€™ compensation coverage. Â Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 343 S.C. 102, 109, 538 S.E.2d 276, 279 (Ct. App. 2000) affâ€™d 349 S.C. 589, 564 S.E.2d 110 (2002) (citing Mauldin v. Dyna-Color/Jack Rabbit, 308 S.C. 18, 416 S.E.2d 639 (1992); Oâ€™Briant v. Daniel Constr. Co., 279 S.C. 254, 305 S.E.2d 241 (1983); Horton v. Baruch, 217 S.C. 48, 59 S.E.2d 545 (1950); Spivey v. D.G. Constr. Co., 321 S.C. 19, 467 S.E.2d 117 (Ct. App. 1996); McLeod v. Piggly Wiggly Carolina Co., 280 S.C. 466, 313 S.E.2d 38 (Ct. App. 1984)).

	In determining such jurisdictional questions, it must be kept in mind that the basic purpose of the Workmenâ€™s Compensation Act is the inclusion of employers and employees within its coverage and not their exclusion, and doubts of jurisdiction will be resolved in favor of inclusion rather than exclusion. Â However, a construction should not be adopted that does violence to the specific provisions of the Act.Â  
	

White v. J. T. Strahan Co., 244 S.C. 120, 135 S.E.2d 720, 723 (1964)
While the appellate court may take its own view of the preponderance of evidence on the existence of an employer-employee relationship, the final determination of witness credibility is usually reserved to the Appellate Panel. Â See Dawkins v. Jordan, 341 S.C. 434, 441, 534 S.E.2d 700, 704 (2000) (citing Ford v. Allied Chem. Corp., 252 S.C. 561, 167 S.E.2d 564 (1969)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Claimant contends the circuit court erred in finding Tickle was not an employer subject to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act because he did not have four or more persons regularly employed.Â  Specifically, Claimant maintains that four workers were Tickleâ€™s regular employees, and three individuals were his statutory employees.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe issue of whether an employer regularly employs the requisite number of employees to be subject to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is jurisdictional.â€Â  Harding v. Plumley, 329 S.C. 580, 584, 496 S.E.2d 29, 31 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  The question of subject matter jurisdiction is a question of law.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 183, 528 S.E.2d 435, 440 (Ct. App. 2000); Roper Hosp. v. Clemons, 326 S.C. 534, 536, 484 S.E.2d 598, 599 (Ct. App. 1997)).Â  On appeal from the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission, this court may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  
 
Pellucidly, the appellate courtâ€™s standard of review in cases involving jurisdictional questions is not a substantial evidence standard.Â  Our precedent lucidly establishes that an appellate court reviews jurisdictional issues by making its own findings of fact without regard to the findings and conclusions of the Appellate Panel.Â  Harding, 329 S.C at 584, 496 S.E.2d at 31 (citing Kirksey, 314 S.C. at 45, 443 S.E.2d at 804).Â  Furthermore, the appellate court evaluates the record and resolves the issue by determining whether the preponderance of evidence supports inclusion under the Act.Â  Id.Â  The appellant bears the burden of showing that the circuit courtâ€™s decision is against the preponderance of evidence.Â  Gray, 339 S.C. at 182, 528 S.E.2d at 440 (citing Lake v. Reeder Constr. Co., 330 S.C. 242, 498 S.E.2d 650 (Ct. App. 1998)); Chavis v. Watkins, 256 S.C. 30, 180 S.E.2d 648 (1971); Crim v. Decoratorâ€™s Supply, 291 S.C. 193, 352 S.E.2d 520 (Ct. App. 1987).
I.  Four or More Persons Regularly Employed
Claimant urges that section 42-1-360(2) does not apply in the instant case, because the greater weight of the evidence indicates Tickle had four regularly employed workers during the relevant time period.Â 
 
The South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act does not mandate coverage for all employees.Â  Section 42-1-360 specifies that the Act excludes 
 

	(1) Casual employees, as defined in Â§ 42-1-130, and Federal employees in this State;
	(2) Any person who has regularly employed in service less than four employees in the same business within the State or who had a total annual payroll during the previous calendar year of less than three thousand dollars regardless of the number of persons employed during that period;
	(3) Textile Hall Corporation, an eleemosynary corporation whose principal object is the organizing and production of the Southern Textile Exposition;
	(4) State and county fair associations; unless any such employer voluntarily elects to be bound by this Title, as provided by Â§ 42-1-380.
	(5) Agricultural employees; unless the agricultural employer voluntarily elects to be bound by this Title, as provided by Â§ 42-1-380.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-360 (Supp. 2006); see also Nolan v. National Sales Co., Inc., 294 S.C. 371, 372, 364 S.E.2d 752, 753 (1988) (holding an employer must have at least four employees in the state to be subject to provisions of South Carolinas Workersâ€™ Compensation Act).
Addressing the minimum number requirement in exemption provisions like section 42-1-306(2), Professor Larson inculcates:

	The controlling number of employees is determined in light of the employerâ€™s established mode or plan in the operation of its business.Â  If it regularly employs the requisite number, the employer remains covered although the number employed falls temporarily below the minimum.Â  Ordinarily only such employees as would themselves be subject to the act are included in the count.Â  Details of interpretation should be controlled by the underlying purpose of the exemption, which is to avoid administrative inconvenience to very small employers.
	The most common problem under the usual wording of statutes conferring this type of exemption is the question of whether the employer â€œregularlyâ€ employs more than the minimum number.Â  Since the practical effect of the numerical boundary is normally to determine whether compensation insurance is compulsory, an employer cannot be allowed to oscillate between coverage and exemption as its labor force exceeds or falls below the minimum from day to day.Â  Therefore, if an employer has once regularly employed enough men to come under the act, it remains there even when the number employed temporarily falls below the minimum.Â  The term â€œregularly employedâ€ has been construed to embrace regularly-employed part-time as well as full-time workers.Â  In all these cases, the fact that the number working at the exact time of injury was below the minimum is of course immaterial. . . .
	The question whether a particular employee should be disregarded for numerical-minimum purposes is very similar to the question whether he or she is a casual employee.Â  It has been said that the two concepts are the same, and observation which, if true, would somewhat simplify the classification problem.Â  As in the casual employment definition, both duration and regularity of recurrence are important factors.Â  Thus, if the minimum number is exceeded on only eight of the one hundred and four days preceding the accident, the employer is not regularly employing the minimum.Â  But if the number exceeds the minimum on seventeen out of twenty-seven days in the course of a construction job, the employer is covered. . . .Â  It is the established mode or plan of operation of the business that is decisive.
	

4 Larson, Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§Â§ 74.01-02 (internal quotations and citations omitted).Â  
 
A.  â€œRegularly Employedâ€
In Harding v. Plumley, we applied section 42-1-360 (2) to a set of facts similar to those in the instant case.Â  329 S.C. at 584, 496 S.E.2d at 31. Â Plumley owned a construction company and hired Harding as a general laborer.Â  Id. at 582, 496 S.E.2d at 30.Â  Harding was injured on his first and only day on the job.Â  Id.Â  The hearing commissioner found the relevant time period for determining the number of regularly employed workers ran from two months before through two months after the accident, which corresponded to the period of construction.Â  Id. at 584, 496 S.E.2d at 31. Â We concluded Plumley had â€œat the most, two regularly employed laborersâ€ who worked during the relevant time period and were paid on an almost weekly basis.Â  Id. at 586, 496 S.E.2d at 33.Â  Two other laborers worked on occasion and received only one or two paychecks.Â  Id.Â  Assuming Hardingâ€™s one day on the job amounted to regular employment, a fourth employee was still needed to meet jurisdictional requirements under section 42-1-360.Â  Id. at 587, 496 S.E.2d at 33.Â  
 
Turning to the case sub judice, we focus on the definition of â€œregularly employed.â€Â  As noted in Harding, section 42-1-360 does not define the term â€œregularly employed.â€ 329 S.C. at 584, 496 S.E.2d at 31.Â  When faced with an undefined statutory term, the court must interpret the term in accord with its usual and customary meaning.Â  Branch v. City of Myrtle Beach, 340 S.C. 405, 409-10, 532 S.E.2d 289, 292 (2000); Liberty Mut. Ins. Co. v. South Carolina Second Injury Fund, 363 S.C. 612, 622, 611 S.E.2d 297, 302 (Ct. App. 2005); University of Southern California v. Moran, 365 S.C. 270, 276, 617 S.E.2d 135, 138 (Ct. App. 2005); see also Santee Cooper Resort v. South Carolina Pub. Serv. Commâ€™n, 298 S.C. 179, 184, 379 S.E.2d 119, 122 (1989) (â€œWords used in a statute should be taken in their ordinary and popular significance unless there is something in the statute requiring a different interpretation.â€). Â â€œThe terms must be construed in context and their meaning determined by looking at the other terms used in the statute.â€ Â Hinton v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole and Pardon Servs., 357 S.C. 327, 332-33, 592 S.E.2d 335, 338 (Ct. App. 2004).
Courts should consider not merely the language of the particular clause being construed, but the word and its meaning in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.Â  Whitner v. State, 328 S.C. 1, 16, 492 S.E.2d 777, 779 (1997); see also State v. Gordon, 356 S.C. 143, 152, 588 S.E.2d 105, 110 (2003) (â€œ[T]he court should not consider the particular clause being construed in isolation, but should read it in conjunction with the purpose of the whole statute and the policy of the law.â€); Stephen v. Avins Const. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 340, 478 S.E.2d 74, 77 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding statutory provisions should be given reasonable and practical construction consistent with purpose and policy of entire act).Â  
 
Dictionaries can be helpful tools during the initial stages of legal research for the purpose of defining statutory terms. Â Heilker v. Zoning Bd. of Appeals for City of Beaufort, 346 S.C. 401, 409, 552 S.E.2d 42, 46 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  The term â€œregularlyâ€ means â€œ[a]t fixed and certain intervals, regular in point of time.Â  In accordance with some consistent or periodical rule or practice.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary, 1286 (6th ed. 1990).Â  â€œRegularâ€ is defined as â€œusual, customary, normal or general.â€Â  Id. at 1285. 
 
In the context of construing the statute, the term â€œregularâ€ is often juxtaposed with the term â€œcasual.â€ Â 4 Larson, Workersâ€™Compensation Â§Â§ 74.01-02 (â€œIt has been said that the two concepts are the same . . . in the casual employment definition, both duration and regularity of recurrence are important factors.â€).Â  Where employment cannot be characterized as permanent or periodically regular, but occurs by chance, or with the intention and understanding on the part of both employer and employee that it shall not be continuous, it is casual. Â Smith v. Coastal Tire and Auto Service 263 S.C. 77, 81, 207 S.E.2d 810, 812 (1974).Â  â€œEmployment is casual when not permanent or periodically regular but occasional or by chance and not in the usual course of the employers trade or business.â€Â  Singleton v. J. P. Stevens & Co., Inc., 533 F. Supp. 887, 892 (D.C.S.C. 1982) affâ€™d Singleton v. J.P. Stevens & Co., Inc., 726 F.2d 1011 (4th Cir. (1984); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-130 (Supp. 2006) (excluding â€œa person whose employment is both casual and not in the course of the trade, business, profession, or occupation of his employerâ€ from the definition of employee under the Act).Â  
 
Because South Carolina workersâ€™ compensation law is fashioned after North Carolinaâ€™s statute, our courts often rely on North Carolina precedent for guidance in interpreting the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 343 S.C. 102, 117-118, 538 S.E.2d 276, 284 (Ct. App. 2000) affâ€™d 349 S.C. 589, 564 S.E.2d 110 (2002) (citing Spoone v. Newsome Chevrolet-Buick, 309 S.C. 432, 424 S.E.2d 489 (1992); Stephen v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 340, 478 S.E.2d 74, 77 (Ct. App. 1996) (decisions of North Carolina courts interpreting that stateâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation statute are entitled to weight when South Carolina courts interpret South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation law).Â  
 
North Carolina courts have interpreted â€œregularly employedâ€ as â€œemployment of the same number of persons throughout the period with some constancy.â€Â  Grouse v. DRB Baseball Management, Inc., 465 S.E.2d 568, 570 (N.C. Ct. App. 1996) (citing Patterson v. L.M. Parker Co., 162 S.E.2d 571, 575 (1968)).Â  The court explained the purpose of the Act would not be accomplished â€œby making it applicable to an employer who may have had, in the total number of persons entering and leaving his service during the period, more than the minimum number required by the Act.â€Â  Patterson, 162 S.E.2d at 575. 
 
B.  Relevant Time Period
A priori, we must identify the relevant time period for determining whether a minimum number of persons were employed throughout the period with some constancy.Â  This task is particularly difficult for employment in which workers come and go due to the nature and type of work they perform.
As Professor Larson edifies, the employerâ€™s established mode or plan of operation dictates, to a large extent, the relevant time period, and both duration and regularity of occurrence are important factors.Â  In Harding, the time roughly corresponding to the duration of the construction project constituted the relevant period.Â  Harding v. Plumley, 329 S.C. 580, 584, 496 S.E.2d 29, 31 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Because only two employees worked with any constancy for the duration of that period, the employer was not required to provide Workersâ€™ Compensation coverage. Â Id. at 587, 496 S.E.2d at 31.
In Patterson, the North Carolina Supreme Court looked at the number employed six weeks prior to the claimantâ€™s injury and determined it was less than the jurisdictional minimum.Â  Patterson v. L.M. Parker Co., 162 S.E.2d 571, 574 (1968).Â  The court concluded the minimum number was not employed with sufficient constancy or regularity during that time to bring the employer under the provisions of the Act.Â  Id. Â 
In Durham v. McLamb, an employer hired four carpenters to work on a construction project in December, 1979.Â  296 S.E.2d 3, 5 (N.C. Ct. App. 1982).Â  The claimant was injured on December 20, 1979. Â Id. at 4. Â All the workers were discharged in January 1980 because the employer could no longer pay them.Â  Id. at 5.Â  The employer argued he was exempt from the Act because during the week claimant was injured, only three workers were on the job. Â Id. at 7. Â The court reasoned â€œthe number of workers on the job site on the date of the injury, standing alone, is not determinative of the issue. Â If the defendant had four or more â€œregularly employedâ€ employees, the fact that he fell below the minimum requirement on the actual date of injury would not preclude coverage.â€Â  Id.Â  The four employees were deemed full-time and â€œregularly employedâ€ until their discharge in early January, 1980. Â Id. Â â€œ[A]lthough they worked irregular days and hours, their employment extended over a period of some four weeks, during which they worked, not by chance or for a particular occasion, but according to a definite employment at hourly wages which were paid at the end of each week worked.â€Â  Id.
The North Carolina Court of Appeals revisited this issue in Grouse v. DRB Baseball Management, Inc., 465 S.E.2d 568, 570 (N.C. Ct. App. 1996).Â  The court found evidence DRB employed â€œwith some constancyâ€ at least four people during the year the claimant was injured, even though only three regularly employed workers were present on the day of the injury.Â  Id. at 571.Â Â  
 
In the case at bar, Tickle left the Finish Company and engaged in itinerant projects to earn income while he was developing his business plan.Â  His mode of operation was â€œproject to project.â€ Â He claimed he initially attempted to form a partnership with the workers. Â Nevertheless, he paid the workers hourly wages, and that arrangement persisted throughout the period. Â 
Once Claimant commenced work in the spring of 2003, he worked continuously until the day of his accident, a period of approximately four to six weeks.Â  Work on Tickleâ€™s projects subsided after Claimant was injured and resumed after Tickle obtained a business license and workersâ€™ compensation insurance.
 
We determine the relevant time period for ascertaining whether Tickle regularly employed four or more employees with some constancy began when Claimant started working for Tickle on the beach chairs project.Â  The period terminated shortly after Claimantâ€™s injury, when Tickle ceased operating until he officially opened his business.
During the relevant period, the workers undertook three projects.Â  Two people worked on the first project painting beach chairs.Â  Three people worked on each of the two houses.Â  Allegedly, a fourth employee continued to finish up work on the Garrett house while the others moved on to the next project.Â  Claimant and Alle worked every weekday and some weekends after Tickle hired them; they expected their employment to continue.
 
Tickle disavowed any employment relationship with the workers, professing instead to have formed a business partnership with them.Â  The record provides little to substantiate Tickleâ€™s assertion.Â  Alternatively, Tickle admitted he hired the workers on a project-by-project basis, because he was just starting up his painting business.
We conclude Claimant and Alle were Tickleâ€™s employees and not business partners.Â  In addition, they were â€œregularly employedâ€ workers during the relevant period.Â  On the other hand, the greater weight of evidence indicates Franklin was not regularly employed by Tickle.Â  Testimony about the duration of his employment was conflicting and inconclusive.Â  Tickle disclaimed any knowledge that Franklin worked on any of the projects, though he was aware another individual might have worked on the Hewitt project. Â Moreover, Beth Garrett never observed more than three workers painting her house.Â  Even if Victor worked for Tickle at the same time, but in another location, Claimant still fails to demonstrate Tickle regularly employed at least four workers with some constancy during the relevant period. Â 
II.  Statutory Employees 

Claimant argues that three individuals were Tickleâ€™s statutory employees under section 42-1-400 and should be counted to meet the jurisdictional requirement of four or more regular employees.Â  We disagree.
 
The question of whether a worker is a statutory employee is jurisdictional and is therefore a question of law for the court.Â  Riden v. Kemet Electronics Corp., 313 S.C. 261, 263, 437 S.E.2d 156, 157 (Ct. App. 1993) (citing Â Â Bigham v. Nassau Recycle Corp., 285 S.C. 200, 328 S.E.2d 663 (Ct. App. 1985). Â 
Section 42-1-400 defines an ownerâ€™s obligation to provide workersâ€™ compensation coverage for the workmen of his subcontractor:

	When any person, in this section and Â§Â§ 42-1-420 and 42-1-430 referred to as â€œowner,â€ undertakes to perform or execute any work which is a part of his trade, business or occupation and contracts with any other person (in this section and Â§Â§ 42-1-420 to 42-1-450 referred to as â€œsubcontractorâ€) for the execution or performance by or under such subcontractor of the whole or any part of the work undertaken by such owner, the owner shall be liable to pay to any workman employed in the work any compensation under this Title which he would have been liable to pay if the workman had been immediately employed by him.

S.C.Â  Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-400 (Supp. 2006).
In Ost v. Integrated Prod., Inc.[4], the supreme court first addressed whether statutory employees of a subcontractor may be counted toward the number of employees required to bring the general contractor within the Act.Â  296 S.C. 241, 371 S.E.2d 796 (1988).Â  Integrated was a Georgia corporation employing three pilots who regularly flew into South Carolina in the course and scope of their employment. Â Id. at 243, 371 S.E.2d at 797. Â Integrated contracted with National Sales Company, a Georgia corporation, to provide personnel to sell Integratedâ€™s yarn products in South Carolina. Â Id.Â  Neither the pilots nor the sales personnel were residents of South Carolina, but 
all traveled into South Carolina regularly in the course of their employment.Â  
Id. (emphasis added).
Ost, a pilot for Integrated, was killed in an airplane crash near Greenville, South Carolina.Â  Id. at 242-43, 371 S.E.2d at 797.Â  The circuit court upheld a Workersâ€™ Compensation award of death benefits and Integrated appealed, arguing it had less than four employees working in South Carolina and was exempt from the Act under S.C. Code section 42-1-360(2). Â Id. at 242, 371 S.E.2d at 797.Â  Ost asserted the employees of National Sales, Integratedâ€™s subcontractor, were statutory employees and should be counted for purposes of meeting the jurisdictional requirement. Â Id.
The court analyzed three South Carolina cases interpreting section 42-1-400 â€œto determine whether employees of a secondary employer constitute statutory employees of the principal employer.â€Â  Ost, 296 S.C. at 244, 371 S.E.2d at 798.

	In the leading case, Marchbanks v. Duke Power Company, 190 S.C. 336, 2 S.E.2d 825 (1939), this Court held that when a person performs work which is part of the trade or business of the principal, the employees of the person will be considered statutory employees of the principal. Â We concluded that a person who was injured while painting the power companyâ€™s pole was engaged in the â€˜trade, business or occupationâ€™ of the power company because the activity was an important part of the power companyâ€™s trade or business.
	Likewise, in Boseman v. Pacific Mills, 193 S.C. 479, 8 S.E.2d 878 (1940), we held that when an activity performed by the employees of a subcontractor is necessary, or essential to, or an integral part of, the operation of the principal employerâ€™s business, the employees of the subcontractor constitute the statutory employees of the principal employer.Â  There, an employee of the subcontractor, who was painting a water tank at a mill, was killed when the tank caught fire and exploded. Â Our court reasoned that the water tank, which provided essential protection to the mill against fires, was an integral part of the trade or business of the mill as to subject it to liability for the death of Boseman.
	This court espoused another test to determine whether an employee of a subcontractor was a statutory employee in
	Bridges v. Wyandotte Worsted Company, 243 S.C. 1, 132 S.E.2d 18 (1963). Â In 
	Bridges, the defendant contracted with an electric company, plaintiffâ€™s employer, to repair or replace the transmission line owned by the defendant and located on his property. Â The lines had been replaced on a previous occasion, and customarily maintained by a qualified crew regularly employed by the defendant. Â We concluded that the repair or replacement of the transmission lines was a part of the work ordinarily and customarily performed by the employees of the defendant in the prosecution of the defendantâ€™s business. Â Finding the repair of the transmission lines was a part of the defendantâ€™s trade or business, we held that the defendant was liable for the subcontractorâ€™s employeesâ€™ injuries.

Id. at 245, 371 S.E.2d at 798-99.
Thus, a three-part test emerged to ascertain whether employees of a subcontractor are statutory employees of the general contractor. Â Id. at 246-47, 371 S.E.2d at 799. Â â€œThis statutory requirement has been construed to include activities that: (1) are an important part of the trade or business of the employer, (2) are a necessary, essential, and integral part of the business of the employer, or (3) have been previously performed by employees of the employer.â€Â  Glass v. Dow Chemical Co., 325 S.C. 198, 201, 482 S.E.2d 49, 50-51 (1997) (citing S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-400 (1976)); Woodard v. Westvaco Corp., 315 S.C. 329, 337, 433 S.E.2d 890, 894 (Ct. App. 1993), vacated on other grounds, 319 S.C. 240, 460 S.E.2d 392 (1995)). Â â€œOnly one of these tests must be met in order for a subcontractorâ€™s employees to be considered the statutory employees of the owner.â€ Â Glass, 325 S.C. at 201, 482 S.E.2d at 51 (citing Woodard, 315 S.C. at 337, 433 S.E.2d at 894). Â â€œSince no easily applied formula can be laid down for determining whether work in a particular case meets these tests, each case must be decided on its own facts.â€ Â Id. (citing Ost, 296 S.C. at 244, 371 S.E.2d at 798); see also Olmstead v. Shakespeare, 354 S.C. 421, 581 S.E.2d 483 (2003); Meyer v. Piggly Wiggly No. 24, Inc., 331 S.C. 261, 500 S.E.2d 190 (Ct. App. 1998). 
 
The Ost court concluded National Salesâ€™ employees were statutory employees of Integrated and held those employees may be included to satisfy the four person jurisdictional requirement of Section 42-1-360(2). Â Ost, 296 S.C. at 247, 371 S.E.2d at 799. Â In reaching this conclusion the court considered the underlying purpose of the Act:Â  
 

	It was evidently realized by the General Assembly that it would not be fair to relieve the owner of compensation to employees doing work which was part of his trade or business by permitting such owner to sublet or subcontract some part of said work. Â Doubtless in many instances such contractor would be financially irresponsible, or the number of employees under him would be so small, as in this case, that such contractor would not be required under the Act to carry compensation insurance. Â It was therefore, provided under the first paragraph that where such work in which the employee was engaged was a part of the ownerâ€™s trade or business, the owner would be responsible in compensation to all employees doing such work, whether employees of an independent contractor or not.

Id. at 247, 371 S.E.2d at 800.
In Harding, Plumley engaged two subcontractors during the relevant time period to perform certain parts of the construction.Â  329 S.C. at 585, 496 S.E.2d at 32.Â  Harding argued the subcontractorsâ€™ two workers were statutory employees according to section 42-1-400 of the South Carolina Code of Laws and should be counted in determining whether Plumley was exempt under provision 42-1-360(2).Â  Id.Â  The court considered Ost in addressing the claimantâ€™s argument.Â  We noted one of Plumleyâ€™s subcontractors was paid only once and the other, twice, during the relevant time period.Â  In contrast, the statutory employees in Ost â€œregularlyâ€ traveled into South Carolina as part of their employment.Â  Even assuming Plumleyâ€™s subcontractorsâ€™ workers were statutory employees, we held the record did not support a conclusion that Plumley employed the â€œsame number of persons through the period with some constancy.â€ Â Id. at 587, 496 S.E.2d at 33 (citing Patterson v. L.M. Parker Co., 162 S.E.2d 571, 575 (N.C. 1968).Â  
 
Here, Claimant asserted that three individualsâ€”Rene, Fernando Lucas, and Claudio Gomezâ€”were statutory employees of Tickle and should be counted toward the jurisdictional minimum.Â  Tickle disclosed that he hired Rene to finish up work after Claimantâ€™s accident.Â  He then explained Fernando Lucas was a finisher with whom he subcontracted to â€œdo a couple of patches.â€Â  Tickle paid Lucas $120.00 on April 10, 2003, $40.00 on May 2, 2003, and $970.00 on July 31, 2003.Â  Tickle issued a $750.00 check to Claudio Gomez on July 25, 2003.[5]Â  The record substantiates that Fernando Lucas performed work that was an important part of Tickleâ€™s painting business and a necessary and integral part of Tickleâ€™s trade.Â  See Ost, 296 S.C. at 244, 371 S.E.2d at 798.Â  However, without evidence describing the work Rene and Gomez performed, we cannot determine whether they were Tickleâ€™s statutory employees under section 42-1-400 and the test in Ost.Â  Even assuming the three were all statutory employees, our reasoning in Harding is equally applicable in addressing whether they should be counted toward the jurisdictional minimum.Â  Like the subcontractorsâ€™ workers in Harding, the statutory employees here did not work for Tickle in a regular, recurring capacity.Â  Although Tickle may have employed some additional workers or statutory employees, the record fails to support the conclusion that Tickle employed â€œthe same number of persons throughout the period with some constancy.â€ Â Harding v. Plumley, 329 S.C. at 587, 496 S.E.2d at 33.Â  
 
CONCLUSION
To promote the purpose of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, the statute is to be construed liberally for the protection of the injured worker, with jurisdictional doubts generally resolved in favor of inclusion.Â  We are, nevertheless, constrained to interpret the Act as it is written and do not have the power to expand its scope.Â 
 
The statutory language unequivocally exempts employers who do not regularly employ four or more employees.Â  We adopt the definition of â€œregularly employedâ€ as employment of the same number of persons with some constancy throughout a relevant time period.Â  We rule the relevant time period should be identified by considering (1) the employerâ€™s established mode of operation; (2) whether the employer generally employs the jurisdictional number at any time during his operation, and (3) the period during which employment is definite and recurrent rather than occasional, sporadic, or indefinite.Â 
 
Taking our own view of the preponderance of the evidence, we conclude Tickle regularly employed less than four workers during the identified relevant time period.Â  Tickle was exempt from the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act when Claimant sustained his injury.Â  The Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission did not have jurisdiction to consider his claim.Â  Â Â Â Â 
 
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is  
AFFIRMED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] This witness is referred to in the Briefs on Appeal as Alle Hernandez.Â  However, at the hearing the witness said his name was Alle Hernandez Alverez.Â  For the sake of clarity we will refer to him as â€œAlle.â€Â  Additionally, Appellantâ€™s Brief refers to Reneâ€™ Alverez, as the worker who finished up after Claimant was injured.Â  However, Tickle declared the workerâ€™s name was Reneâ€™ Everest.Â  Assuming this is the same individual, we will refer to him as â€œRene.â€
[3] The second painting job is confusingly referred to as the Hewitt house in some parts of the record and as the Pitts house in other parts.Â  For clarity we refer to the second house as the Hewitt house. 
 
[4] The court distinguished Nolan v. National Sales, 294 S.C. 371, 364 S.E.2d 752 (1988) in its analysis in Ost.Â  In Nolan, the claimant, a National Sales employee, attempted to amalgamate Integratedâ€™s pilots as Nationalâ€™s statutory employees in order to meet the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Actâ€™s jurisdictional requirement.Â  The Court of Appeals held Nolanâ€™s assertion was not preserved and without merit.Â  The supreme court affirmed and suggested its agreement with the Court of Appeals that National Sales, as the subcontractor of Integrated, could not count Integratedâ€™s employees to meet the jurisdictional requirement.
 
[5]Â  We are unable to identify from the handwriting on this check the purpose of its issue.
