title: Ecclesiastes Production Ministries v. Outparcel Associates
description: This opinion analyzes the efficacy of a mutual release between two entities as juxtaposed to a third party claim.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Ecclesiastes Production Ministries, Appellant,
				v.
				Outparcel Associates, LLC, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge 
Opinion No. 4254
Submitted June 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 14, 2007

REVERSED


	
		
			
				S. Allan Hill, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Ralph Gleaton, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	


ANDERSON, J.: Â Ecclesiastes Production Ministries (â€œEPMâ€) appeals the grant of a directed verdict in regard to its third-party claims against Outparcel Associates, LLC (â€œOutparcelâ€).Â  The trial judge granted Outparcelâ€™s motion based on a settlement agreement between EPM and JDL Holdings, LLC (â€œJDLâ€) that he deemed to require Outparcelâ€™s release as well.Â  We REVERSE.[1]
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
On July 18, 2001, EPM entered into an agreement with Outparcel for the lease of a building (â€œthe Leased Propertyâ€) in Greenville County.Â  The lease contained a seven-page, handwritten addendum granting EPM the option to purchase the land and the right of first refusal.
On March 31, 2003, without EPMâ€™s knowledge, Outparcel entered into a bond for title agreement with JDL for the sale of a larger tract of land that included the Leased Property.Â  JDL later filed suit against EPM to collect rent under the lease agreement between EPM and Outparcel.
EPM answered and brought Outparcel into the suit as a third-party defendant.Â  EPMâ€™s pleadings asserted, inter alia, that Outparcel had failed to offer a right of first refusal to EPM before entering into the bond for title agreement with JDL.Â  Additionally, EPM counterclaimed against JDL for fraud and tortious interference with its contractual right of first refusal.
Shortly before trial, on February 2, 2005, EPM and JDL settled their claims and released one another with a document they termed a â€œMutual Settlement and Releaseâ€ (â€œthe Settlement Agreementâ€).Â  The Settlement Agreement between EPM and JDL was conditioned upon EPM continuing to pursue its claims for damages against Outparcel.Â  Under certain circumstances, EPM was to share an award from Outparcel.Â  The document detailed how any recovered damages were to be divided between EPM and JDL.
EPMâ€™s third-party complaint against Outparcel came to trial on February 6, 2005.Â  At the conclusion of EPMâ€™s case, Outparcel moved for a directed verdict, arguing the Settlement Agreement had the effect of releasing EPMâ€™s claim against Outparcel.Â  The trial court granted the motion.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In ruling on a motion for a directed verdict, the trial court is required to view the evidence and the inferences that reasonably can be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the party opposing the motion. Â Hurd v. Williamsburg County, 363 S.C. 421, 611 S.E.2d 488 (2005); Hinkle v. Natâ€™l Cas. Ins. Co., 354 S.C. 92, 96, 579 S.E.2d 616, 618 (2003); Huffines Co. v. Lockhart, 365 S.C. 178, 187, 617 S.E.2d 125, 129 (Ct. App. 2005); Lingard v. Carolina By-Products, 361 S.C. 442, 446, 605 S.E.2d 545, 547 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The trial court must deny such a motion when the evidence yields more than one inference or its inference is in doubt. Â Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Reg., 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999); Collins Entertainment, Inc. v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 611 S.E.2d 262 (Ct. App. 2005); Sims v. Giles, 343 S.C. 708, 714, 541 S.E.2d 857, 860 (Ct. App. 2001). Â If the evidence as a whole is susceptible to more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied. Â Jinks v. Richland County, 355 S.C. 341, 345, 585 S.E.2d 281, 283 (2003); Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995); Huffines at 187, 617 S.E.2d at 129.
A motion for directed verdict goes to the entire case and may be granted only when the evidence raises no issue for the jury as to liability. Â Carolina Home Builders, Inc. v. Armstrong Furnace Co., 259 S.C. 346, 358, 191 S.E.2d 774, 779 (1972).Â  â€œWhen the evidence yields only one inference, a directed verdict in favor of the moving party is proper.â€ Â Swinton Creek Nursery v. Edisto Farm Credit, ACA, 334 S.C. 469, 476-77, 514 S.E.2d 126, 130 (1999); accord Sims, at 714, 541 S.E.2d at 860; R & G Constr., Inc. v. Lowcountry Regâ€™l. Transp. Auth., 343 S.C. 424, 540 S.E.2d 113 (Ct. App. 2000). Â â€œThe issue must be submitted to the jury whenever there is material evidence tending to establish the issue in the mind of a reasonable juror.â€Â  Small v. Pioneer Machinery, Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 461, 494 S.E.2d 835, 841 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  However, if the evidence taken as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, the case must be submitted to the jury. Â Quesinberry v. Rouppasong, 331 S.C. 589, 594, 503 S.E.2d 717, 720 (1998); Getsinger v. Midlands Orthopaedic Profit Sharing Plan, 327 S.C. 424, 426, 489 S.E.2d 223, 223 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Heyward v. Christmas, 352 S.C. 298, 573 S.E.2d 845 (Ct. App. 2002) (if the evidence is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the court may not grant a directed verdict).
â€œWhen considering directed verdict motions, neither the trial court nor the appellate court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony or evidence.â€ Â Harvey v. Strickland, 350 S.C. 303, 308, 566 S.E.2d 529, 532 (2002); accord Pond Place Partners v. Poole, 351 S.C. 1, 15, 567 S.E.2d 881, 888 (Ct. App. 2002); Boddie-Noell Props., Inc. v. 42 Magnolia Pâ€™ship, 344 S.C. 474, 482, 544 S.E.2d 279, 283 (Ct. App. 2000), affâ€™d as modified by 352 S.C. 437, 574 S.E.2d 726 (2002). Â â€œThe issue must be submitted to the jury whenever there is material evidence tending to establish the issue in the mind of a reasonable juror.â€Â  Huffines, at 188, 617 S.E.2d at 129-30 (citing Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997)). Â However, this rule does not authorize the jury to the submission of speculative, theoretical, or hypothetical views. Â Small v. Pioneer Mach., Inc., 329 S.C. 448, 461, 494 S.E.2d 835, 842 (Ct. App. 1997). Â Our courts have recognized that when only one reasonable inference can be deduced from the evidence, the question becomes one of law for the court to determine. Â Bell v. Bank of Abbeville, 211 S.C. 167, 173, 44 S.E.2d 328, 330 (1947); Small, 329 S.C. at 461, 494 S.E.2d at 841-42. Â â€œA corollary of this rule is that verdicts may not be permitted to rest upon surmise, conjecture or speculation.â€ Â Hanahan, 326 S.C. at 149, 485 S.E.2d at 908; Small, 329 S.C. at 461, 494 S.E.2d at 841-42. Â This does not mean the trial court should ignore facts unfavorable to the opposing party. Â Long v. Norris & Assocs., Ltd., 342 S.C. 561, 568, 538 S.E.2d 5, 9 (Ct. App. 2000); Love v. Gamble, 316 S.C. 203, 208, 448 S.E.2d 876, 879 (Ct. App. 1994). Â In deciding whether to grant or deny a directed verdict motion, the court is concerned only with the existence or nonexistence of evidence. Â Pond Place Partners, Inc., 351 S.C. at 15, 567 S.E.2d at 888.
An appellate court will reverse only where there is no evidence to support the trial judgeâ€™s ruling, or where the ruling was controlled by an error of law. Â Clark v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Public Safety, 362 S.C. 377, 382-83, 608 S.E.2d 573, 576 (2005); Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing & Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 386, 520 S.E.2d 142, 148 (1999); Abu-Shawareb v. S.C. State Univ., 364 S.C. 358, 613 S.E.2d 757 (Ct. App. 2005); Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 300, 536 S.E.2d 408, 418 (Ct. App. 2000). Â Essentially, this court must resolve whether it would be reasonably conceivable to have a verdict for a party opposing the motion under the facts as liberally construed in the opposing partyâ€™s favor. Â Harvey, 350 S.C. at 309, 566 S.E.2d at 532; Hanahan, 326 S.C. at 149, 485 S.E.2d at 908.
LAW/ANALYSIS
EPM argues the trial judge erred in granting Outparcelâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on the ground that the mutual release granted by EPM and JDL to one another had the effect of releasing Outparcel as well.Â  EPM avers that viewing the facts in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party, the law of contract construction does not allow for finding that the Settlement Agreement provides for Outparcelâ€™s release from EPMâ€™s third-party claim.Â  We agree.
A. The Extant Precedent
1.Â  Settlement Agreements
The term â€œreleaseâ€ has been defined as the â€œrelinquishment, concession, or giving up of a right, claim, or privilege, by the person in whom it exists or to whom it accrues, to the person against whom it might have been demanded or enforced.â€Â  76 C.J.S. Release Â§ 2 (1994).Â  A release is an agreement providing that a duty owed to the maker of the release is discharged immediately.Â  Id.; see also Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1315-16 (6th ed. 1990) (a release is the act of giving up a right or claim to the person against whom it could have been enforced).Â  Whether a particular agreement constitutes a release is to be determined from the intent of the parties.Â  Id.
Under the common law, the release of one of multiple joint tortfeasors, unavoidably resulted in the release of all. Bartholomew v. McCartha, 255 S.C. 489, 179 S.E.2d 912 (1971).Â  In response to the obvious quandaries caused by this rule, South Carolina jurisprudence adopted documents in lieu of a general release:Â  (1) a covenant not to sue; and (2) a covenant not to execute.Â  A covenant not to sue was recognized and approved in Powers v. Temple, 250 S.C. 149, 156 S.E.2d 759 (1967).Â  A covenant not to execute received the imprimatur and approbation of our supreme court in Poston by Poston v. Barnes, 294 S.C. 261, 363 S.E.2d 888 (1987).
In Ackerman v. Travelers Indemnity Co., 318 S.C. 137, 456 S.E.2d 408 (Ct. App. 1995), this court discussed the genesis of the covenant not to sue:

	At common law, a valid release of one joint tort-feasor was usually a release of all the joint wrongdoers and was a bar to a suit against any of them for the same wrong.Â  At the base of this rule was the theory that there could be but one compensation for the joint wrong.Â  If the injured party was paid by one of the wrongdoers for the injury he had suffered, each wrongdoer being responsible for the whole damage, his cause of action was satisfied in exchange for a release, and he could not proceed against the others.Â  Thus a release of one joint wrongdoer released all.Â  But when the consideration received for the release was not full compensation for the injury, the purpose for the harsh rule did not exist.Â  To allow for this, the covenant not to sue was developed.

Ackerman, 318 S.C. at 146-47, 456 S.E.2d at 413.Â  Technically, in the case of a release, there is an immediate discharge; whereas, in the case of a covenant not to sue, there is merely an agreement not to prosecute a suit.Â  66 Am. Jur. 2d Release Â§ 2 (1973).Â  
 
The differences between a covenant not to sue and a covenant not to execute were succinctly explained in Poston:

	Other jurisdictions hold that a Covenant Not To Execute is not a satisfaction or a release and that its legal effect is similar to that of a Covenant Not To Sue because it does not operate to release other joint tortfeasors. Â A Covenant Not To Execute is a promise not to enforce a right of action or execute a judgment when one had such a right at the time of entering into the agreement. Â A Covenant Not to Sue and a Covenant Not to Execute are so closely akin that a major distinguishing factor is that the latter is normally executed when a settlement occurs after the filing of a lawsuit, while the former is entered into before a lawsuit is filed. Â In South Carolina when a Covenant Not To Sue has been entered into, usually the covenanting tortfeasor is no longer a party to the litigation.
	We are cognizant that litigants are free to devise a settlement agreement in any manner that does not contravene public policy or the law. Â In fact, this Court encourages such compromise agreements because they avoid costly litigation and delay to an injured party. Â However, these settlement agreements must be carefully scrutinized in order to determine their efficiency and impact upon the integrity of the judicial process.

Poston, 294 S.C. at 263-64, 363 S.E.2d at 889-90 (citations omitted).
Bartholomew v. McCartha addressed the efficacy of a settlement agreementâ€™s release as to the liability of a third-party and manifestly replaced â€œthe ancient common-law rule, that regardless of the intention of the parties, the release of one joint tort-feasor releases all.â€Â  255 S.C. 489, 491, 179 S.E.2d 912, 913 (1971) (quoting Mickle v. Blackmond, 252 S.C. 202, 224, 166 S.E.2d 173, 182 (1969)).Â  In Bartholomew the plaintiff was involved in a car crash with two other vehicles.Â  After the victim settled out of court with one of the two tortfeasor defendants, the remaining defendant claimed the other partiesâ€™ agreement released him from liability as well.Â  Declining to adopt the traditional common-law rule that the release of one joint tortfeasor discharged all others, the court held:

	Being untrammeled by the ancient rule which, in our view, tends to stifle settlements, defeat the intention of parties and extol technicality, we adopt the view that the release of one tort-feasor does not release others who wrongfully contributed to plaintiffâ€™s injuries unless this was the intention of the parties, or unless plaintiff has, in fact, received full compensation amounting to a satisfaction. Â It, therefore, becomes unnecessary for us to determine whether the instrument involved here is a release rather than a covenant.

Bartholomew at 492, 179 S.E.2d at 914.
Finding no merit to the appellantsâ€™ contention that the circuit court erred in finding the plaintiffâ€™s release of another defendant did not, as a matter of law, operate to exonerate the appellants from liability, in Scott by McClure v. Fruehauf Corp., 302 S.C. 364, 396 S.E.2d 354 (1990), the South Carolina Supreme Court enunciated:

	The release of one tortfeasor does not constitute a release of others who contributed to the plaintiffâ€™s injuries unless the parties intended such a release or the plaintiff received full satisfaction. Â Bartholomew v. McCartha, 255 S.C. 489, 179 S.E.2d 912 (1971). Â The release here evidences no intent to release others from liability and in fact contemplates further litigation against other tortfeasors to fully compensate [the plaintiff].
	

Id. at 368, 396 S.E.2d at 356.
In Loydâ€™s Inc. by Richardson Const. Co. of Columbia, S.C., Inc. v. Good, 306 S.C. 450, 412 S.E.2d 441, (Ct. App. 1991), a release was executed between a subcontractor and pond owner who had suffered siltation damage.Â  The agreement provided full satisfaction of the pond ownerâ€™s claims, and therefore had the efficacy of releasing the general contractor and upstream property owner from liability as well.Â  This court instructed:

	[B]efore the effective date of the [act creating a right of contribution of joint tortfeasors], the law was clear that the release of one tortfeasor served to release others who wrongfully contributed to the plaintiffâ€™s injuries only if the injured party and released party intended that result, or the injured party in fact received full compensation for his injuries amounting to a satisfaction. Â Following this reasoning, a covenant not to sue or a release which is not effective as a full release of all tortfeasors is a satisfaction â€œpro tantoâ€ and reduces the amount of damages recoverable against the nonsettling tortfeasors by the amount of the consideration for the release.

Id. at Â 454, 412 S.E.2d at 444 (internal citations omitted).
After executing a release with other persons involved in their automobile accident, in Bowers v. South Carolina Dept. of Trans., 360 S.C. 149, 600 S.E.2d 543 (Ct. App. 2004), an injured motorist and her parents filed suit against the South Carolina Department of Transportation alleging its negligence in roadway maintenance contributed to the collision.Â  Looking to the language of the release document, the Court of Appeals upheld the circuit courtâ€™s award of summary judgment.Â  The court based its determination on both prongs of Bartholomew, and concluded Â that, under the terms of the release, the parties received full compensation and intended that all claims for injuries would be relinquished: 
 

	The terms of the Release do not evince an intent to limit its scope to any specifically identified parties. Â Rather, the Release is general and all encompassing in its scope. Â It clearly states that the Appellants released the tort-feasor â€œand all other persons, firms or corporations liable, or who might be claimed to be liable.â€ Â This language is a clear, explicit, and unequivocal indication of the partiesâ€™ intent that
	all claims arising from the accident-now and in the future-are barred under the terms of the Release. Â Had Appellants intended a contrary result and desired to limit the operation of the Release to named persons only, the terms of the Release could have been easily tailored to that end. Â We are constrained by the plain, unambiguous language of the Release to find that Appellantsâ€™ claims against SCDOT fall within the terms of the Release.
	This result is also compelled under the second prong of 
	Bartholomew. The Release clearly and unequivocally contemplates that the respective settlement payments to Appellants constituted a â€œfull compensation amounting to a satisfaction.â€
	Appellants, however, argue that â€œdamages to be awarded for injury and resulting pain and suffering cannot be determined with mathematical precisionâ€ and this determination is, therefore, always â€œan issue of fact.â€ Â They essentially argue that full compensation is always a function of the juryâ€™s discretion, rendering summary judgment unavailable. While we agree that damages, especially non-pecuniary damages, in a personal injury claim are difficult to ascertain in light of the broad discretion accorded the trier of fact, Appellants misconstrue the precise issue before us. Â The issue is not determining the exact amount (assuming liability) a jury would award. Instead, the issue is â€œfull compensation amounting to a satisfaction.â€ Â Id. at 491, 179 S.E.2d at 913 (emphasis added).
	A â€œsatisfactionâ€ is generally defined as â€œ[t]he discharge of an obligation by paying a party what is due to himâ€ or â€œ[t]he performance of a substituted obligation in return for the discharge of the original obligation.â€ 
	Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1342 (6th ed. 1990). Â In cases involving a disputed or liquidated claim arising in contract or tort, the parties will reach an â€œaccordâ€ whereby one of the parties agrees to accept as â€œsatisfactionâ€ of the disputed claim some performance or undertaking different from that which he considers himself entitled. Â See
	South Carolina Farm Bureau Mut. Ins. Co. v. Kelly, 345 S.C. 232, 239, 547 S.E.2d 871, 875 (Ct. App. 2001) (noting that â€œ[a]n accord and satisfaction occurs when there is (1) an agreement to accept in discharge of an obligation something different from that which the creditor is claiming or is entitled to receive; and (2) payment of the consideration expressed in the new agreement.â€) (quoting 
	Tremont Constr. Co. v. Dunlap, 310 S.C. 180, 182, 425 S.E.2d 792, 793 (Ct. App. 1992); 
	Mercury Marine Div. v. Costas, 288 S.C. 383, 386, 342 S.E.2d 632, 633 (Ct. App. 1986)). Indeed, parties regularly reach compromise settlements for a variety of reasons, including the vagaries and unpredictability of litigation and the desire for finality. Where, as here, a party accepts â€œa full and final compromise adjustment and settlement of any and all claims,â€ such amounts to a Bartholomew satisfaction, thereby extending the preclusive effect of the release to nonparties to the instrument.

Bowers v. Dept. of Transp., 360 S.C. 149, 154-55, 600 S.E.2d 543, 545-46 (Ct. App. 2004) (emphasis in original).
2. Contract Interpretation
A release is a contract and contract principles of law should be used to determine what the parties intended.Â  See Bowers v. Dept. of Transp., 360 S.C. 149, 153, 600 S.E.2d 543, 545 (Ct. App. 2004) (stating â€œThe Release is a contractâ€ and applying South Carolinaâ€™s rules of contract construction); see also Lowery v. Callahan, 210 S.C. 300, 300, 42 S.E.2d 457, 458 (1947) (noting that the â€œsame principles of adequacy of consideration which apply to other contracts, govern as to releasesâ€); Hyman v. Ford Motor Co., 142 F. Supp. 2d 735 (D.S.C. 2001) (applying South Carolina contract law principles to determine validity of a release); 18 S.C. Jur. Release Â§ 2 (2003) (â€œBecause a release is a contract, principles of law applicable to contracts generally are also applicable to releases.â€); 76 C.J.S. Release Â§ 2 (1994) (stating that a release is contractual in nature). 
 
â€œIn construing a contract, the primary objective is to ascertain and give effect to the intention of the parties.â€Â  Southern Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 349 S.C. 77, 80-81, 562 S.E.2d 482, 484-85 (Ct. App. 2002); accordÂ  D.A. Davis Constr. Co., Inc. v. Palmetto Props., Inc., 281 S.C. 415, 418, 315 S.E.2d 370, 372 (1984); Williams v. Teran, Inc., 266 S.C. 55, 59, 221 S.E.2d 526, 528 (1976); RentCo., a Div. of Fruehauf Corp. v. Tamway Corp., 283 S.C. 265, 267, 321 S.E.2d 199, 201 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œContracts should be liberally construed so as to give them effect and carry out the intention of the parties.â€Â  Mishoe v. Gen. Motors Acceptance Corp., 234 S.C. 182, 188, 107 S.E.2d 45, 47 (1958).
The partiesâ€™ intention must, in the first instance, be derived from the language of the contract.Â  Schulmeyer v. State Farm Fire & Cas. Co., 353 S.C. 491, 495, 579 S.E.2d 132, 134 (2003); C.A.N. Enters., Inc. v. S.C. Health & Human Services Fin. Commâ€™n., 296 S.C. 373, 377, 373 S.E.2d 584, 586 (1988) (â€œIn construing terms in contracts, this Court must first look at the language of the contract to determine the intentions of the parties.â€); Jacobs v. Service Merch. Co., 297 S.C. 123, 375 S.E.2d 1 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  To discover the intention of a contract, the court must first look to its languageâ€”if the language is perfectly plain and capable of legal construction, it alone determines the documentâ€™s force and effect.Â  Superior Auto. Ins. Co. v. Maners, 261 S.C. 257, 263, 199 S.E.2d 719, 722 (1973).Â  â€œParties are governed by their outward expressions and the court is not at liberty to consider their secret intentions.â€Â  Blakeley v. Rabon, 266 S.C. 68, 73, 221 S.E.2d 767, 769 (1976); Ellie, Inc. v. Miccichi, 358 S.C. 78, 93-94, 594 S.E.2d 485, 493-94 (Ct. App. 2004); accord Kable v. Simmons, 217 S.C. 161, 166, 60 S.E.2d 79, 81 (1950.
The partiesâ€™ intention must be gathered from the contents of the entire agreement and not from any particular clause thereof.Â  Thomas-McCain, Inc. v. Siter, 268 S.C. 193, 197, 232 S.E.2d 728, 729 (1977); see also Barnacle Broad., Inc. v. Baker Broad., Inc., 343 S.C. 140, 147, 538 S.E.2d 672, 675 (Ct. App. 2000) (â€œThe primary test as to the character of a contract is the intention of the parties, such intention to be gathered from the whole scope and effect of the language used.â€).Â  â€œDocuments will be interpreted so as to give effect to all of their provisions, if practical.â€Â  Reyhani v. Stone Creek Cove Condominium II Horizontal Property Regime, 329 S.C. 206, 212, 494 S.E.2d 465, 468 (Ct. App. 1997) (citing 17A Am. Jur. 2d Contracts Â§ 385 (1991)).Â  In ascertaining intent, the court will strive to discover the situation of the parties, along with their purposes at the time the contract was entered.Â  Klutts Resort Realty, Inc., 268 S.C. 80, 89, 232 S.E.2d 20, 25 (1977); Bruce v. Blalock, 241 S.C. 155, 161, 127 S.E.2d 439, 442 (1962); Mattox v. Cassady, 289 S.C. 57, 61, 344 S.E.2d 620, 622 (Ct. App. 1986). 
 
In Brady v. Brady, 222 S.C. 242, 72 S.E.2d 193 (1952) the South Carolina Supreme Court asseverated:

	It is fundamental that in the construction of the language of a [contract], it is proper to read together the different provisions therein dealing with the same subject matter, and where possible, all the language used should be given a reasonable meaning.
	Agreements should be liberally construed so as to give them effect and carry out the intention of the parties.Â  In arriving at the intention of the parties to a lease, the subject matter, the surrounding circumstances, the situation of the parties, and the object in view and intended to be accomplished by the parties at the time, are to be regarded, and the lease construed as a whole.Â  Different provisions dealing with the same subject matter are to be read together.

Id. at 246-47, 72 S.E.2d at 195.  
If a contractâ€™s language is plain, unambiguous, and capable of only one reasonable interpretation, no construction is required and its language determines the instrumentâ€™s force and effect.Â  Jordan v. Security Group, Inc., 311 S.C. 227, 230, 428 S.E.2d 705, 707 (1993); Blakeley at 72, 221 S.E.2d at 769.Â  â€œWhere an agreement is clear and capable of legal interpretation, the courts only function is to interpret its lawful meaning, discover the intention of the parties as found within the agreement, and give effect to it.â€Â  Ellie at 93, 594 S.E.2d at 493 (quoting Heins v. Heins, 344 S.C. 146, 158, 543 S.E.2d 224, 230 (Ct. App. 2001)).Â  However, where an agreement is ambiguous, the court should seek to determine the partiesâ€™ intent.Â  Smith-Cooper v. Cooper, 344 S.C. 289, 295, 543 S.E.2d 271, 274 (Ct. App. 2001); Prestwick Golf Club, Inc. v. Prestwick Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 331 S.C. 385, 390, 503 S.E.2d 184, 187 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  
 
â€œA contract is ambiguous when it is capable of more than one meaning or when its meaning is unclear.â€Â  Ellie at 94, 594 S.E.2d at 493; accord Bruce at 160, 127 S.E.2d at 441; Hawkins v. Greenwood Dev. Corp., 328 S.C. 585, 493 S.E.2d 875 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  â€œ[A]n ambiguous contract is one capable of being understood in more senses than one, an agreement obscure in meaning, through indefiniteness of expression, or having a double meaning.â€Â  Carolina Ceramics, Inc. v. Carolina Pipeline Co., 251 S.C. 151, 155-56, 161 S.E.2d 179, 181 (1968) (citation omitted)
â€œAmbiguous language in a contract should be construed liberally and most strongly in favor of the party who did not write or prepare the contract and is not responsible for the ambiguity; and any ambiguity in a contract, doubt, or uncertainty as to its meaning should be resolved against the party who prepared the contract or is responsible for the verbiage.â€Â  Myrtle Beach Lumber Co., Inc. v. Willoughby, 276 S.C. 3, 8, 274 S.E.2d 423, 426 (1981) (quoting 17A C.J.S. Contracts Â§ 324)
The court must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms, regardless of the contractâ€™s wisdom or folly, or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefully.Â  Ellis v. Taylor, 316 S.C. 245, 248, 449 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1994); Jordan v. Security Group, Inc., 311 S.C. 227, 230, 428 S.E.2d 705, 707 (1993). 
 
Whether a contractâ€™s language is ambiguous is a question of law.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Resources v. Town of McClellanville, 345 S.C. 617, 550 S.E.2d 299 (2001); Southern Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 349 S.C. 77, 80-81, 562 S.E.2d 482, 484-85 (Ct. App. 2002), affâ€™d as modified, 356 S.C. 444, 590 S.E.2d 27 (2003).Â  Once the court decides the language is ambiguous, evidence may be admitted to show the intent of the parties.Â  Id.; see also Charles v. B & B Theatres, Inc., 234 S.C. 15, 18, 106 S.E.2d 455, 456 (1959) (â€œ[W]hen the written contract is ambiguous in its terms, ... parol and other extrinsic evidence will be admitted to determine the intent of the parties.â€) (citation omitted).Â  The determination of the partiesâ€™ intent is then a question of fact for the jury to determine.Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Resources, 345 S.C. at 623, 550 S.E.2d at 303.
B. The Case Sub Judice
In granting Outparcelâ€™s motion for a directed verdict, the trial judge stated:

	Iâ€™m going to grant the motion for a directed verdict based on this mutual settlement and release that I marked as a Courtâ€™s Exhibit.Â  And just reading that there is no question that this lease and any causes of action that arise out of it, have been transferred to Mr. Ashy and his company, JDL Holdings.Â  That while I donâ€™t condone the actions of Mr. Gleatonâ€™s client, they are in privity, in privity with Mr. Ashy and his company with respect to this agreement.Â  And that all causes of action then existing or now existing at the time of the release arising hereafter, related to the events set forth in the lawsuit which could have been asserted in the lawsuit or related to the business relationship among the parties were fully settled.Â  So Iâ€™m granting the directed verdict.

Although the judge was somewhat enigmatical, it appears he based the directed verdict award on Outparcelâ€™s contention that the Settlement Agreement between EPM to JDL had the effect of releasing Outparcel from EPMâ€™s claim for breach of their contractual right of first refusal.Â  This argument centered upon the following provision in the Settlement Agreement:

	3. Release by Danny Yopp d/b/a Ecclesiastes Ministries.Â  Danny Yopp d/b/a Ecclesiastes Ministries and its members, officers, directors, employees, heirs, successors and assigns, hereby release and forever discharge JDL Holdings, LLC, and any shareholders, officers, directors, employees, agents, servants, successors, and assigns, and any parent, subsidiary or affiliate thereof, and any other persons, firms, or corporations who are or may be liable, now or in the future, from any and all claims, demands, actions, or causes in action, whether in law or in equity, whether
	ex contractu or ex delicto, for damages of any kind, including compensation, loss of profits or income, expenses, consequential damages, punitive damages, costs, attorneyâ€™s fees, expert witness fees, or any other damages, whether known or unknown, presently existing or which may arise in the future, arising out of, in connection with, or in any way related to the events set forth in the Lawsuit, or any other event, failures or breaches which are asserted or which could have been asserted in the Lawsuit.

Following South Carolinaâ€™s rules of contract construction, the quoted language of the Settlement Agreement cannot possibly bear the meaning placed upon it by Outparcel and the circuit court.Â  Executed only days before the trial between EPM and JDL was scheduled to begin, the first sentence of the Settlement/Release states: Â â€œThis Mutual Release is . . . by and between JDL Holdings, LLC, Plaintiff and Danny Yopp d/b/a Ecclesiastes Productions Ministries.â€Â  Palpably, the Settlement Agreement was exclusively between EPM and JDL.Â  Outparcel is not, and was not invited to be, a party to the Settlement Agreement. Â Despite Outparcelâ€™s urging to the contrary, the release of â€œany other persons, firms, or corporations who are or may be liable, now or in the future, from any and all claims, demands, actions, or causes in actionâ€ can only reasonably be interpreted to include those persons and entities involved in the claims directly between EPM and JDL.
EPM and JDL mutually settled and released the other from what the Settlement Agreement captioned as, â€œthe Lawsuit.â€Â  While the meaning of the term â€œthe Lawsuitâ€ may refer to the entirety of the litigation, pellucidly EPM and JDL did not intend to include any claims against Outparcel in what was being settled, as the agreement discusses the continued pursuit of claims against Outparcel by both EPM and JDL.Â  Unlike the general release in Bowers, the Settlement Agreement here clearly evinces an intent to limit its scope to the claims asserted by EPM and JDL against one another.

	The Settlement Agreement is predicated upon the continuation of EPMâ€™s claims against Outparcel for fraud and contractual breach of the right of first refusal.Â  The fifth paragraph of the Settlement Agreement reads:
	5.Â  Payment by Danny Yopp d/b/a Ecclesiastes Ministries: In consideration of the aforementioned covenants and promises Danny Yopp d/b/a
	Ecclesiastes Ministries, agrees to pay JDL Holdings, LLC the following:
	A.Â  One Hundred Thousand ($100,000.00) Dollars as settlement of JDLâ€™s claims for past due rents, attorneyâ€™s fees, etc.
	i.Â  Payment of the aforementioned $100,000.00 shall be due and payable if, and only if, Danny Yopp and/or Ecclesiastes Ministries are successful in obtaining a judgment against Outparcel Associates, LLC on the Cross Claims filed in said Lawsuit for an amount in excess of $200,000.00 and is successful in collecting on the judgment as provided herein. Â Danny Yopp agrees to vigorously pursue recovery of all of its damages as demanded in its complaint against Outparcel. Â In the event Danny Yopp and/or Ecclesiastes Ministries are successful in obtaining a judgment against Outparcel Associates, LLC on the Cross Claims filed in said Lawsuit for an amount less than $200,000.00, no amount will be due JDL Holdings, LLC or Peter Ashy. If Danny Yopp is awarded a judgment in excess of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000), the first one hundred thousand ($100,000) dollars received toward satisfaction of the judgment Danny Yopp may obtain against Outparcel will be free and clear of any claim by JDL Holdings, LLC or Peter Ashy. Any amounts received to satisfy the judgment in excess of $100,000 dollars will be divided 20% in favor of JDL Holdings and 80% in favor of Danny Yopp up to a maximum of $100,000 dollars (less attorney fees as provided herein) being paid to JDL Holdings to satisfy the terms of this settlement agreement. The actual amounts due and payable will be directly contingent upon the judgment obtained by Danny Yopp, if any, and those monies received to satisfy said judgment, if any. The parties further agree their respective attorneys will execute an additional addendum to this agreement following the outcome of the February 9th trial, in which the attorneyâ€™s [sic] will set forth in detail the actual judgment amounts and the ratioâ€™s [sic] and/or percentage each parties [sic] will be entitled to any collected monies. In the event Danny Yopp engages the services of an attorney to pursue collection of any judgment amount awarded, any reasonable contingency fees and costs charged by the attorney will be applied to any amounts received before applying the distribution percentages shown above. Payment will be due within fifteen (15) days of Danny Yopp and/or Ecclesiastes Production Ministries receiving cash or other funds as satisfaction of the judgment it anticipates obtaining on claims filed in this Lawsuit.
	
	. . . .
	iv. The parties also recognize that JDL Holdings, LLC is in the process of filing a claim against Outparcel Associates, LLC and Solomon Bekele for breach of contract, conversion and other related claims. The parties agree that any judgment obtained by JDL Holdings, LLC against Outparcel in the subsequent suit will be subordinate to the first one hundred thousand dollars of the escrowed funds generated by the sale of the disputed property and being held by North Georgia Title, Inc., the Qualified Intermediary, or any real estate purchased with those funds, which may be available to satisfy both judgments. Â This provision in no manner limits, restricts or otherwise subordinates JDL Holdings, LLC ability to collect any judgment it may obtain against Solomon Bekele individually.

(Emphasis added).Â   
JDLâ€™s recovery from EPM is entirely dependent on EPM successfully recovering in its suit with Outparcel.Â  Key provisions of the agreement contemplate successful litigation against Outparcel, not its release.Â  EPMâ€™s settlement payment to JDL is conditioned upon EPMâ€™s continued pursuit of its claims against Outparcel: â€œPayment . . . shall be due and payable if, and only if Danny Yopp and/or [EPM] are successful in obtaining a judgment against Outparcel . . . .â€Â  EPM agrees to â€œvigorously pursue recovery of all of its damages as demanded in its complaint against Outparcel.â€Â  Furthermore, the agreement discusses a lawsuit JDL has filed against Outparcel.Â  In order for this section to be efficaciousness and have any purpose whatsoever, indubitably the Settlement Agreement must be interpreted as effecting solely the suit between EPM and JDL. Â An interpretation otherwise would render this section absurd and nugatory.
CONCLUSION 
Based on the foregoing, the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict is
REVERSED.
HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: State v. Thompson
description: The Court of Appeals affirmed the lower court's denial of a directed verdict motion when there was evidence that Furman Thompson was guilty of burglary in the first degree and attempted armed robbery under the "hand of one is the hand of all" theory of accomplice liability.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Furman Thompson, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â C. Victor Pyle, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4255
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 18, 2007Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Shawn L. Reeves, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

WILLIAMS, J.: Furman Thompson appeals his convictions for first degree burglary and attempted armed robbery, claiming the judge erred in failing to direct a verdict of not guilty.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On the morning of February 16, 2004, Thompson met with Wanda Harris and discussed whether she knew of a â€œlick.â€ Â Harris testified a â€œlickâ€ is a target for a robbery. Â Later that day, Harris called Thompson and told him about a potential lick and asked him to meet her.Â  Thompson showed up approximately one hour later with Darrel Sturkey, the codefendant in the underlying case. Â Sturkey and Harris planned the details of the burglary while Thompson spoke with Tyrone Scott, who accompanied Harris to the scene.
 
According to the plan, Harris walked alone to the apartment to investigate the potential lick under the guise of purchasing crack cocaine.Â  Harris testified that as she approached the apartment, Scott lagged behind her. Â Just before Harris entered the apartment, she turned around and did not see Thompson or Sturkey.
 
Harris then entered the apartment and began a conversation with Torrey Hudson, who lived there, while Hudsonâ€™s friend, Andre Chiles, sat on the couch watching television. Â Chiles had a gun on the couch next to him. Â While Harris attempted to buy some crack cocaine, Scott knocked on the door and was let into the apartment. Â Harris and Scott are frequently together so this did not alarm Hudson or Chiles. Â Scott informed Hudson he knew of other potential customers in case Hudson wanted to sell more crack cocaine, but Hudson informed Scott he did not have any more crack. Â Shortly thereafter, Harris and Scott attempted to leave the apartment. 
 
As Harris walked out of the door, she saw Sturkey standing against the outer wall of the apartment pulling a ski mask over his head. Â Sturkey pushed Harris out of the way, stepped into the apartment and fired a gun into the apartment. Â Chiles immediately grabbed his gun and returned fire towards the intruder. Â After several shots were exchanged between Sturkey and Chiles, Chilesâ€™ gun jammed and he retreated into the bathroom to clear the gun. Â When Chiles came out of the bathroom, the apartment was empty.
 
As a result of the altercation, Chiles sustained two gunshots to the abdomen.Â  Sturkey sustained one gunshot to his right leg.Â  Nothing was stolen from the apartment or from either of the occupants.Â  Thompson and Sturkey were charged with first degree burglary and attempted armed robbery, and Sturkey was also charged with assault and battery with attempt to kill.Â  Thompson and Sturkey were tried together, and the jury convicted each on their respective charges.
DISCUSSION
Thompson argues the trial judge erred by not directing a verdict of not guilty because the state failed to present any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence to show that Thompson was guilty of first degree burglary or attempted armed robbery, either as a principal or as an accomplice.Â  We disagree.
When analyzing the denial of a directed verdict motion, this Court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.Â  State v. McHoney, 344 S.C. 85, 97, 544 S.E.2d 30, 36 (2001).Â  â€œThe trial court, in a directed verdict motion, is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not with its weight.â€Â  State v. Elmore, 368 S.C. 230, 234, 628 S.E.2d 271, 273 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The trial court must be affirmed if the record contains any direct or substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused or from which guilt may be fairly and logically deduced.Â  State v. Avery, 333 S.C. 284, 294, 509 S.E.2d 476, 482 (1998); State v. Williams, 303 S.C. 274, 276, 400 S.E.2d 131, 132 (1991).
â€œUnder the â€˜hand of one is the hand of allâ€™ theory [of accomplice liability], one who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design and purpose.â€Â  State v. Condrey, 349 S.C. 184, 194, 562 S.E.2d 320, 324 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œA defendant may be convicted on a theory of accomplice liability pursuant to an indictment charging him only with the principal offense.â€Â  Id. at 194, 562 S.E.2d at 325. 
 
Mere presence and prior knowledge that a crime was going to be committed, without more, is insufficient to constitute guilt.Â  Id. at 195, 562 S.E.2d at 325.Â  However, â€œpresence at the scene of a crime by pre-arrangement to aid, encourage, or abet in the perpetration of the crime constitutes guilt as a [principal].â€Â  State v. Hill, 268 S.C. 390, 395-96, 234 S.E.2d 219, 221 (1977).Â  
 
A person is guilty of first degree burglary when he enters a dwelling without consent and with intent to commit a crime in the dwelling and either:

	(1) when, in effecting entry or while in the dwelling or in immediate flight, he or another participant in the crime: (a) is armed with a deadly weapon or explosive; or (b) causes physical injury to a person who is not a participant in the crime; or (c) uses or threatens the use of a dangerous instrument; or (d) displays what is or appears to be a knife, pistol, revolver, rifle, shotgun, machine gun, or other firearm; or . . . (3) the entering or remaining occurs in the nighttime.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-311 (Supp. 2006).Â  A person is guilty of attempted armed robbery if the person has a specific intent to commit armed robbery.Â  State v. Nesbit, 346 S.C. 226, 231, 550 S.E.2d 864, 866-67 (Ct. App. 2001).Â Â  â€œRobbery is defined as the felonious or unlawful taking of money, goods, or other personal property of any value from the person of another or in his presence by violence or by putting such person in fear.â€Â  State v. Bland, 315 S.C. 315, 317, 457 S.E.2d 611, 612 (1995).Â Â Â  The crime is â€œarmed robberyâ€ when a person commits a robbery while armed with a deadly weapon.Â  State v. Tasco, 292 S.C. 270, 272, 356 S.E.2d 117, 118 (1987).Â  
 
Testimony in this case establishes that the codefendant, Sturkey, entered the apartment without permission, during the nighttime, with a gun, and intended to commit the crime of armed robbery.Â  Therefore, the crime of burglary in the first degree with respect to Sturkey was established sufficiently to withstand a directed verdict motion.Â  Testimony also showed that it was the intent of Sturkey, at the very least, to use a deadly weapon to rob Hudson of money, goods, or personal property.Â  Therefore, the crime of attempted armed robbery with respect to Sturkey was sufficiently established to withstand a directed verdict motion.Â  The question that remains before us is whether Sturkeyâ€™s crimes can be imputed to Thompson either as a principal or under a theory of accomplice liability.
Sturkeyâ€™s statement, which was read into evidence during Officer Bobby Cariasâ€™ testimony, establishes that Sturkey and three others were together when they came up with the plan to rob Hudson. Â Later when everyone ran from the scene, â€œthe guy asked if [Sturkey] was okay.Â  [Sturkey] told him [he] was okay. . . .Â  We got in the car and went home.â€ Â Sturkeyâ€™s statement constitutes direct evidence that Sturkey arrived at the scene and left the scene with one of the three other participants.Â 
 
Harrisâ€™ testimony constitutes direct evidence that Thompson asked her if she knew of a lick, then later spoke to her on the phone about a possible lick.Â  Further, it establishes Thompson then showed up with Sturkey at the apartment complex where Harris informed him there was a possible lick, and Thompson was present in the vicinity while Harris and Sturkey planned the robbery. Â 
In Hill, the appellant previously discussed the robbery with the perpetrators, appeared at the crime scene, and may have viewed the commission of the robbery, but he was possibly unaware of the final planning and did not accompany the perpetrators as they committed the robbery.Â  Hill at 396, 234 S.E.2d at 221.Â  The Court in Hill found the evidence justified submission of the case to the jury.Â  Id.Â  Likewise, here Thompson discussed the robbery, appeared at the crime scene with Sturkey, and may have viewed the attempted robbery.Â  At the very least, Thompson aided the commission of the crime by driving Sturkey to the scene and encouraged the crime by setting the events in motion earlier that day.
Thus, under the hand of one is the hand of all theory of accomplice liability, acts committed by Sturkey are imputed to Thompson making him guilty of any acts done incidental to the execution of the common design or scheme of the crime.Â  State v. Curry, 370 S.C. 674, 684, 636 S.E.2d 649, 654 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  Therefore, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to the State, the trial judge properly denied Thompsonâ€™s motion for a directed verdict on each charge and submitted the case to the jury. 
 
Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s decision is  
AFFIRMED.[1]Â  
STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Shuler v. Tri-County Electric Co-op, Inc.
description: Concludes that the claimant, a member of the Board of Trustees of Tri-County Electric Co-op, was not an employee for purposes of determining his eligibility for workers' compensation benefits.
text:
Shuler v. Tri-County Electric Co-op


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Frederick D. Shuler, Appellant,
				v.
				Tri-County Electric Co-op, Inc., Employer, and Federated Rural Electric Insurance Corp., Carrier, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4256
Heard April 10, 2007 â€“ Filed June 18, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			Kevin Hayne Sitnik and John Gressette Felder, Jr., both of Columbia, for Appellant.Â 
			
			W. Hugh McAngus, Weston Adams, III, and Mary Margaret Hyatt, all of Columbia, for Respondents.
			Samuel F. Painter, of Columbia, for Amicus Curiae. 
			
		
	

STILWELL, J.:Â  Frederick D. Shuler filed this action alleging entitlement to workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Shuler appeals the circuit courtâ€™s ruling he was not an employee of Tri-County Electric Co-op, Inc. (the Co-op) and therefore not entitled to coverage.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
The Co-op is a rural electric cooperative.[1]Â  Shuler served on the Co-opâ€™s Board of Trustees.Â  Shuler requested authorization from the Co-op to attend the annual convention of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association in Dallas.Â  Although Shulerâ€™s attendance was not mandatory, and he was not a voting delegate at the meeting, the Co-op approved his request.Â  Shuler was injured in an automobile accident while driving to Dallas and filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  The Co-op denied the claim, contending Shuler was not an employee.Â  
 
As a board member, Shuler received compensation from the Co-op, including reimbursed expenses and a per diem allowance for attendance at meetings.Â  This compensation was designated on Shulerâ€™s IRS 1099 form issued by the Co-op as â€œNonemployee compensation.â€Â  Shuler also received benefits from enrollment in the Co-opâ€™s retirement and health insurance plans. Â 
The single commissioner found Shuler was not the Co-opâ€™s employee and was therefore ineligible for workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  The full commission reversed the commissioner.Â  The circuit court reversed the full commission, reinstating the single commissionerâ€™s decision.Â  
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The existence of an employer-employee relationship is a factual question that determines the jurisdiction of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Nelson v. Yellow Cab Co., 349 S.C. 589, 594, 564 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2002).Â  When an issue involves jurisdiction, the appellate court can take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â Â  Dawkins v. Jordan, 341 S.C. 434, 439, 534 S.E.2d 700, 703 (2000).Â  â€œIn determining jurisdictional questions, doubts of jurisdiction will be resolved in favor of inclusion of employees within workersâ€™ compensation coverage rather than exclusion.â€Â  Wilson v. Georgetown County, 316 S.C. 92, 94, 447 S.E.2d 841, 842 (1994).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Shuler argues he is an employee of the Co-op and therefore entitled to workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
To decide the issue of employment in this case, we are required to review:Â  1) the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, 2) the Electric Cooperative Act, and 3) the Co-opâ€™s by-laws. Â We shall do so seriatim.
In interpreting the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act, we are required to construe the statutes liberally in favor of coverage.Â  Peay v. U.S. Silica Co., 313 S.C. 91, 94, 437 S.E.2d 64, 65 (1993).Â  The primary section of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act involved in this case is section 42-1-130.Â  Section 42-1-130 defines an employee as a â€œperson engaged in an employment under any appointment [or] contract of hire, . . . expressed or implied, oral or written . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-130 (Supp. 2006). 
 
In construing the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act to define an employee, our court has held that coverage depends on the existence of an employment relationship.Â  Edens v. Bellini, 359 S.C. 433, 439, 597 S.E.2d 863, 866 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The â€˜contract of employmentâ€™ is the jurisdictional factor used to determine if an employment relationship exists.Â  Alewine v. Tobin Quarries, Inc., 206 S.C. 103, 109, 33 S.E.2d 81, 83 (1945).Â  Although no formality is required, the contract is established if the parties recognize each other as employer and employee.Â  Id.Â  Furthermore, an employeeâ€™s right to demand payment for his services from the employer is essential to the establishment of an employment relationship.Â  Kirksey v. Assurance Tire Co., 311 S.C. 255, 257, 428 S.E.2d 721, 723 (Ct. App. 1993), affâ€™d, 314 S.C. 43, 443 S.E.2d 803 (1994).Â  For example, in Doe v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 323 S.C. 33, 39-40, 448 S.E.2d 564, 567-68 (Ct. App. 1994), this court held an unpaid volunteer candy striper was not the employee of a hospital.Â  Likewise, in McCreery v. Covenant Presbyterian, this court found an unpaid church volunteer not an employee of the church for workersâ€™ compensation purposes.Â  299 S.C. 218, 383 S.E.2d 264 (1989), revâ€™d on other grounds, 303 S.C. 271, 400 S.E.2d 130 (1990).Â  See also Kirksey, 311 S.C. at 257, 428 S.E.2d at 723 (finding unpaid daughter of store owner not an employee).Â  See generally 3 Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation Law Â§ 65.01 (2006). 
 
To correctly determine the relationship of the parties in this case, we must next turn our attention to the language of the Electric Cooperative Act and the by-laws adopted by the individual co-op pursuant to the provisions of that act.Â  The Electric Cooperative Act governs rural electric cooperatives in South Carolina.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§33-49-10 to -1450 (2006 & Supp. 2006).Â  Section 33-49-630 of the Electric Cooperative Act, entitled â€œCompensation or employment of trustee,â€ provides:

	The bylaws may make provision for the compensation of trustees; 
	provided, however, that compensation shall not be paid except for actual attendance upon activities authorized by the board. Â The bylaws may also provide for the travel, expenses and other benefits of trustees, as set by the board. Â A trustee, except in emergencies, shall not be employed by the cooperative in any other capacity involving compensation.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 33-49-630 (2006) (emphasis in original).Â  
 
While we are required to construe the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act liberally in favor of coverage, the same is not true in the interpretation and construction of either the Electric Cooperative Act or the by-laws adopted pursuant thereto.Â  With regard to these enactments, we apply more general rules of construction. Â The cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp. v. First Carolina Corp., 369 S.C. 150, 153-54, 631 S.E.2d 533, 535 (2006).Â  The court should give words their plain and ordinary meaning, without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation.Â  Sloan v. S.C. Bd. of Physical Therapy Examâ€™rs, 370 S.C. 452, 469, 636 S.E.2d 598, 607 (2006).Â  
 
The plain language of section 33-49-630 allows a rural electric cooperative to provide for the compensation of trustees and limits this compensation â€œfor actual attendance upon activities authorized by the board.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§33-49-630 (2006).Â  However, this section does not mandate the compensation or employment of a trustee, nor does it create in the trustee a right to demand payment.Â  See, e.g., Nallan v. Motion Picture Studio Mechs. Union, 360 N.E.2d 353, 353 (N.Y. 1976) (emphasizing, in the context of whether a board member of a labor union was an employee of the union, that the board memberâ€™s stipend did not constitute a salary or compensation under workersâ€™ compensation laws).Â  We also find instructive the language of the Electric Cooperative Act itself, which prohibits a trustee from being employed by the cooperative in any other capacity involving compensation except in emergency situations.Â  We are able to discern no right to demand a wage arising pursuant to section 33-49-630 sufficient to satisfy the test for the creation of an employment relationship as required in court decisions.Â  Nor do we discern from the Electric Cooperative Act any intent by the legislature to create an employment relationship for purposes of workersâ€™ compensation benefits. 
 
Finally, we look to the by-laws of the individual co-op to determine if they provide a basis for concluding that an employment relationship existed between the Co-op and Shuler.Â  The by-laws are an integral component establishing Shulerâ€™s relationship as a board member of Tri-County Electric Co-op.Â  The by-laws should be construed in the same manner a contract is construed because they form the basis for the relationship between the parties, as does a typical contract.Â  â€œThe primary purpose of all rules of contract construction is to determine the intent of the parties.â€Â  Goldston v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 358 S.C. 157, 170, 594 S.E.2d 511, 518 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  In determining the partiesâ€™ intentions, the court must read the contract as a whole.Â  S. Atl. Fin. Servs., Inc. v. Middleton, 356 S.C. 444, 447, 590 S.E.2d 27, 29 (2003).Â  When the language of a contract is clear, explicit, and unambiguous, the language of the contract alone determines the contractâ€™s force and effect, and the court must construe it according to its plain, ordinary, and popular meaning.Â  Moser v. Gosnell, 334 S.C. 425, 430, 513 S.E.2d 123, 125 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  
 

Article IV, Section 9 
	of the by-laws provides, in pertinent part:

	
		Board members shall not receive any salary for their services as such, except that the board may authorize a fixed sum for each day or portion thereof spent on Cooperative business . . . . Â If authorized by the board, board members may also be reimbursed for expenses actually and necessarily incurred in carrying out such cooperative business or granted a reasonable per diem allowance . . . .
	

Other provisions of the by-laws provide that trustees are elected by the Co-op members and serve for a fixed term of three years.Â  The by-laws provide that trustees must be members, but employees do not have to be members.Â  They also prohibit any employee from being a trustee while being simultaneously employed by the Co-op or having been employed in the preceding five years.Â  â€œNo person shall be eligible to become or remain a board member . . . who . . . is employed by the Cooperative or was employed by the Cooperative at any time during the preceding five (5) years.â€Â  
 
Although the by-laws permit compensation on a per diem basis, provide for trustees to be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred, and allow other benefits, when read as a whole the by-laws do not create an employment relationship.Â  Rather, these benefits and compensation constitute gratuitous payments, allowed in the boardâ€™s discretion, and are not compensation for services rendered.Â 
 
For the foregoing reasons, we hold Shuler is not the Co-opâ€™s employee, and he is not entitled to coverage under the workersâ€™ compensation act.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s decision is
AFFIRMED.[2]
HEARN, C.J., and GOOLSBY, J., concur.

[1]  The parties stipulated many of the facts before the single commissioner. Â 
[2]  Shuler contends the circuit court erred in several other aspects of its analysis.Â  However, based on our conclusion that Shuler is not the Co-opâ€™s employee, we need not address these issues.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR (â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, decision or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€).

title: State v. Spare
description: Appellant appeals the revocation of his probation.  He contends the circuit court judge erred in revoking his probation because the record established that he was making a bona fide effort to pay the court-ordered restitution.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				George Spare, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4257
Submitted May 1, 2007 â€“ Filed June 18, 2007
VACATED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				John Benjamin Aplin, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

BEATTY, J.:Â  George Spare appeals the revocation of his probation.Â  He contends the circuit court judge erred in revoking his probation because the record established that he was making a bona fide effort to pay the court-ordered restitution.Â  We vacate the revocation of Spareâ€™s probation and remand to the circuit court for proceedings consistent with the provisions of this opinion.[1]
FACTS
On May 19, 2003, Spare pleaded guilty to breach of trust in an amount greater than $5,000. Â Circuit Court Judge Jackson Gregory sentenced Spare to ten years imprisonment, which was suspended upon five years probation and the payment of restitution in an amount to be calculated at a later date.Â  After a restitution hearing was held on August 13, 2003, Judge Gregory ordered Spare to pay restitution in the amount of $34,475 to the victim, plus a mandatory 20 percent collection fee, resulting in a total restitution obligation of $41,370.Â  
 
On May 12, 2004, Spareâ€™s probation agent served Spare with a financial probation citation, alleging that Spare was in arrears for his restitution.Â  By order dated June 15, 2004, Judge Gregory continued Spare on probation but ordered him to enroll in the Restitution Center.Â Â Â 
 
On September 12, 2005, Spare was again served with a financial probation citation for being $4,921 in arrears on restitution. Â On that date, the unpaid balance of the restitution was $40,362.75.
Circuit Court Judge Howard King held a probation revocation hearing on September 15, 2005.Â  In addressing the court regarding the violation, Spareâ€™s probation agent stated that Spare had reported on time and had paid what he could toward the restitution.Â  He added that Spare has â€œsome financial situations that donâ€™t particularly allow him to pay the $753 a month that he has been ordered to.â€Â  In terms of Spareâ€™s employment, Spareâ€™s counsel explained that Spare was unable to work for the government, his previous employer, or use his masterâ€™s degree as a result of his criminal record, which included a drug conviction.Â  Spare was employed with Cracker Barrel for forty-four hours per week.Â  His check, however, had been garnished by the Internal Revenue Service for payment of back taxes and was also used to make payments to probation.Â  He further stated that Spare does not own any real property, but instead, resides at a Motel 6 and eats all of his meals at his place of employment.Â  Counsel emphasized that Spare had â€œnot missed a payment other than . . . not having the ability to make the required payment a month.â€Â  Counsel also pointed out that Spare paid less toward his financial obligation when he attended the Restitution Center for 181 days because he was making less money than he was currently earning at Cracker Barrel. 
 
At the conclusion of the hearing, Judge King found that 
Spare had willfully violated the terms of his probation.  As a result, 
Judge King revoked one year of Spareâ€™s sentence and ordered Spare to remain on 
probation and pay restitution when he was released from prison.   
Spare appeals the revocation of his probation.
DISCUSSION
Spare argues the circuit court judge erred in revoking his probation when he was employed full time and paying restitution.Â  He contends his failure to pay was not willful given he was making a bona fide effort to pay his court-ordered obligation.Â  
 
The decision to revoke probation is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Allen, 370 S.C. 88, 94, 634 S.E.2d 653, 655 (2006); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-460 (2007).Â  â€œThis courtâ€™s authority to review such a decision is confined to correcting errors of law unless the lack of a legal or evidentiary basis indicates the circuit judgeâ€™s decision was arbitrary and capricious.â€Â  State v. Hamilton, 333 S.C. 642, 647, 511 S.E.2d 94, 96 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Â 
In deciding whether to revoke probation, â€œ[t]he trial court must determine whether the State has presented sufficient evidence to establish that a probationer has violated the conditions of his probation.â€Â  Allen, 370 S.C. at 94, 634 S.E.2d at 655.Â  â€œProbation is a matter of grace; revocation is the means to enforce the conditions of probation.â€Â  Hamilton, 333 S.C. at 97, 511 S.E.2d at 648; see State v. White, 218 S.C. 130, 136, 61 S.E.2d 754, 756 (1950) (â€œWhile probation is a matter of grace, the probationer is entitled to fair treatment, and is not to be made the victim of whim or caprice.â€).Â  Â â€œHowever, the authority of the revoking court should always be predicated upon an evidentiary showing of fact tending to establish a violation of the conditions.â€Â  Hamilton, 333 S.C. at 97, 511 S.E.2d at 648.
Our appellate courts have continued to maintain that â€œprobation may not be revoked solely for failure to make required payments of fines or restitution without the circuit judge first determining on the record that the probationer has failed to make a bona fide effort to pay.â€ Â Hamilton, 333 S.C. at 649, 511 S.E.2d at 97 (discussing Bearden v. Georgia, 461 U.S. 660 (1983))[2]; Nichols v. State, 308 S.C. 334, 337, 417 S.E.2d 860, 861 (1992); Barlet v. State, 288 S.C. 481, 483, 343 S.E.2d 620, 622 (1986).Â  â€œTherefore, in those cases involving the failure to pay fines or restitution, the circuit judge must, in addition to finding sufficient factual evidence of the violation, make an additional finding of willfulness.â€Â  Hamilton, 333 S.C. at 649, 511 S.E.2d at 97.
â€œWillful failure to pay means a voluntary, conscious and intentional failure.â€Â  People v. Davis, 576 N.E.2d 510, 513 (Ill. App. Ct. 1991); see State v. Sowell, 370 S.C. 330, 336, 635 S.E.2d 81, 83 (2006) (â€œA willful act is defined as one â€˜done voluntarily and intentionally with the specific intent to do something the law forbids, or with the specific intent to fail to do something the law requires to be done; that is to say, with bad purpose either to disobey or disregard the law.â€™â€ (quoting Spartanburg County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Padgett, 296 S.C. 79, 82-83, 370 S.E.2d 872, 874 (1988))). Â â€œThe trial court may infer that the failure to pay is intentional where a probationer has the ability to pay a fee, but does not do so.â€Â  Joseph v. State, 3 S.W.3d 627, 641 (Tex. Crim. App. 1999)(citations omitted).Â 
 
â€œA proper analysis should include an inquiry into the reasons surrounding the probationerâ€™s failure to pay, followed by a determination of whether the probationer made a willful choice not to pay.â€Â  Commonwealth v. Eggers, 742 A.2d 174, 176 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1999).Â  â€œAfter making those determinations, if the court finds the probationer â€˜could not pay despite sufficient bona fide efforts to acquire the resources to do so,â€™ the court should then consider alternatives to incarceration in accordance with Bearden.â€ Id. at 176 (quoting Bearden v. Georgia, 461 U.S. 660, 672 (1983)).
Turning to the facts of the instant case, we find the circuit court judge abused his discretion in concluding that Spareâ€™s failure to pay restitution was willful.Â  Based on our review of the record, we believe the judge failed to make the requisite inquiry into Spareâ€™s ability to pay, his reasons for failing to pay, and whether his failure to pay was willful.Â  From all indications, Spare was making progress, albeit slow, toward paying his restitution obligation.Â  After being released from the Restitution Center, he obtained a full-time job in which he worked forty-four hours per week.Â  As represented by counsel, Spare was using his income from this job to pay for housing at a local motel, pay the IRS for back taxes, and make payments toward his court-ordered financial obligation.Â  Significantly, Spareâ€™s probation agent stated at the hearing that Spare has â€œsome financial situations that donâ€™t particularly allow him to pay the $753 a month that he has been ordered to.â€
 
Therefore, without a specific accounting of Spareâ€™s total earnings, living expenses, other sources of income, and potential earning capacity, it is difficult to conclude that he had the ability to pay more toward his restitution but made a voluntary, conscious, and intentional decision not to pay.Â  Although we understand the courtâ€™s frustration with Spareâ€™s limited progress in making payments, we find the evidence does not support the courtâ€™s finding of willfulness.Â  
 
Based on the foregoing discussion, we vacate the revocation of Spareâ€™s probation and remand this case for a new probation revocation hearing.Â  See Eggers, 742 A.2d at 176 (vacating revocation of probation based on probationerâ€™s failure to pay and remanding for a new hearing where trial court â€œmade no judicial inquiry into the [probationerâ€™s] ability to pay and reasons for [probationerâ€™s] failure to make paymentâ€ and disregarded â€œan inquiry into whether the failure to pay was willful, and if willful, whether alternatives to incarceration were properâ€); Davis, 576 N.E.2d at 513-14 (reversing revocation of probation for probationerâ€™s failure to pay and remanding for trial court to determine whether an additional period of probation should be granted within which restitution may be paid where there was evidence that probationer made restitution payments before becoming unemployed and the record did not show that defendant refused to work merely to avoid restitution); see also Jordan v. State, 939 S.W.2d 255, 257-58 (Ark. 1997)(reversing and remanding revocation of probation for failure to pay, based on state statutory guidelines, and holding that probationerâ€™s lack of financial assistance from family and friends did not demonstrate that probationer willfully refused to pay restitution and could not be the basis for revoking probation).
VACATED AND REMANDED.[3]
ANDERSON and HUFF, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  In Bearden v. Georgia, the United States Supreme Court established the analytical procedure required for the revocation of probation based solely on a probationerâ€™s failure to pay a fine and make restitution.Â  Specifically, the Court stated:

	We hold, therefore, that in revocation proceedings for failure to pay a fine or restitution, a sentencing court must inquire into the reasons for the failure to pay.Â  If the probationer willfully refused to pay or failed to make sufficient bona fide efforts legally to acquire the resources to pay, the court may revoke probation and sentence the defendant to imprisonment within the authorized range of its sentencing authority.Â  If the probationer could not pay despite sufficient bona fide efforts to acquire the resources to do so, the court must consider alternate measures of punishment other than imprisonment.Â  Only if alternate measures are not adequate to meet the Stateâ€™s interests in punishment and deterrence may the court imprison a probationer who has made sufficient bona fide efforts to pay.Â  To do otherwise would deprive the probationer of his conditional freedom simply because, through no fault of his own, he cannot pay the fine.Â  Such a deprivation would be contrary to the fundamental fairness required by the Fourteenth Amendment.

Bearden v. Georgia, 461 U.S. 660, 673 (1983).
[3]Â Â  Although the State indicates in its brief that Spare was released from prison during the pendency of this appeal, we do not believe the issue presented is moot given the restitution is still outstanding and Spare will undoubtedly be issued another financial probation citation for being in arrears.
