title: Town of Iva v. Holley
description: At issue in this appeal is whether the Town of Iva denied the appellants equal protection of the law in its enforcement of a zoning ordinance prohibiting mobile homes in certain areas.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Town of Iva, By and Through Its Zoning Administrator, Respondent,
				v.
				Annette Holley and Anne Holley-Barnes, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Anderson County
Â Ellis B. Drew, Jr., Master-In-Equity
Opinion No. 4262
Heard April 10, 2007 â€“ Filed June 21, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood, for Appellants.
				Mary C. McCormac, of Clemson, for Respondent.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, J.:Â Â  Annette Holley and Anne Holley-Barnes (collectively the Holleys) appeal an order in which the master-in-equity found the enforcement of a zoning ordinance against them did not violate the Equal Protection Clause.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In 1986, the Town of Iva (the Town) adopted a zoning ordinance that included an â€œRSâ€ classification intended to provide â€œhomogeneous and aesthetically harmonious development of single-family dwellings on lots having an area of 10,000 square feet or more.â€Â  One permitted use in the RS area was â€œ[d]etached single-family dwellings, excluding mobile homes.â€ Â After enactment of the ordinance, however, city officials did not regularly enforce the portion of the ordinance not allowing mobile homes in the RS zone even after appellant Annette Holley complained in 1999 during a town council meeting that mobile homes had been placed in areas that were not zoned for them. Â 
On July 1, 2002, the Townâ€™s newly elected mayor and council members were sworn into office.Â  Since then, the Town has prohibited mobile homes in RS areas that were not in place before the new administration took office. Â The decision to enforce the prohibition against mobile homes in RS areas was made without a public vote or public notice, and the Town apparently failed to notify Anderson County, the governmental entity responsible for issuing permits to move mobile homes.Â  
 
On January 15, 2003, Holleyâ€™s daughter, appellant Anne Holley-Barnes, obtained a permit from Anderson County to move her mobile home onto Holleyâ€™s property at 400 Betsy Street.Â  400 Betsy Street is in an RS zone of the Town.Â  In preparation for the move, Holley-Barnes paid a deposit to the Town for sewer and water connections.Â  After the mobile home was moved onto the lot, both a Town police officer and a Town council member informed Holley-Barnes the mobile home was located on property not zoned for mobile homes and she would not be allowed to complete the installation.Â  The Holleys refused to remove the mobile home from the property and continued with the remaining preparations.Â  On January 20, 2003, the mayor and town council notified Holley-Barnes by letter to â€œcease and desist from continuing any further actions to install a mobile home on the property.â€Â  Although the Town sent the Holleys several more letters informing them of the zoning ordinance violation and their rights to appeal the zoning enforcement, the Holleys persisted in their refusal to remove the mobile home from 400 Betsy Street.
On October 9, 2003, the Town filed a complaint against the Holleys for violating the zoning ordinance.Â  The Holleys answered, asserting the Town was selectively enforcing the zoning ordinance in violation of the Equal Protection Clause.[1]Â  At trial, the town clerk and treasurer acknowledged that, since the adoption of the ordinance in 1986, many mobile homes, including one in which the mayor resided, had been moved into the RS zone.Â  Two witnesses who had both previously served as mayor and as council members testified that, while they were in office, the Town had never enforced the zoning ordinance as to mobile homes.Â  Both witnesses left their offices in 2002.
The master found the Holleys did not demonstrate the Town did not treat them differently from the way it treated other similarly situated persons, namely those desiring to place mobile homes in RS areas after July 1, 2002, when the members of the current administration took office.Â  Furthermore, the master found the Holleys were in knowing violation of the zoning ordinance since January 15, 2003, and ordered them to remove the mobile home within ninety days.Â  The master declined to assess any fines against the Holleys unless the mobile home was not removed in the time specified, in which case they would be fined $500.00 per day.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, the Holleys contend the master erred in failing to find the Town, in enforcing the zoning ordinance against them, denied them equal protection under the law.Â  We disagree.
Under the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment, a state may not â€œdeny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws.â€[2] Â This clause requires that â€œthe states apply each law, within its scope, equally to persons similarly situated, and that any differences of application must be justified by the lawâ€™s purpose.â€[3] Â It does not dictate that people in different circumstances cannot be treated differently under the law.[4] Â Rather, â€œthe classification must be reasonable, not arbitrary, and must rest upon some ground of difference having a fair and substantial relation to the object of the legislation, so that all persons similarly circumstanced shall be treated alike.â€[5] Â 
One seeking to show discriminatory enforcement in violation of the Equal Protection Clause must demonstrate arbitrary and purposeful discrimination in the administration of the law being enforced.[6]Â  â€œ[E]ven assuming [a governmental entity] is not enforcing [an] ordinance equally, the fact that there is some unequal treatment does not necessarily rise to the level of a constitutional equal protection violation.â€[7]Â   
In the present case, we agree with the master that the Holleys failed to establish the Town had a discriminatory purpose in enforcing the zoning ordinance against them.Â  In their brief, the Holleys noted there had been a feud between Annette Holley and the Town since 1999, when Holley began appearing at council meetings to complain about mobile homes installed in violation of the ordinance[8]; however, the record shows the Town has enforced the ordinance against all others attempting to move mobile homes into RS areas since July 1, 2002, even those who sought to replace mobiles homes that were installed in such areas before enactment of the ordinance. 
 
Moreover, we do not agree with the Holleys that the â€œclass of oneâ€ concept discussed by the United States Supreme Court in Village of Willowbrook v. Olech[9] supports their claim of an equal protection violation. Â Willowbrook concerned a dismissal of a complaint â€œfor failure to state a cognizable claim under the Equal Protection Clause.â€[10] Â The present case, however, involves a merits hearing at which the Town demonstrated to the satisfaction of the hearing tribunal that the efforts of the current council members to enforce the ordinance against those seeking to move mobile homes onto properties in RS areas after July 1, 2002, would further the stated purpose of the ordinance of â€œprovid[ing] a homogeneous and aesthetically harmonious development of single-family dwellings on lots having an area of 10,000 square feet or more.â€[11]Â  Moreover, consistent enforcement of the prohibition against mobile homes in RS areas, regardless of when such enforcement has begun, will eventually result in phasing out all mobile homes in those locations because of the relatively temporary nature of this type of dwelling. Â Â Â 
Because the Town has enforced the ordinance against all others attempting to move mobile homes onto property in the RS areas after the new Town administration took office and because the enforcement was rationally related to a legitimate governmental objective, we affirm the masterâ€™s determination that the application of the zoning ordinance against the Holleys did not violate the Equal Protection Clause.Â 
 
AFFIRMED. 
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J., concur.

[1]Â  The pleadings indicate the Holleys unsuccessfully sought to have the Town rezone the property at 400 Betsy Street; however, it was unclear whether the Holleys sought judicial review of the Townâ€™s decision.
[2]Â  U.S. Const. amend. XIV, Â§ 1.Â  
 
[3]Â  Sylvia Dev. Corp. v. Calvert County, Md., 48 F.3d 810, 818 (4th Cir. 1995).Â  
 
[4]Â  Id.Â  
 
[5]Â  Royster Guano Co. v. Virginia, 253 U.S. 412, 415 (1920).
[6]Â  See Snowden v. Hughes, 321 U.S. 1, 8 (1944) (â€œ[A] discriminatory purpose is not presumed.â€); State v. Solomon,245 S.C. 550, 574, 141 S.E.2d 818, 831 (1965) (noting evidence of unequal enforcement â€œwas insufficient to show discriminatory enforcement in violation of the Equal Protection Clause [because] [t]here was a total absence of testimony to show an arbitrary and purposeful discrimination in the administration of the statute necessary to sustain the claimâ€).Â 
 
[7]Â  Denene, Inc. v. City of Charleston, 359 S.C. 85, 96, 596 S.E.2d 917, 922 (2004); see also 
Oyler v. Boles, 368 U.S. 448, 456 (1962) (holding â€œthe conscious exercise of some selectivity in enforcement is not in itself a federal constitutional violation,â€ absent allegations that â€œthe selection was deliberately based upon an unjustifiable standard such as race, religion, or other arbitrary classificationâ€).Â  We note the Holleys have not alleged they are members of a protected class, defined by the South Carolina Supreme Court as a class â€œsaddled with such disabilities, or subjected to such history of purposeful unequal treatment, or relegated to such a position of political powerlessness as to command extraordinary protection from the majoritarian political process.â€Â  Denene, Inc., 359 S.C. at 94, 96, 596 S.E.2d at 921-22 (quoting Massachusetts Bd. of Retirement v. Murgia, 427 U.S. 307, 313 (1976)).
[8] Â The animosity continued after Holley-Barnes moved her mobile home onto the Betsy Street property.Â  After the Town asked Holley to remove the mobile home from her property but before it filed suit against her, Holley placed an outhouse on her property and spray-painted references to the Town on it.Â  In addition, according to the Holleysâ€™ attorney, Holley placed a pile of manure on a lot she owned that was located across the street from the mayorâ€™s residence as well as a junk car that was also spray-painted with notations that appeared to be references to the mayor and the Town.
[9] 528 U.S. 562 (2000).
[10] Id. at 563.Â  In her complaint, the plaintiff in Willowbrook alleged â€œthe Village intentionally demanded a 33-foot easement as a condition of connecting her property to the municipal water supplyâ€ but â€œrequired only a 15-foot easement from other similarly situated property ownersâ€ and â€œthe Villageâ€™s demand was â€˜irrational and wholly arbitrary.â€™ â€ Id. at 565.
[11] See Denene, 359 S.C. at 91, 596 S.E.2d at 920 (â€œIf the classification does not implicate a suspect class or abridge a fundamental right, the rational basis test is used.â€); City of Beaufort v. Holcombe, 369 S.C. 643, 648, 632 S.E.2d 894, 897 (Ct. App. 2006) (applying the â€œrational basisâ€ test based on a determination that the class at issue in the case was not a suspect class).

title: Williams v. Williams
description: The issues in this appeal are (1) whether the family court properly dismissed an equitable distribution claim for failure to plead the requisite elements of fraud; and (2) whether the family court properly dismissed the daughters of the now-deceased wife as parties to the action.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				James Lee Williams, Appellant,
				v.
				Betty R. Williams, by her personal representatives, Renitia W. Anderson and Wanda H. Sturkey, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â Kellum W. Allen, Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 4263
Heard April 10, 2007 â€“ Filed June 21, 2007
REVERSED AND REMANDED


	
		
			
				Jan L. Warner, of 
				
				Columbia, for Appellant.
				Stevens Bultman Elliott, of
				
				Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, J:Â  In this family court proceeding, James Lee Williams (Husband) appeals the dismissal of his claim for equitable distribution and the dismissal of Respondents Renetia W. Anderson and Wanda H. Sturkey as defendants in their individual capacities.Â  We reverse and remand.Â Â Â 
 
FACTS
Husband married Betty R. Williams (Wife) in 1981.Â  Both had been married before.Â  Before the marriage, Husband owned as his separate property a lot and residence located at 237 Lowry Road in Lexington, South Carolina.Â  Husband had purchased this property with a Veterans Administration loan in his name.
During the early years of their marriage, Husband drank to excess regularly.Â  Around 1982, Husband was committed to the South Carolina Department of Mental Health for treatment of various problems, most of which concerned his drinking. 
 
Husband maintained that, because of his memory deficits and vulnerability, he thereafter depended on Wife to handle his financial dealings.Â  Regardless of whether this assertion is correct, it appears undisputed that most of his income was deposited into a joint account on which Wife could write checks. 
 
Apparently with the consent of both Husband and Wife, Respondent Anderson, one of Wifeâ€™s daughters from a prior marriage, moved with her family into the residence on the Lowry Road property with the understanding that she pay rent.Â  Husband and Wife then moved into a mobile home on the same lot.Â  Thereafter, according to Husband, Respondent Sturkey, another of Wifeâ€™s daughters from her prior marriage, moved her mobile home to the Lowry Road property on the condition that she also pay rent.
In 2003, Husband, while measuring the residence so he could have aluminum siding installed, was verbally accosted by Anderson, who asserted she now owned the residence and he could not have anything to do with it.Â  Husband then went to the Lexington County Registrar of Deeds and located two deeds, one dated July 1, 1983, and the other dated January 26, 1995.Â  In the first deed, Husband purportedly conveyed the Lowry Road property to Wife.Â  In the second deed, Wife in turn transferred the property to Anderson and Sturkey.Â  According to Husband, further investigation revealed that neither Anderson nor Sturkey paid rent and both had misappropriated money from the joint checking account.
Husband commenced this action against Wife, Anderson, and Sturkey on July 11, 2003.Â  In his pleadings, Husband alleged he â€œdid not recall signingâ€ the 1983 deed and â€œbelieve[d] he was tricked into signing said document.â€Â  Husband requested, among other relief, an equitable division of the assets of the marriage, including the Lowry Road property and rental income from Anderson and Sturkey. Â On September 10, 2003, counsel for Wife,[1] Sturkey, and Anderson filed responsive pleadings contending, among other defenses, the action should be dismissed because Husband failed to allege sufficient facts to support an action for fraud. Â Â 
A final hearing in the matter took place on August 29 and 30, 2005.Â  By order dated October 13, 2005, the family court, although finding the action was for equitable division and declining to dismiss the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction, granted the motion to dismiss insofar as it concerned the Lowry Road property on the ground that Husbandâ€™s allegations concerning this asset did not include the requisite elements of a cause of action for fraud.Â  In addition, the family court dismissed Sturkey and Anderson as defendants in their individual capacities.[2]Â  Following the denial of his motion to reconsider, Husband filed this appeal.
LAW/ANALYSIS
On appeal, Husband contends that, because the family court had subject matter jurisdiction to apportion property owned by third parties, it erred in dismissing his complaint for failure to state facts sufficient to constitute a cause of action for fraud and in dismissing Anderson and Sturkey as individual defendants in this action.Â  We agree.[3]
South Carolina Code section 20-7-473 defines marital property as â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation . . . regardless of how legal title is held.â€[4]Â  As noted by the supreme court in Sexton v. Sexton, â€œ[t]his section specifically provides for the possibility that marital property could be titled in a third party.â€[5] Â 
In the present case, neither Husband nor Wife has held legal title to the disputed property since 1995.Â  Nevertheless, under Sexton, the family court in this case had subject matter jurisdiction to determine if the Lowry Road property was marital property as defined in section 20-7-473 and to join Anderson and Sturkey as defendants in their individual capacities based their position as record owners of the property under the 1995 deed.Â 
 
In our view, the complaint adequately alleges the Lowry Road property was subject to equitable division.Â  Whether Husband knowingly deeded the property to Wife in 1983 or she deceived him into transferring it to her, the conveyance of the property from Husband to Wife during the partiesâ€™ marriage would have been sufficient reason to classify it as marital property, but for Wifeâ€™s purported conveyance to Anderson and Sturkey.[6] Â 
Furthermore, because Anderson and Sturkey hold title to the property, we agree with Husband they should not have been dismissed as defendants to this lawsuit.Â  As the supreme court held in Sexton, 
 

	[W]hen property is alleged to be marital property, but is owned by a third party, the Family Court has the subject matter jurisdiction to join all persons with a possible interest in the property as parties to the action and to determine if the property constitutes marital property as defined in Â§ 20-7-473.Â  If it is determined that the property is marital property, then the Family Court has the authority to determine the partiesâ€™ equitable rights therein.[7]Â  Â 

As evident in the above-quoted passage, to join a third party in an action for equitable distribution, a litigant needs only to make allegations to support a contention that property titled in the third partyâ€™s name is actually marital property.Â  Moreover, the language in this passage indicates that, if the requisite allegation is made, the party seeking equitable division is entitled at least to a determination by the family court as to whether the property in question is in fact a marital asset.[8]Â  In the present case, the complaint alleges facts that, if substantiated at trial, would support a finding that Wife â€œacquiredâ€ the Lowry Road property during the partiesâ€™ marriage.Â  We therefore hold the family court prematurely dismissed Husbandâ€™s claim for equitable distribution of the Lowry Road property.Â Â  Â Â Â 
In determining that Husband was entitled to have the family court determine whether or not the Lowry Road property was a marital asset, we are mindful of the caveat in Panhorst v. Panhorst, wherein this court cautioned that section 20-7-473, in specifying â€œthat the marital estate must be identified as of a fixed date,â€ . . . has the effect of â€œforeclos[ing] spouses from litigating every expenditure or transfer of property during the marriageâ€ and preventing marital litigants from â€œresurrectingâ€ foolish, selfish, or unprofitable transactions â€œto gain an advantage in the equitable distribution.â€[9] Â We note, however, that in Panhorst this court also recognized that cases involving â€œfraudulent transfers or dissipation of marital assets in contemplation of the breakdown of the marriageâ€ are distinguishable.[10]Â  Moreover, in following the supreme courtâ€™s directive in Sexton, we hold that a party seeking equitable division of an asset need only set forth allegations to support a finding that the asset is marital property in order to have the family court make this threshold determination.[11]
Based on the foregoing, we hold Husband is entitled to have the family court determine whether the Lowry Road property is a marital asset and, if so, to have the court determine the rights of all parties claiming an interest to it.Â  For this reason, we also hold Anderson and Sturkey should remain parties to this action pending further determination by the family court as to the marital nature of the property.
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J., concur.

[1]Â  Wife died on September 4, 2003, and her estate was later substituted as a party Defendant through her personal representative.
[2]Â  In the appealed order, the family court granted Husband his personal property that was located at the Lowry Road property and a cemetery plot in West Columbia, South Carolina.Â  The court also dismissed Husbandâ€™s claim for damages on the ground that it lacked statutory authority.
[3]Â  Husband does not appeal the dismissal of his claim for damages; therefore, we do not consider whether he can proceed on his claims concerning rent payments, funds allegedly misappropriated by Anderson and Sturkey, or damages allegedly caused by Sturkey in placing a right-of-way on the Lowry Road property.
[4]Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2006) (emphasis added).
[5]Â  Sexton v. Sexton, 298 S.C. 359, 361, 380 S.E.2d 832, 834 (1989); see also S.C. Code Ann. 20-7-420(19) (1985) (granting the family court jurisdiction to â€œbring in and make parties to any proceedings pending in the court any person or persons . . . whose presence to the proceedings may be found necessary to complete determination of the issues therein . . . .â€).
[6]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473(1) (Supp. 2006) (exempting â€œproperty acquired by either party by . . . giftâ€ from inclusion in the marital estate, but noting the gift must be â€œfrom a party other than the spouseâ€).
[7]Â  Â Sexton, 298 S.C. at 361-62, 380 S.E.2d at 834 (emphasis added).Â  
 
[8]Â  As noted in Sexton, â€œ[i]f the property is found to be marital property, the Court has the authority to apportion it among the parties. In contrast, if it is not marital property, the owners of the property may be dismissed as parties.â€Â  Id. at 361, 380 S.E.2d at 834.
[9] Â Panhorst v. Panhorst, 301 S.C. 100, 105, 390 S.E.2d 376, 379 (Ct. App. 1990).
[10] Id. at 105, 390 S.E.2d at 379.
[11] It is for this reason that we reject Respondentsâ€™ argument that Husbandâ€™s action, insofar as it concerned the Lowry Road property, was incorrectly filed in the family court.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Law Firm of Paul L. Erickson, P.A. Appellant,
        v.
        James R. Boykin and Mona S. Boykin, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
  Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Opinion No. 4264
  Heard November 6, 2007 â€“ Filed June 27,
  2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Paul L. Erickson, of Asheville, N.C., for Appellant.
        Carolyn R. Hills, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  

SHORT, J.: Â Paul
  L. Erickson appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order denying enforcement of a North Carolina default judgment based on the foreign courtâ€™s lack of personal
  jurisdiction.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
James and Mona Boykin (the Boykins) are
  residents of Horry County, South Carolina and the parents of an autistic son.Â  In 1999, they hired Erickson, a North Carolina attorney licensed to
  practice law in South Carolina, to represent them in an action against the Horry County  School District for failure to provide certain services to their son.

DEFAULT JUDGMENT
The Full Faith and
  Credit Clause provides that â€œFull Faith and Credit shall be given in each state
  to the . . . judicial proceedings of every other State.â€Â  U.S. Const. Art. IV. Â§ 1.Â  This clause requires that judgments of the courts of one state are given
  the same faith and credit in another state.Â  Hamilton v. Patterson, 236
  S.C. 487, 492, 115 S.E.2d 68, 70 (1960) (citation omitted). Â Where a judgment
  is rendered by a court of competent jurisdiction, the Full Faith and Credit
  Clause precludes any examination into the merits of the case â€œor the validity
  of the legal principles on which the judgment is based.â€Â  Id.Â  However, the
  â€œFull Faith and Credit Clause does not prevent the litigation of personal jurisdiction in an action
  to enforce a foreign judgment.Â  Colonial Pacific Leasing Corp. v. Taylor,
  326 S.C. 529, 532, 484 S.E.2d 595, 596-7 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Â Â 
The Supreme
  Court of South Carolina has recognized that a judgment rendered by a court
  presumes subject matter and personal jurisdiction, and if the judgment â€œappears
  on its face to be a record of a court of general jurisdiction, such
  jurisdiction overâ€ the case is presumed â€œunless disproved by extrinsic
  evidence, or by the record itself.â€Â  Taylor v. Taylor, 229 S.C.
  92, 97, 91 S.E.2d 876, 879 (1956) (citations omitted).Â  As part of the Uniform
  Enforcement of Foreign Judgments Act, South Carolina has enacted Â§15-35-940 which
  provides:

  (A)Â 
    The judgment debtor may file a motion for relief from, or notice of defense to,
    the foreign judgment . . . on any . . . ground for which relief from a judgment
    of this State is allowed.
  (B)Â  If
    the judgment debtor has filed a motion for relief or notice of defenses, then
    the judgment creditor may move for enforcement or security of the foreign
    judgment as a judgment of this State, if all appeals of the foreign judgment
    are finally concluded and the judgment is not further contested.Â  The judgment
    creditorâ€™s motion must be heard before a judge who has jurisdiction of the
    matter based upon the amount in controversy as the amount remaining unpaid on
    the foreign judgment.Â  The South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure apply.Â  The
      judgment creditor has the burden of proving that the foreign judgment is
      entitled to full faith and credit.Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-35-940 (2005)
  (emphasis added).Â  
This statute was enacted by
  the Legislature to extend greater protection to South Carolina citizens in the
  enforcement of foreign judgments and impacts the earlier presumption of
  validity laid out in South Carolina case law.Â  
Under
  this statutory scheme, the presumption of regularity ends when the judgment
  debtor files a motion for relief from or notice of defense to the foreign

  to full faith and credit shifts to the judgment creditor.[1]Â  See The Jay Group, Ltd. v. The Bootery of Haywood Mall, Inc., 335

In
  the present case, the Boykins, who did not make a general appearance in North Carolina, moved for relief from enforcement of the foreign judgment.Â  Upon this
  motion, pursuant to Â§15-35-940(B) the burden of proving the North Carolina
  judgment was entitled to full faith and credit shifted to Erickson.Â  The only evidence

The dissent
  would reverse based on a finding that Erickson, the judgment creditor, had not

JUDICIAL NOTICE
Erickson
  argues the circuit court erred in failing to take judicial notice of numerous
  documents and facts, and he requests this court take judicial notice of the

  that the circuit court take judicial notice of the complaint he filed in North Carolina, the attorney/client agreement between the parties, and an affidavit stating
  the Boykins solicited his services and attesting to the number of hours he

  (a)
    Scope of Rule. This rule governs
    only judicial notice of adjudicative facts.
  (b)
    Kinds of Facts. A judicially noticed fact
    must be one not subject to reasonable dispute in
    that it is either (1) generally known within the territorial jurisdiction of the
    trial court or (2) capable of accurate and ready determination by resort to
    sources whose accuracy cannot reasonably be questioned.

    Time of Taking Notice. Judicial notice may be taken at any stage of the proceeding. . . .

When a court takes judicial
  notice of a fact it â€œadmit[s] into evidence and consider[s], without proof of

  S.E.2d 610, 615 (Ct. App. 2002) (citation omitted). 
The facts included
  in the documents presented by Erickson are not the type accepted without

Additionally,
  Erickson requests this court take judicial notice of certain facts showing the

  difficult to discern from the record if Erickson requested the circuit court

Denckla, 357 U.S. 235, 253 (1958) (â€œThe unilateral activity [within the forum state] of

  the requirement of contact with the forum State.â€).Â

  burden of proof in all cases in which the judgment debtor attacks the
  validity of a foreign judgment.Â  As explained above, this conclusion is
  erroneous.Â  Only where the judgment debtor moves for relief from a foreign
  judgment and the judgment creditor â€œthenâ€ moves for enforcement does the
  judgment creditor have the burden of proving the foreign judgment is entitled
  to full faith and credit.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-35-940(B) (2005). 
[22]Â  Taylor v. Taylor, 229 S.C. 92, 97, 91
  S.E.2d 876, 879 (1956).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Shirley Leder Osterneck, as Personal Representative of the Estate of Guy Kenneth Osterneck, Appellant,        
          
        
        v.
        Myles N. Osterneck, Gertrude B. Osterneck, and Rhoda Osterneck, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master In Equity

Opinion No. 4265
Heard May 9, 2007 â€“ Filed June 27, 2007

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        John Ravenel Chase, of Florence, and Sarah Patrick Spruill, of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
        David B. Miller and Mary Anna Neill, both of Myrtle Beach, for
          Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Shirley Osterneck appeals the master in equityâ€™s ruling that Myles
  Osterneck is the owner of property formerly owned by his parents, David and
  Gertrude Osterneck (Father and Mother).Â  Shirley disputes the masterâ€™s reliance
  on a purported family agreement between Mother and her children, and the
  allowance of testimony by Rhoda Osterneck, Father and Motherâ€™s
  daughter-in-law.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Father died testate on November 9, 1986,
  survived by Mother and their three sons: Â Robert, Guy Kenneth, and Myles.Â  Fatherâ€™s
  will named Myles and Robert as co-executors; however, Robert declined to serve.Â 
  Fatherâ€™s estate consisted of a one-half interest in the marital home, worth
  approximately $225,000, and approximately $231,000 in other assets.Â  Father and
  Mother also held a joint certificate of deposit with a right of survivorship.Â 
  The certificate of deposit was valued at $230,000.Â  Fatherâ€™s will left Mother
  all personal property and the sons $500,000 to divide equally. Â There were
  insufficient non-marital assets in the estate to fund the bequest to the sons.Â 
  Fatherâ€™s will did not specifically devise his one-half interest in the marital
  home.Â  On June 11, 1987, Mother disclaimed her interest in the certificate of
  deposit, allowing the money to pass to the estate.Â  
Father and Motherâ€™s eldest son, Robert, died in 1991 and was
  survived by his widow, Rhoda.Â  Father and Motherâ€™s middle son, Guy Kenneth,
  passed away in 1993 and was survived by his widow, Shirley, the appellant.Â  
In
  October 1993, Myles filed a petition to reopen Fatherâ€™s estate for the purpose
  of conveying Fatherâ€™s one-half interest in the marital home to Mother.Â  In a letter dated December 1994, Shirley received
  notice regarding the deed of distribution. 
In October 1998, Myles purchased the marital home from Mother for
  $635,000, $10,000 more than its appraised value.Â  In March 2001, Shirley
  instituted litigation claiming an interest in the marital home.Â  She subsequently
  filed an amended complaint alleging breach of fiduciary duty and fraud by
  Myles.Â  
The master found
  that a family agreement existed to exchange Fatherâ€™s half interest in the
  marital home for Motherâ€™s interest in the certificate of deposit, and that
  title to the marital home belonged to Myles.Â  Further, the master held Myles
  did not commit fraud or breach his fiduciary duty and that these claims were
  barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The parties
  disagree on the applicable standard of review.Â  A declaratory judgment action
  is neither equitable nor legal, but is instead determined by the nature of the
  underlying issue.Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400
  S.E.2d 781, 782 (1991).Â  
Shirley argues the underlying action is to quiet
  title, which she requested in her amended complaint.Â  An action to quiet title
  resides in equity. Â Van Every v. Chinquapin Hollow, Inc., 265 S.C. 474,
  477, 219 S.E.2d 909, 910 (1975).Â  When reviewing an equitable action heard first
  by a master-in-equity and appealed directly to an appellate court, the court
  should review the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of
  evidence in the record.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229,
  237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1990).Â  This broad scope of review does not require
  the appellate court to ignore the fact that the master was in a better position
  to assess the credibility of witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Id.
Myles argues the
  real issue is determining who has title to the marital home.Â  The determination
  of who has title to real estate is a legal issue.Â  Cook v. Eller,
  298 S.C. 395, 397, 380 S.E.2d 853, 854 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œIn a law case tried
  by the judge without a jury the standard of appellate review is limited to a
  correction of errors of law and a determination if there is any evidence to
  support the factual findings of the trial judge.â€Â  Id. (citing Wigfall v.
    Fobbs, 295 S.C. 59, 367 S.E.2d 156 (1988); Patterson v. I.H. Servs. Inc.,
  295 S.C. 300, 368 S.E.2d 215 (Ct. App. 1988)).
It is unnecessary
  for us to determine which standard of review is applicable in this particular
  case, as under either standard the result would be the same.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Family Agreement
Shirley argues the master
  erred in finding the existence of a family agreement to exchange Fatherâ€™s
  estateâ€™s half interest in the marital home for Motherâ€™s interest in a
  certificate of deposit.Â  We disagree.
First,
  we note the South Carolina Probate Code generally requires family agreements to
  be in writing.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-912 (1987).Â  However, the South Carolina
  Probate Code does not apply to this case, because the probate code took effect
  on July 1, 1987, after the agreement resulting in the swap of assets.[1] 
The recognition
  of family agreements is favored by the courts, and the evidence in this case
  fully supports the making of such an agreement.Â  Smith v. Williams,
  141 S.C. 265, 279, 139 S.E. 625, 629 (1927).Â  From a documentary perspective,
  Fatherâ€™s estateâ€™s half interest in the marital home was initially listed in the
  estateâ€™s probate papers.Â  Mother then signed a document disclaiming her
  interest in a certificate of deposit worth $230,000, allowing this sum to pass
  through the estate to the sons.Â  Subsequently, an accounting was submitted by
  Myles, which listed the certificate of deposit but did not list the one-half
  interest in the marital home.Â  Lastly, the deed of distribution was executed by
  Myles on behalf of Fatherâ€™s estate, giving Mother the entire interest in the
  marital home.Â  
Additionally, the
  testimony of several parties corroborated the evidence regarding the existence
  of a family agreement.Â  Kenneth Davis, the accountant who prepared the tax
  return for Fatherâ€™s estate, stated in a deposition:

  So all
    of us met - - Myles, Guy [Kenneth], Bob, and his mother.Â  All these Osternecks
    and myself met in Guyâ€™s office.Â  And thatâ€™s when they told me that they had
    decided that they had made a swap of the CD for the - - for the house in her
    name.Â  So - - and for me to go ahead and make the tax return based on - - and -
    - and whatever was best.Â  So thatâ€™s when I came up with the disclaimer.

At trial Myles
  testified, â€œ[m]y brothers and myself agreed to exchange the half interest in my
  father and motherâ€™s home so that my mother had full title to the house in
  exchange for the $230,000.â€Â  In addition, the testimony of Rhoda, discussed in
  more detail below, further corroborates the existence of the agreement. 
Shirley correctly
  notes that certain tax returns for Fatherâ€™s estate indicate that Mother and
  Father jointly held title to the marital home as tenants by the entirety.[2]Â 
  She contends therefore that the family believed Mother already owned the
  marital home outright, and she gave her disclaimer for no consideration.Â  If
  so, there was no true exchange, and Fatherâ€™s half interest in the house should
  remain in trust for the ultimate benefit of the sons or their heirs.Â  Despite
  the tax returns, the greater weight of the evidence supports the existence of a
  family agreement.Â  Consequently, the ruling of the master was appropriate.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Testimony Against
  Interest
Shirley
  further argues the master erred by admitting hearsay testimony from Rhoda
  Osterneck regarding statements by Rhodaâ€™s deceased husband, Robert.Â  We disagree.
â€œThe
  admission of evidence is a matter left to the discretion of the trial judge
  and, absent clear abuse, will not be disturbed on appeal.â€Â  Carlyle v.
    Tuomey Hosp., 305 S.C. 187, 193, 407 S.E.2d 630, 633 (1991)
  (citation omitted).Â  â€œIn order for this court to reverse a case based on the
  erroneous admission or erroneous exclusion of evidence the plaintiff must show
  error and prejudice.â€Â  Timmons v. S.C. Tricentennial Commâ€™n, 254 S.C.
  378, 405, 175 S.E.2d 805, 819 (1970).
Rules
  804(a)(4) and 804(b)(3) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence provide
  exceptions to the hearsay rule if the declarant, in this case Robert, is
  unavailable due to death. Â The exception permits the admission of the statement
  if it is so far contrary to the declarantâ€™s pecuniary interest that a
  reasonable man in the same position would not have made the statement unless it
  was true.Â  Rule 804(b)(3), SCRE. 
Section
  19-11-20 of the South Carolina Code (1976), the â€œDead Manâ€™sâ€ statute, bars the
  testimony of a person with an interest from testifying regarding a conversation
  with a deceased individual.Â  However, the statute has many exceptions,
  including â€œwitness testimony that is against his or her interest.â€Â  Brooks
    v. Kay, 339 S.C. 479, 486, 530 S.E.2d 120, 124 (2000).Â  
At
  trial, Rhoda agreed she was in the same legal position as Shirley because they
  are both widows of a son of Father and Mother.Â  Rhoda testified her deceased
  husband had told her that the sons and Mother met with the accountant and
  decided Mother would disclaim her interest in the certificate of deposit in
  exchange for Fatherâ€™s estateâ€™s one-half interest in the marital home.Â  
Rhodaâ€™s
  testimony was against her personal interest, because she could make the same
  claim Shirley was pursuing for an interest in the marital home.Â  Additionally,
  Rhodaâ€™s husbandâ€™s statement was against his own interest because, if the family
  agreement did not exist and Mother disclaimed her interest in the certificate
  of deposit, the sons would have a windfall.Â  Therefore, the master did not
  abuse his discretion in admitting Rhodaâ€™s testimony.Â  Even if the master erred
  in admitting Rhodaâ€™s testimony, Shirley was not prejudiced due to the
  overwhelming evidence that the family agreement existed.
III.Â Â Â  Deed of
  Distribution
Shirley
  argues the deed of distribution does not convey Fatherâ€™s one-half interest in
  the marital home to Mother.Â  We disagree.
A
  deed of distribution from a personal representative is evidence that the distributee has succeeded to the interest of the estate.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-908 (Supp. 2006).Â  A personal representative
  is also authorized to make a distribution in kind pursuant to section 62-3-907
  of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006).Â  
Fatherâ€™s
  will vested in Myles, as executor, the following powers:

  (a)Â  To
    sell, transfer and convey the whole or any part of the property, whether real
    or personal, constituting this estate or trust, at such times, in such manner,
    upon such terms and conditions, and for such price, as to the executor or
    trustee shall seem best, together with power to make, execute and deliver such
    instruments as shall be necessary to effectuate such sale or sales without an
    order of court.

Myles acted within
  his power as executor by releasing the estateâ€™s claim on the marital home in
  accordance with the family agreement through the deed of distribution.Â 
  Therefore, relying heavily on the masterâ€™s comprehensive opinion, we hold the
  equities and legal conclusions reside with Myles.
CONCLUSION
Accordingly,
  the master did not err in holding Myles the sole owner of title to the marital
  home because evidence established that a family agreement existed.Â  Further,
  the master did not err in admitting Rhodaâ€™s testimony regarding statements made
  by her deceased husband, and Myles acted within his powers as executor in
  releasing Fatherâ€™s estateâ€™s claim on the marital home.Â  Therefore, the masterâ€™s
  ruling is
AFFIRMED.
SHORT and
  WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
  

[1] S.C. Code Ann. Code Â§ 62-1-100 (Supp.
  2006).Â  Section 62-1-100(4) provides:

  [A]n act done before the effective date in any proceeding and any
    accrued right is not impaired by this Code. Â Unless otherwise provided in the
    Code, a substantive right in the decedentâ€™s estate accrues in accordance with
    the law in effect on the date of the decedentâ€™s death. Â If a right is acquired,
    extinguished, or barred upon the expiration of a prescribed period of time
    which has commenced to run by the provisions of any statute before the
    effective date, the provisions remain in force with respect to that right . . .
    .

[2] This is the presumption prevailing under North Carolina law, where the
  Osternecks had previously resided.Â  See Nesbitt v. Fairview Farms,
    Inc., 80 S.E.2d 472, 476 (N.C. 1954).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Terry Pressley, Employee/Claimant, Respondent,
        v.
        REA Construction Company, Inc., Employer,
        and
        Zurich-American Insurance Company, Insurer, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Orangeburg County
  Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court
  Judge

Opinion No. 4266
Heard April 5, 2007 â€“ Filed June 27, 2007

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND
  REMANDED


  
    
      
        Stephen L. Brown, Matthew K. Mahoney, and Jeffrey J. Wiseman, all
          of Charleston, for Appellants.
        Joe Ann Matthews Calvy, of Kingstree, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  REA
  Construction Co., Inc. and Zurich-American Insurance Co. (collectively â€œInsurerâ€)
  appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order requiring them to provide Terry Pressley with a
  wheelchair accessible mobile home and awarding Pressley compensation for ten
  hours per day of non-professional home healthcare services.Â  We affirm in part,
  reverse in part and remand.[1]
FACTS
On July 24, 2001, Pressley suffered a
  compensable injury to his spinal cord while working for REA. The injury
  rendered Pressley a paraplegic.Â  Â Insurer admitted Pressley suffered a
  compensable injury and agreed Pressley was entitled to lifetime benefits.
  Accordingly, Insurer has continuously provided appropriate medical care and
  treatment to Pressley.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
At the time of the accident, Pressley
  rented an apartment. After his injury, Pressley temporarily resided in various
  rehabilitation facilities and hospitals. In September 2002, Pressley moved in
  with his mother (Mother) where he has lived since. Initially, when Pressley
  moved in with Mother, professional caregivers attended to his needs about eight
  hours per day, five days a week. For reasons the record does not reveal,
  professional care has since diminished to four hours per day.Â  Mother takes
  care of him at all other times.Â  
At some point, to accommodate Pressleyâ€™s needs, Insurer made minor
  modifications to Motherâ€™s house. However, the modifications only allowed
  Pressley to access his bedroom; Pressley could not access any other room,
  including the kitchen or the bathroom.Â  Motherâ€™s house could be modified to
  become completely handicap accessible for a cost of approximately $68,400,[2] which, according to one estimate, is
  almost as much as the cost of a new house upfitted for wheelchair
  accessibility.Â Â  
In June
  2002, Pressley filed a Form 50 with the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission
  seeking, in relevant part, increased medical care and wheelchair accessible
  housing. After a hearing, the Single Commissioner held Pressley was entitled
  to: (1) professional home healthcare for six hours a day, seven days a week;
  (2) non-professional healthcare (from Mother or other non-professional) for ten
  hours a day, seven days a week, at $7.00 per hour; and (3) wheelchair
  accessible housing.Â  To determine the most appropriate method of providing
  wheelchair accessible housing, the single commissioner instructed Insurer to
  provide cost estimates for modifying Motherâ€™s house, providing a wheelchair
  accessible apartment, purchasing wheelchair accessible housing with ownership
  reverting to or retained by Insurer, and other appropriate options.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
On
  appeal, an appellate panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (hereafter
  Commission) affirmed the Single Commissioner. However, the Commissionâ€™s order
  included two â€œamendmentsâ€ to the Commissionerâ€™s order: â€œHousing: Carrier to
  provide handicap accessible housing-mobile home or residential care facility.Â 
  If housing is mobile home, the ownership remains with carrier.Â  Finding of Fact
  #7:Â  [Pressley] entitled to eight hours professional home health care seven
  days a week; [Pressley] entitled to additional rehabilitation training.â€ The circuit
  court affirmed the Commissionâ€™s ruling â€œin regards to wheelchair accessible
  housingâ€ and found Pressley was â€œentitled to eight hours of professional home
  healthcare as ordered by the [Commission],â€ and further held Pressley was
  â€œentitled to ten hours of non-professional care as ordered by the single
  commissioner.â€Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
â€œThe
  South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act governs judicial review of a
  decision of an administrative agency.â€Â  Clark v. Aiken County Govâ€™t, 366 S.C. 102, 107, 620 S.E.2d 99, 101 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  Section 1-23-380(A)(5) of
  the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2006) establishes the substantial evidence rule
  as the standard of review.Â  Under this standard, a reviewing court may reverse
  or modify an agency decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or
  modify an agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous.Â  See Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d) and (e).Â  
â€œOn
  appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission
  in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports the
  findings.â€Â  Peoples v. Henry Co., 364 S.C. 123, 127, 611 S.E.2d 527, 528-29 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  â€œâ€˜Substantial
  evidenceâ€™ is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly
  from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a
  whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the
  administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its
  action.â€Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306
  (1981) (citation omitted).
The
  primary rule of statutory construction is that the courts must ascertain the
  intention of the legislature. Cooper v. Moore, 351 S.C. 207, 212, 569
  S.E.2d 330, 332 (2002). The interpretation of a statute involves a question of
  law for the court. Charleston County Parks & Rec. Commâ€™n
    v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995). Thus, this court is
  free to decide matters of law with no particular deference to the trial court. Â Moriarty
    v. Garden Sanctuary Church of God, 341 S.C. 320, 327, 534 S.E.2d 672, 675
  (2000). Nevertheless, ordinarily, the construction of a statute by an agency
  charged with its administration will be accorded the most respectful deference
  and will not be overruled absent compelling reasons. Brown v. S.C. Depâ€™t of
    Health & Envtl. Control, 348 S.C. 507, 515, 560 S.E.2d 410,414 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.  Purchase of Wheelchair
  Accessible Mobile Home
Insurer
  argues the circuit court erred in affirming the Commissionâ€™s order requiring
  Insurer to purchase Pressley a wheelchair-accessible mobile home.[3]Â 
  Specifically, Insurer contends the Commission does not have the statutory
  authority under Â§ 42-15-60 of the South Carolina Code (1985) to require an
  Insurer to cover the total purchase price of a wheelchair accessible mobile
  home. Insurer contends the statute only gives the Commission authority to
  require the payment of necessary costs to make housing provided by claimant
  handicap accessible, i.e. the difference between a comparable new mobile home
  and a new modified mobile home.Â Â Â Â Â  
Section
  42-15-60 governs the Commissionâ€™s award of reasonably necessary medical costs.Â 
  Section 42-15-60 provides, in pertinent part: â€œIn cases in which total and
  permanent disability results, reasonable and necessary nursing services,
  medicines, prosthetic devices, sick travel, medical, hospital and other
    treatment or care shall be paid during the life of the injured employee,
  without regard to any limitation in this title including the
  maximum compensation limit.â€Â  (emphasis added). Thus, this appeal presents the novel issue of whether the Commission has
  the statutory authority to require an insurer to provide the base cost of
  furnishing an employee handicap accessible housing. Both parties rely on Strickland v.
    Bowater, Inc., 322 S.C. 471,
  472 S.E.2d 635 (Ct. App. 1996) as furnishing the answer to this question.
In Strickland,
  this court analyzed whether Â§ 42-15-60, in particular the provision allowing
  for â€œother treatment or care,â€ authorizes the Commission to require an Insurer
  to pay the full cost of a van modified to accommodate the handicapped
  claimant.Â  In Strickland, the employer agreed to pay the costs associated with modifying the van and
  acquiesced to the Commissionâ€™s
  order to pay the cost difference between an unmodified van and a mid-range
  automobile of the same year.Â  On appeal, the employee argued the Insurer should
  also be required to pay the â€œbase costâ€ of the modified van.Â  We held: â€œWhile the provisions of the workersâ€™ compensation law are
  entitled to a liberal construction in favor of the employee, we do not believe
  that under our present statute an employer could be required to pay for [the
  base costs of the unmodified van].â€Â  Id. at 474, 472 S.E.2d at 637.Â  
In Thompson
  v. S.C. Steel Erectors, 369
  S.C. 606, 632 S.E.2d 874 (Ct. App. 2006) (cert. pending), we examined whether
  the Commission erred in denying an employeeâ€™s request for funds to upfit his
  new home to accommodate his special needs.Â  In Thompson, the Commission
  ordered employer to advance the employee a lump sum to purchase a new home;
  however, the Commission did not require the employer to pay the costs for
  modifying the employeeâ€™s new home.Â  Id. at 610-11, 632 S.E.2d at 877.Â  Both
  parties appealed.Â  This court affirmed the partial-lump sum award[4] and held the employer must also pay to upfit the employeeâ€™s home
  because â€œ[t]he modifications are necessitated solely by [employeeâ€™s] admittedly
  compensable injury.â€Â  Id. at 619, 632 S.E.2d at 882.Â  Thus, the employer
  was required to both advance sums to purchase the employeeâ€™s new home, and pay
  the cost to modify it.Â  
While Strickland and Thompson offer guidance as to the appropriate
  interpretation of Â§42-15-60, neither case controls our analysis in the present
  appeal.Â  In Strickland, the employer agreed to pay certain costs
  directly connected to employeeâ€™s handicapped condition (the costs of
  modification and increased price of van over average mid-size car).Â  As such, Strickland only stands for the proposition that
  the Commission has authority to require an employer to pay for that portion of
  the base cost an employeeâ€™s unmodified van that exceeds the price of an average
  mid-sized car.Â  Similarly, in Thompson,
  the employer only argued the partial-lump sum advance for the new house, i.e.
  the â€œbase cost,â€ violated section 42-9-10 of the South Carolina Code (Supp.
  2005); the employer did not contend the Commission lacked the authority to make
  such an award.Â  Id. at 614-15, 632 S.E.2d at 879.Â  Accordingly, Thompson fails to articulate whether Â§ 42-15-60 allows the Commission to require the
  employer to pay the â€œbase costâ€ of the employeeâ€™s new home.Â  
Inasmuch
  as our Workerâ€™s Compensation Act is modeled after the North Carolina Act, we
  naturally look to North Carolinaâ€™sÂ  decisions in interpreting similar
  provisions. As stated in Strickland, the North Carolina Supreme Court
  held in Derebery v. Pitt County Fire Marshall, 318 N.C. 192, 347 S.E.2d
  814 (1986) that â€œother treatment or careâ€ as contained in its statute required
  an employer to provide an employee with wheelchair-accessible housing. However,
  we note that in the subsequent North Carolina Court of Appeals case ofÂ  Timmons
    v. N. C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 123 N.C. App. 456, 462-63, 473 S.E. 2d 356, 360
  (Ct. App. 1996), that court found that the employer did not have to absorb the
  entire cost of constructing the claimantâ€™s new residence.Â  The court reasoned:Â  

  We
    do not agree with [claimant], however that Derebery requires [employer]
    to pay the entire cost of constructing his residence. As pointed out by Justice
    (later Chief Justice) Billings in her dissent in Derebery, the expense
    of housing is an ordinary necessity of life, to be paid from the statutory
    substitute for wages provided by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act. The costs of
    modifying such housing, however, to accommodate one with extraordinary needs
    occasioned by a workplace injury, such as the [claimant] in this case, is not
    an ordinary expense of life for which the statutory substitute wage is intended
    as compensation. 

Id. at 461-62, 473 S.E.2d at 359 (affirmed by Timmons v. N.C. Depâ€™t
  of Transp., 346 N.C. 173, 484 S.E.2d 551 (1997)).
We are in
  agreement with what appears to be the law of North Carolina that the base cost
  of providing an injured employee housing is an ordinary necessity of life which
  the statutory substitute for wages should be utilized by the employee to
  obtain.Â  We, therefore, reverse the circuit courtâ€™s order to the extent it
  holds that section 42-15-60 permits the Commission to order an employer to pay
  the base cost of handicap accessible housing.
At
  oral argument, it developed that although the employer is willing to provide
  care for Pressley in a residential care facility, Pressley has refused the same.Â 
  On the other hand, although Pressley appealed to the circuit court the
  Commissionâ€™s failure to â€œenter specific findings as to its basis/rationale for
  determining that [employer] is only required to provide [him] handicap
  accessible housing-mobile home or residential care facility,â€ he has not
  appealed the failure of the trial court to address that issue.Â  Moreover, the
  Commission adopted â€œin totoâ€ the findings of fact of the Single Commissioner
  which required Insurer to provide a factual basis to enable it to determine
  what type of handicap accessible housing would be appropriate for Pressley.Â  This
  has never been done, and the Commission did not have this information before it
  when it made its decision.Â  The posture of the case is further complicated by
  the failure of the Commission and trial court to specify whether Insurer or
  Pressley has the option to choose which of the two types of housing enumerated
  in the Commissionâ€™s order the Insurer must provide.
Under
  the unique facts of this case, it appears that under both 
      Strickland and Thompson, the Commission could have ordered the
  Insurer to absorb the cost to modify Pressleyâ€™s motherâ€™s house. Moreover, the
  record indicates that the cost to modify the motherâ€™s house totals between
  $68,400[5] and $70,000.[6]Â  According to the trial court, the apparent reason for the Commission
  not ordering that option was its economic infeasibility.Â  Under the confused
  posture of this case, justice demands we remand to the Commission to determine
  what wheelchair accessible housing is appropriate in light of our decision that
  the statute does not permit the Commission to require the employer to pay the
  base cost of a wheelchair accessible mobile home.Â Â  
II. Non-Professional Care
Insurer
  argues the circuit court erred in finding Pressley was entitled to receive ten
  hours per day of non-professional home healthcare.Â  We agree.
Section
  42-15-60 also controls our analysis of this issue.Â  Pursuant to section
  42-15-60, an injured employee is entitled to receive â€œreasonable and necessary
  nursing services.â€ 
The
  Single Commissioner, under findings of fact #7 held:

  [Pressley] is entitled to
    professional home health care for 6 hours a day, 7 days a week.Â  [Pressley]â€™s mother or other non-professional should be paid $7.00
    an hour for 10 hours a day, 7 days a week.Â  This is a total of 16 hours of
    health care [sic] and/or assistance per day.Â  

The
  Commissionâ€™s order also contained an amendment which read: â€œFinding of Fact #7:Â  [Pressley] entitled
  to eight hours professional home health careÂ  seven days a week; [Pressley]
  entitled to additional rehabilitation training.â€Â  The circuit court held
  Pressley was entitled to eight hours professional home healthcare as ordered by
  the Commission and ten hours non-professional care as ordered by the Single Commissioner.Â 
  The circuit court also remanded the case to the Commission to determine the
  appropriate compensation rate for non-professional healthcare providers.Â Â  
Insurer contends the Commissionâ€™s order implicitly
  reversed the Single Commissionerâ€™s order in regards to non-professional care. Â We
  agree.Â  The Commissionâ€™s order amends finding of fact # 7 to award 8 hours of
  professional care and eliminates any requirement to pay for non-professional
  care.Â  Pressley appealed the Commissionâ€™s failure to provide for non-professional
  care to the circuit court, which awarded 10 hours of non-professional care
  daily. 
Before
  the Single Commissioner, Pressley testified he needs assistance throughout most
  of the day and, at times, when he wakes in the middle of the night. Â Pressley
  also testified he believes he needs help twenty-four hours a day.Â  Further, a
  doctorâ€™s evaluation provides that while Pressley is able to perform some
  self-care functions he â€œwill always need a caregiver to assist him with all the
  activities of daily living.â€ On the other hand, Dr. Adora Matthews of Palmetto
  Rehabilitation Medicine stated that â€œPressley will benefit from some care in
  the home, probably up to 8 hours per day.â€ 
Although
  there is evidence that some non-professional care is needed, there is no basis
  for the finding of the circuit court awarding 10 hours of non-professional
  care.[7]Â 
  After a thorough review of the record, we hold substantial evidence supports
  the finding of the Commission regarding the professional care needed by
  Pressley, but not a finding that Pressley does not need any non-professional
  home care.Â  Moreover, while the circuit court could have found the evidence
  mandated remand to the Commission for a determination of the appropriate hours
  of non- professional care, the court was not free to establish the hours at ten
  hours per day.Â  We therefore remand to the Commission the issues of the
  appropriate number of non-professional hours of care Pressley is entitled to
  and the establishment of the rate to be paid for that care. 
CONCLUSION
We
  find the circuit court erred in concluding the Insurer was required to provide
  Pressley with a handicap accessible mobile home.Â  Additionally, the court erred
  in ordering employer to pay for ten hours per day of non-professional care.Â  We
  therefore remand this case to the Commission to determine the appropriate
  handicap accessible housing for Pressley, the appropriate number of hours of
  non-professional care he may be entitled to receive, and the rate at which the
  care is to be paid.Â  On both issues, the Commission shall with specificity set
  forth the basis for its decision in accordance with Shealy v. Aiken County,
  341 S.C. 448, 535 S.E.2d 438 (2000) and Baldwin v. James River Corp.,
  304 S.C. 485, 405 S.E.2d 421 (Ct. App. 1991).Â  Accordingly, the order of the
  circuit court is 
AFFIRMED
  IN PART, REVERSED IN PART AND REMANDED.Â Â Â  
BEATTY
  and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
  

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] Pressley testified it would cost $70,000 to upfit his
  motherâ€™s home, while a contractor submitted an estimate for $68,400 to make the
  home wheelchair accessible.
[3] We note the Commissionâ€™s order appears to provide
  that the purchase of the mobile home is one option Insurer may undertake and
  does not specifically require Insurer to purchase the mobile home. Â Â Â Â 
[4] This lump-sum was to be deducted from the employeeâ€™s
  life time benefits.
[5] As stated by a builder.
[6] As testified to by Pressley.
[7] In this regard, the Commission, not the circuit court
  is the fact finder as to how much non-professional care Pressley is entitled
  to.

title: State v. Davis
description: Terry Bernard Davis appeals his conviction for voluntary manslaughter.  Davis argues that the trial judge erred in declining to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Terry Bernard Davis, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  4267
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed June 28, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of
				
				Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Edgar Lewis Clements, III, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	

GOOLSBY, J.: Â Terry Bernard Davis (â€œDavisâ€) appeals his conviction for voluntary manslaughter.Â  Davis argues that the trial judge erred in declining to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
 Davis, along with his cousin Robert Britton, lived in the home of his brother, Christopher Davis (â€œChristopherâ€).Â  Davis, a crack cocaine user, allowed Kevin Harrison and Shontae Broaddus to sell crack cocaine out of Christopherâ€™s home in exchange for some of their crack cocaine.[2]Â  Davis also acted as a sort of middleman for Harrison and Broaddus, bringing customers to the dealers in exchange for a portion of the crack cocaine being sold.Â  Davis allowed Bridgette Martin, a fellow crack cocaine user, to live in the home. [3] 

Before leaving for work on the morning of October 1, 2003, Christopher told Davis that Harrison and Broaddus could no longer stay in the house and that Davis would have to ask them to leave.Â  Broaddus overheard Christopherâ€™s request and, realizing he was no longer welcome, decided to leave.Â  Broaddus commented to Harrison that he should leave too; however, Harrison ignored him and returned to a recliner he had been sleeping in earlier.
Davis, in a statement to the police, claimed he asked Harrison to leave the residence.Â  By this time, Christopher, Broaddus, and Britton had already left the house.Â  Harrison supposedly pulled out his handgun, put it to Davisâ€™s head, and told Davis to leave him alone.Â  Harrison reportedly said he had given Davis enough crack cocaine to entitle him to remain in the home until 10 a.m.Â  Davis returned shortly thereafter with Brittonâ€™s five-pound sledgehammer, wrapped a towel around the head of it, and hit Harrison twice in the head with it.Â  Harrison was seated in the recliner when Davis struck him with the sledgehammer.Â  The first blow supposedly stunned Harrison, but Davis claimed he needed to hit Harrison again to prevent Harrison from using his gun.Â  Davis then enlisted Martinâ€™s help, the only other person in the house at that time, and the two of them dragged Harrisonâ€™s body outside.Â  Davis repeated this version of events to Christopher and Britton, although in Brittonâ€™s version Davis claimed he only intended to knock Harrison out and remove him from the home.
Martin testified she did not hear Davis and Harrison argue that day.Â  Before Harrison was killed, Davis told her, â€œIâ€™m gone [sic] kill that b***h.â€Â  Martin initially ignored the statement, but Davis returned later and said, while dragging Harrisonâ€™s body past the bedroom door, that he â€œkill[ed] that b***h.â€Â  Davis was holding a sledgehammer with the hammer part wrapped in a towel as he dragged Harrisonâ€™s body.Â  Martin testified Davis had threatened other dealers in the past, often with a variation of the phrase â€œ[I will] [k]ill you and smoke your s**t like a chimneyâ€; however, the threats were never taken seriously.Â  Martin admitted she smoked crack cocaine and consumed alcohol on the morning that Harrison was killed.
 Davis traded Harrisonâ€™s gun and cell phone for $40 in crack cocaine.Â  Martin also claims that Davis took Harrisonâ€™s supply of crack cocaine and offered to share with her.Â  A neighbor discovered Harrisonâ€™s body, wrapped in a carpet, situated between his yard and Christopher Davisâ€™s property.
An autopsy of Harrison revealed an injury to his skull, caused by a significant blow to the side of Harrisonâ€™s head, which produced a fracture at the base of Harrisonâ€™s skull from ear to ear.Â  The forensic pathologist who conducted the autopsy, Dr. Janice Ross, opined that Harrisonâ€™s injury was consistent with one or two blows from a sledgehammer that he received while seated.Â  Her examination of Harrison did not reveal any defensive wounds.[4]
 Davis was indicted for murder.Â  Davisâ€™s counsel requested jury instructions on involuntary manslaughter and self-defense.Â  The State objected to the involuntary manslaughter charge and the trial court declined to charge the jury on involuntary manslaughter.Â  The jury found Davis guilty of voluntary manslaughter, and the trial court sentenced him to thirty years imprisonment.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.â€[5]Â  â€œTo warrant reversal, a trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested jury charge must be both erroneous and prejudicial to the defendant.â€[6]Â  â€œDue process requires that a lesser included offense be charged when the evidence warrants it but only if the evidence would permit a jury rationally to find the defendant guilty of the lesser offense.â€[7]
LAW/ANALYSIS
Davis argues the trial judge erred by declining to instruct the jury on the lesser included offense of involuntary manslaughter.
Involuntary manslaughter is defined as â€œthe killing of another without malice and unintentionally while engaged in either: (1) an unlawful act not amounting to a felony and not naturally tending to cause death or great bodily harm; or (2) a lawful act with reckless disregard for the safety of others.â€[8]Â  â€œTo constitute involuntary manslaughter, there must be a finding of criminal negligence, statutorily defined as a reckless disregard of the safety of others.â€[9]
Davis relies on State v. Chatman for the proposition that an intentional act causing death does not necessarily preclude involuntary manslaughter.[10]Â  We believe Chatman is distinguishable from the case at hand.Â  Chatman was engaged in an assault and battery with the victim, during which Chatman, while facing the victim, pressed his shoulder into the victimâ€™s neck.[11] Â Although Chatman released the victim shortly thereafter, the victim â€œdied as a result of asphyxiation due to manual strangulation.â€[12]Â  Chatmanâ€™s actions did not fit the typical strangulation type situation because he did not place his hands around the victimâ€™s neck.[13]Â  As a result, the court concluded Chatman was entitled to a charge on involuntary manslaughter because his actions were not the kind that would naturally tend to cause serious bodily injury or death.[14]Â  We think the facts in this case do not fit the first definition of involuntary manslaughter, as the court used in deciding Chatman, because striking someone on the side of the head with a five-pound sledgehammer would naturally tend to cause death or great bodily injury.[15]
Davis also argues the facts of this case fit the second definition of involuntary manslaughter.Â  He contends he acted lawfully by arming himself in self-defense to drive out an armed trespasser.Â  Davis fails to meet the second definition of involuntary manslaughter because there is no evidence he handled the sledgehammer with reckless disregard for the safety of others.Â  The evidence firmly establishes that Davis intentionally struck Harrison on the head with the sledgehammer. [16] 
Based on the above, we hold the trial court did not commit error in denying Davisâ€™s request for a jury charge on involuntary manslaughter.

    AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and STILWELL, J., concur.

[1] Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Harrison is also referred to by his alias â€œLittle Kâ€ throughout the record.
[3]Â  Martin testified she only stayed at the home during the daytime.
[4]Â  Dr. Ross testified that defensive wounds are wounds incurred by the victim while trying to defend from an attacker.Â  These injuries are usually in the form of bruises or lacerations on the outside of the arms or hands.
[5]Â  State v. Patterson, 367 S.C. 219, 231, 625 S.E.2d 239, 245 (Ct. App. 2006).
[6]Â  Id. at 232, 625 S.E.2d at 245 (Ct. App. 2006).
[7]Â  State v. Small, 307 S.C. 92, 94, 413 S.E.2d 870, 871 (Ct. App. 1992).
[8]Â  State v. Reese, 370 S.C. 31, 36, 633 S.E.2d 898, 900 (2006).
[9]Â  State v. Crosby, 355 S.C. 47, 52, 584 S.E.2d 110, 112 (2003).
[10]Â  State v. Chatman, 336 S.C. 149, 519 S.E.2d 100 (1999).
[11]Â  Id. at 152-53, 519 S.E.2d at 101-02.
[12]Â  Id. at 152, 519 S.E.2d at 101.
[13]Â  Id. at 153, 519 S.E.2d at 101-02.
[14]Â  Id. at 152-53, 519 S.E.2d at 101-02.
[15]Â  We note that Davis may have wrapped the head of the sledgehammer in a towel.Â  There is no evidence, however, that this lessened the tendency of a five-pound sledgehammer to cause death or great bodily injury if used to strike someone in the head.Â  See State v. Bennett, 328 S.C. 251, 262, 493 S.E.2d 845, 850-51 (1997) (â€œA deadly weapon is generally defined as any article, instrument or substance which is likely to produce death or great bodily harm.â€); Commonwealth v. Marks, 704 A.2d 1095, 1100 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1997) (categorizing a sledgehammer as a deadly weapon when used upon a vital part of the body such as the head).
[16]Â  See State v. Smith, 315 S.C. 547, 550, 446 S.E.2d 411, 413 (1994) (holding â€œthe intentional use of a dangerous instrumentality does not support the allegation of mere criminal negligence.â€); State v. Morris, 307 S.C. 480, 484, 415 S.E.2d 819, 821-22 (Ct. App. 1991) (holding the defendant was not entitled to a charge of involuntary manslaughter where there was no evidence that he involuntarily pulled his gun and shot the victim, noting the act must be unintentional to constitute criminal negligence); State v. Craig, 267 S.C. 262, 269, 227 S.E.2d 306, 310 (1976) (finding involuntary manslaughter charge not warranted by the evidence where the defendant intentionally fired his shotgun but claimed he meant to shoot over the victimâ€™s head); Bozeman v. State, 307 S.C. 172, 177, 414 S.E.2d 144, 147 (1992) (finding no evidence to support an allegation of mere criminal negligence in the use of a dangerous instrumentality because the defendant intentionally fired his weapon); State v. Light, 363 S.C. 325, 331 n.1, 610 S.E.2d 504, 507 n.1 (Ct. App. 2005) (noting that evidence tending to show the intentional use of a weapon would not support an involuntary manslaughter charge).
