title: Shelton v. LS&K, Inc.
description: Shleton appeals the trial court's granting of summary judgment to LS&K, Inc., and its denial of Shelton's motion to reconsider.  We affirm.
text:
Shelton v. LS&K


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Annabelle Shelton, Appellant,
				v.
				LS&K, Inc., Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4268
Submitted April 2, 2007 â€“ Filed June 28, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Rodney M. Brown, of Fountain Inn, for Appellant.
				Phillip E. Reeves, of Greenville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  Annabelle Shelton appeals the trial courtâ€™s granting of summary judgment to LS&K, Inc., and its denial of Sheltonâ€™s motion to reconsider.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
This case arises out of an accident that occurred on May 7, 2004 in front of a Burger King franchise owned and operated by respondent LS&K.Â  The accident occurred when Jo Ann Suttles was exiting the parking lot to turn onto North Main Street in Fountain Inn, South Carolina.Â  The driveway exit crossed a pedestrian sidewalk to reach the street.
Immediately prior to the accident, Suttles approached the parking lot exit and stopped her vehicle to wait for traffic to pass before making a right turn.Â  Unbeknownst to Suttles, Annabelle Shelton was walking along the sidewalk to the right of Suttlesâ€™ car.Â  When the traffic cleared, Suttles started her right-turn and struck Shelton as she crossed the driveway on the sidewalk.Â 
 
Shelton sustained a head injury and has no recollection of how the accident occurred.Â  Officer R. E. Inman saw the accident as Shelton was struck by the car, but did not see any of the preceding events.Â  There were no other witnesses.
The dispute in this case centers on a Bradford Pear tree which was located to Suttlesâ€™ right as she exited the parking lot onto North Main.Â  Suttles testified that she frequently visited the Burger King and was familiar with the parking lot and the location of the pear tree.Â  Shelton maintains that the tree obscured Suttlesâ€™ view of Shelton walking on the sidewalk. Â Shelton alleged that LS&K was negligent in failing to maintain its premises so that drivers exiting the parking lot had a clear view of pedestrians on the sidewalk.
Shelton filed her amended complaint in September of 2004, alleging that LS&K was negligent in the design of its landscaping and parking lot and causing and/or contributing to the accident.Â  After discovery, LS&K moved for summary judgment, arguing no genuine issue of material fact existed as to the elements of negligence.Â  The trial court granted its motion, finding Shelton did not provide evidence that LS&K breached any duty of care owed to her, and that she did not provide evidence of proximate cause.Â  The trial court concluded Shelton failed to establish a prima facie case of negligence against LS&K, because she offered no expert testimony to establish the appropriate standard of care.Â  This appeal followed. 
 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Appellate courts review a grant of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the circuit court pursuant to Rule 56, SCRCP.Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield of S.C., Inc., 349 S.C. 356, 361, 563 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002).Â  â€œSummary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue of material fact and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Id.Â Â  When reviewing the record, the evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn therefrom are viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Id. 361-62.Â  The existence of a mere scintilla of evidence in support of the nonmoving partyâ€™s position is not sufficient to overcome a motion for summary judgment.Â  Bravis v. Dunbar, 316 S.C. 263, 265, 449 S.E.2d 495, 496 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  The party seeking summary judgment has the burden of establishing the absence of a genuine issue of material fact.Â  McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 341, 499 S.E.2d 488, 493 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  With respect to an issue upon which the nonmoving party bears the burden of proof, this initial responsibility may be discharged by showing the trial court there is an absence of evidence to support the nonmoving partyâ€™s case.Â  Id.
LAW/ANALYSIS

I.  Breached Duty of Care
Shelton first argues the court misapprehended her negligence claim as an allegation of negligent design, and therefore improperly ruled against her based upon lack of expert testimony.Â  We disagree.
The trial court held there was no evidence to establish that LS&K breached any duty of care owed to the plaintiff because it found that negligence in the design and construction, as a matter of professional negligence, requires qualified expert testimony to establish both the standard of care for design and construction of the parking lot, and LS&Kâ€™s deviation therefrom.Â  Notably, Shelton conceded before the circuit court that the design of a parking lot is a matter not within the expertise of a layperson.Â  Thus, because Â Sheltonâ€™s only expert had no opinion relating to the design of the parking lot or any other standard of care, the court concluded that Shelton presented no evidence of a breached duty of care.
On appeal, Shelton argues that it was never her position that the parking lot was designed improperly.Â  However, Sheltonâ€™s complaint and arguments at trial are at odds with this contention.Â  Sheltonâ€™s amended complaint alleges that LS&K was negligent in â€œ[p]lacing inappropriate trees, shrubbery and landscaping around the driveway,â€ and in â€œ[f]ailing to appropriately delineate where the sidewalk was with any sort of lineage.â€Â  Also, at the summary judgment hearing, Shelton argued to the trial court: â€œThey designed the lot.Â  They designed where the exit was.Â  They designed where the tree was planted and they planted it.â€Â  We find that these allegations and arguments did indeed contemplate a claim of negligence in the design. Â â€œIt is well settled that one cannot present and try [her] case on one theory and then change [her] theory on appeal.â€Â  Gurganious v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 488, 454 S.E.2d 912, 916 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  
 
Moreover, even if this was not a design defect case, we would affirm the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment. Â In deciding whether a defendant acted negligently, â€œ[t]he court must determine, as a matter of law, whether the defendant owed the plaintiff a particular duty.Â  If there is no duty, then the defendant in a negligence action is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€Â  Underwood v. Coponen, 367 S.C. 214, 217, 625 S.E.2d 236, 238 (Ct. App. 2006). Â Here, Shelton failed to supply any evidence, expert or otherwise, regarding the proper placement and maintenance of trees in a commercial parking lot.Â  Thus, based on the evidence presented, the visual obstruction caused by the tree was no different than an obstruction caused by a building or anything else encountered in daily life.Â  We find that without any basis on which a jury might differentiate between those visual obstructions which are permissible and those which are not, a jury would have to engage in pure conjecture and speculation in deciding how LS&K should have designed or maintained its parking lot. [1]
Underwood v. Coponen is factually a very similar case.Â  In Underwood, the trial court granted summary judgment in favor of a defendant landowner whose tree obstructed a stop sign, thereby causing a motorist to be involved in a collision.Â  367 S.C. 214, 625 S.E.2d 236 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  The court of appeals affirmed summary judgment because Underwood failed to establish a legal duty on the part of the landowner to prevent his tree from causing such obstruction.Â  Likewise, Shelton does not establish a legal duty on the part of LS&K to prevent the obstruction caused by the Bradford pear tree in this case.
Further, Sheltonâ€™s own expert testified that Suttles had an unobstructed view twenty-five feet down the sidewalk to her right before she struck Shelton and that Shelton had an unobstructed view of the front of Suttlesâ€™ vehicle from forty-five feet away.Â  Shelton provided no evidence of how far a pedestrian and a driver should have been afforded unobstructed views at the parking lot exit, and she provided no evidence that these views were insufficient. Â See Williams v. Lancaster County School Dist., 369 S.C. 293, 307, 631 S.E.2d 286, 294 (Ct. App. 2006) (summary judgment upheld because of claimantâ€™s â€œinability to establish evidence to support the elements required under the claimâ€). 
 
Finally, landowners generally do not owe a duty to warn others of an open and obvious condition on the property.Â  See Denton v. Winn Dixie Greenville, Inc., 312 S.C. 119, 121, 439 S.E.2d 292, 294 (Ct. App. 1993) (affirming summary judgment in a negligence action where customer tripped over a shopping cart corral in a parking lot, reasoning corrals are common structures that a person taking reasonable care for her own safety would likely expect and see while on the premises).Â  Absent any evidence that LS&K created an unreasonably dangerous condition, there is no genuine issue of material fact and summary judgment is appropriate.Â  Garvin v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 343 S.C. 625, 629, 541 S.E.2d 831, 833 (2001).Â Â  Because Shelton has failed to provide any evidence to establish how the presence of the tree was unreasonable, she failed to meet her burden of proof.Â  Therefore, we find no error by the trial court in granting summary judgment.
II.  Proximate Cause
Second, Shelton argues that the court improperly ruled against her based on lack of evidence of proximate cause.Â  Because we affirm summary judgment based on the duty of care and breach elements, we do not reach Sheltonâ€™s second argument. 
 
CONCLUSION
Based on the undisputed facts of this case, viewed in the light most favorable to Shelton, we find that Shelton failed to present evidence of a duty on the part of LS&K, or that such a duty was breached. Based on the foregoing, the order of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.

[1] South Carolina does recognize a duty of reasonable care on the part of urban landowners to inspect trees on their property and make sure they are safe.Â  Underwood v. Coponen, 367 S.C. 214, 217, 625 S.E.2d 236, 238 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  But this duty extends only to ensuring that a tree is not â€œunsound or defective.â€Â  Israel v. Carolina Bar-B-Que, 292 S.C. 282, 288-90, 356 S.E.2d 123, 127-28 (Ct. App. 1987) (holding an urban landowner liable for damage caused by a fallen limb because there was evidence that the owner saw or could have seen upon reasonable inspection that the tree was partially decayed).Â  Because the only alleged defect of the tree was that it obscured Suttlesâ€™ vision at some point before she reached the sidewalk, the Israel rule does not apply to these facts.Â  Underwood v. Coponen, 367 S.C. 214, 218, 625 S.E.2d 236, 238 (Ct. App. 2006).

title: Wilson v. SCB&CB Employee Insurance Program
description: The State Budget and Control Board Emmployee Insurance Program appeals the circuit court's award of long term disability benefits to Wilson.  The Insurance Program argues the circuit court exceeded its scope of review when it reversed the Long Term Disability Appeals Committee's denial of Wilson's claim.  We agree and reverse.
text:
Wilson v. SCB&CB


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Linda McPhail Wilson, Respondent,
				v.
				State Budget and Control Board Employee Insurance Program, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Florence County
Â B. Hicks Harwell, Jr., Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4269
Hearn June 5, 2007 â€“ Filed June 29, 2007Â Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Michael T. Brittingham and James T. Hedgepath, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				G. Conrad Derrick, of Florence, Â for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  The State Budget and Control Board Employee Insurance Program (the Insurance Program) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s award of long term disability benefits to Linda McPhail Wilson.Â Â  The Insurance Program argues the circuit court exceeded its scope of review when it reversed the Long Term Disability Appeals Committeeâ€™s denial of Wilsonâ€™s claim.Â  We agree and reverse.
FACTS
Wilson, a â€œjob developerâ€ for the Darlington County Disabilities and Special Needs Board, applied for long term disability benefits after she was involved in an automobile accident on April 28, 2001.Â  She sought disability benefits due to an alleged injury to her lower back and knee.
Initially, Wilsonâ€™s claim was reviewed by Standard Insurance Company (Standard), the third-party claims administrator for her long term disability plan.Â  Standard denied the claim, and Wilson requested a review of the denial.Â  For the review, Wilson submitted additional medical records, but again, Standard denied her claim. Â After receiving this second denial, Wilson sought an independent review from Standardâ€™s Quality Assurance Unit, which also denied Wilsonâ€™s claim. After this denial, Wilson pursued an appeal to the Employee Insurance Programâ€™s Long Term Disability Appeals Committee (Appeals Committee).Â  This three-member committee conducted a de novo review of Wilsonâ€™s Long Term Disability Insurance Plan (the Insurance Plan) and Wilsonâ€™s medical records.Â  
 
According to the Insurance Plan, employees are considered disabled if an injury renders them unable to perform â€œwith reasonable continuity the Material Duties of [their] Own Occupation.â€Â  The Insurance Plan further explains:

	Own Occupation means any employment, business, trade, profession, calling or vocation that involves Material Duties of the same general character as your regular and ordinary employment with the Employer.Â  Your Own Occupation is not limited to your job with your Employer.

According to the generic description of a â€œJob Developer,â€ the position involves standing, walking, sitting, lifting, carrying, pushing, pulling, climbing, stooping, kneeling, crouching, crawling, and reaching, among other less strenuous activities.Â  However, Wilsonâ€™s supervisor, Christopher Woods, stated that Wilsonâ€™s job merely required frequent driving, walking, and standing with no lifting.Â  Furthermore, Karol Paquette, Wilsonâ€™s vocational case manager, reported that the physical requirements of Wilsonâ€™s job did not require crawling, kneeling, crouching, or climbing.Â  Paquette opined that Wilsonâ€™s job might fall in the â€œsedentary to light range of strength.â€Â  
 
In addition to this evidence regarding Wilsonâ€™s â€œOwn Occupation,â€ the Appeals Committee also reviewed a long transcript of medical records from five different physicians: Dr. Hyler, Wilsonâ€™s family doctor; Dr. Faulstich, Wilsonâ€™s radiologist; Dr. Healy, a neurologist; Dr. Beeson, a board-certified internist; and Dr. DeMichele, a neurologist.
Dr. Hyler noted that Wilson experienced â€œspasms and pain in [her] lower back,â€ and he recommended she stop working after the accident. Â He referred Wilson to a neurologist.Â  As of July 5, 2001, Dr. Hyler opined she could likely return to work in three months.Â 
 
On June 6, 2001, Dr. Faulstich performed an MRI of Wilsonâ€™s spine and found no abnormalities.Â  The record before the Appeals Committee also contained an X-Ray of Wilsonâ€™s spine taken the day of her accident.Â  This X-Ray did not reveal any abnormalities either.
 
Dr. Healy, the neurologist to whom Dr. Hyler referred Wilson, also reviewed the June 6, 2001 MRI and found it â€œunremarkable.â€Â  He suggested Wilson pursue physical therapy to alleviate her pain.Â 
 
Dr. Beeson reviewed Wilsonâ€™s medical records at the behest of Standard, the third-party insurer.Â  In August of 2002, he found that based on the information from Wilsonâ€™s treating physicians, Wilson could â€œcontinue to work in a sedentary or light occupation such as that of a job development specialist.â€Â  
 
In October of 2002, Wilson consulted Dr. DeMichele, who ordered a bone scan of Wilsonâ€™s entire body.Â  The bone scan showed signs of arthritis in Wilsonâ€™s back.Â  Dr. DeMichele also had Wilson participate in a lower body nerve conduction study.Â  The results showed evidence of nerve damage in Wilsonâ€™s left leg.Â  Â Â 
After visiting with Dr. DeMichele, Wilson submitted the results of her bone scan and nerve conduction study to Dr. Beeson.Â  Even in light of this additional information, Dr. Beeson was of the opinion that Wilson could perform a light work occupation.Â 
 
Before the Appeals Committee made its determination, Wilson submitted a February 18, 2003 note from Dr. DeMichele, which stated Wilson was â€œtotally and permanently disabled.â€Â  Wilson also submitted notes from her March 19, 2003 visit with Dr. DeMichele, which stated, â€œIf they could read, they would see a nerve conduction study . . . which shows diffuse polyneuropathy in [Wilsonâ€™s] lower extremity.â€Â  The notes also opined that Wilson had osteoarthritis and other problems in her lower back.Â 
 
With these facts before it, the Appeals Committee unanimously denied Wilsonâ€™s claim, finding â€œinsufficient medical documentation to support limitations or restrictions that continued through the end of the [Planâ€™s 90-day Benefit Waiting Period].â€Â  The Appeals Committee also found Wilsonâ€™s occupation involved â€œsedentary-light workâ€ and that she was capable of performing the duties required of her.Â  
 
After receiving this decision from the Appeals Committee, Wilson submitted documentation establishing that she had been approved to receive Social Security Disability.Â  The Appeals Committee reconsidered the case in light of the finding of disability by the Social Security Administration, but reaffirmed its denial of Wilsonâ€™s claim.Â  The Appeals Committee noted that it was bound by the Long Term Disability Income Benefit Plan, and the information provided regarding Social Security benefits did not alter the Committeeâ€™s original decision that Wilson did not meet the Planâ€™s definition of disabled.Â  
 
Wilson appealed this decision to the circuit court.Â  After hearing oral argument from counsel, the circuit court suggested an independent medical examination be conducted by Dr. Donald Johnson, a surgeon at the Southeastern Spine Institute.Â  Both parties consented, and Dr. Johnson examined Wilson and her medical records.Â  Based on his examination, Dr. Johnson opined:Â  â€œBased on the medical records, particularly the objective information that I have seen, I would expect that this patient should be able to return to sedentary/light work.â€Â  
 
Despite Dr. Johnsonâ€™s independent medical examination, the circuit court found the decision of the Appeals Committee was arbitrary, capricious, and clearly erroneous in light of the substantial evidence in the record.Â  Specifically, the circuit court found the Appeals Committee erred in relying on the opinion of Dr. Beeson, a non-treating internist, rather than on the opinions of her treating physicians, particularly that of Dr. Hyler and Dr. DeMichele.Â  Pursuant to its holding, the circuit court awarded Wilson $36,800 in retroactive benefits and continuing benefits as allowed under the Long Term Disability policy.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
Pursuant to section 1-23-380(6) of the South Carolina Code (2005), when the circuit court reviews the final decision of an agency, â€œ[t]he court shall not substitute its judgment for that of the agency as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.â€Â  Rather, the decision of the agency should be affirmed unless it is clearly erroneous in light of the substantial evidence in the record, is arbitrary or capricious, or is affected by other error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(6) (2005).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Insurance Program argues the circuit court erred in finding the denial of benefits to Wilson was not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We agree.
Although Wilson presented evidence to the Appeals Committee supporting her disability claim, the Committee also had before it substantial evidence to the contrary.Â  The X-Ray of Wilsonâ€™s spine taken immediately after the accident showed no abnormalities, and both Dr. Faulstich and Dr. Healy found no abnormalities in the MRI performed on Wilsonâ€™s lumbar spine in June of 2001.Â  Based on a review of Wilsonâ€™s medical records, Dr. Beeson unequivocally found Wilson was not disabled.Â  Furthermore, substantial evidence in the record supported the finding that Wilsonâ€™s job required light to sedentary work.Â  Thus, even though the bone scan showed that Wilson suffered from osteoarthritis, substantial evidence did not demonstrate why such a condition would prevent her from performing light duties.Â  Notably, both parties consented to allowing Dr. Johnson to perform an independent medical examination of Wilson for the circuit courtâ€™s benefit.Â  Dr. Johnsonâ€™s opinion reaffirmed the opinion of the Appeals Committee that Wilson was capable of performing light work.Â 
 
While we recognize that Dr. DeMichele and the Social Security Administration found otherwise, we remain cognizant that as an appellate court, we must affirm an agencyâ€™s decision when substantial evidence supports the decision.Â  See Converse Power Corp. v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health and Envtl. Control, 350 S.C. 39, 46, 564 S.E.2d 341, 345 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œUnder our standard of review, we may not substitute our judgment for that of an agency unless the agencyâ€™s findings are clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence in the whole record.â€).Â  Accordingly, based on the substantial evidence refuting Wilsonâ€™s disability claims, the circuit courtâ€™s award of benefits is
REVERSED.
KITTREDGE, J., and CURETON, A.J., concur.

title: State v. Ward
description: Ward appeals his murder conviction, arguing the trial court erred by (1) refusing to grant a mistrial after the State insinuated the crime revolved around gang activity, (2) permitting autopsy photos to be admitted, (3) charging the jury that "the hand of one is the hand of all," (4) refusing to grant a directed verdict in Ward's favor, and (5) allowing the State to play a recording of a co-defendant's testimony from a prior trial.  We affirm.
text:
State v. Ward


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				John Henry Ward, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Â Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 4270
Heard May 7, 2007 â€“ Filed June 29, 2007Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				William J. Watkins, Jr. of Greenville, and Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Melody Brown, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

HEARN, C.J.:Â  John Henry Ward appeals his murder conviction, arguing the trial court erred by (1) refusing to grant a mistrial after the State insinuated the crime revolved around gang activity, (2) permitting autopsy photos to be admitted, (3) charging the jury that â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all,â€ (4) refusing to grant a directed verdict in Wardâ€™s favor, and (5) allowing the State to play a recording of a co-defendantâ€™s testimony from a prior trial.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
During the early morning hours of May 11, 2003, Jamie Simmons was fatally wounded when a gunfight broke out in the parking lot area of Club Diamante in Charleston County.Â  Simmons, who had the misfortune of stopping outside the club on his way home from work to speak with his cousin, had not been involved in the altercation.Â  Instead, the tragedy resulted from a long-running feud between residents of two communities â€“ the Petersfield community and the Cherry Hill community.Â  This particular fight erupted when John Campbell, a man from Cherry Hill, danced with the girlfriend of Keith Richards, a man from Petersfield.Â  The fight began indoors, but moved outdoors where it continued to escalate.Â 
 
Once outdoors, Campbell ran to a truck where his cousin, Kevin Dunmeyer, was waiting to give Campbell a ride home.Â  As Campbell tried to flee the scene, a group of Petersfield men, which included Appellant Ward and his co-defendant Tremayne Washington, confronted Dunmeyer and Campbell. Â Dunmeyer was separated from his vehicle, so he attempted to flee on foot.Â  As he ran, he was chased by a group of Petersfield men.Â  Dunmeyer was rescued by Antonio Washington, a compatriot from the Cherry Hill community, who drove toward Dunmeyer and attempted to run over anyone from Petersfield who was in the way.Â 
 
Meanwhile, Appellant Ward, co-defendant Washington, and Catrell Douglas, leapt into a truck and chased after Antonio Washington and Dunmeyer.Â  Before the Petersfield contingent got into the truck, a witness heard co-defendant Washington declare: â€œWe will handle that,â€ and â€œsome bitch is going to die tonight.â€Â  As the two vehicles left the parking lot, heavy gunfire erupted.Â  Later, investigators found shell casings from three different types of guns: a .40-caliber, a 9-millimeter, and a .25-caliber. Â Forensic experts determined it was a 9-millimeter bullet that struck and killed Simmons.Â 
 
The State initially tried Ward for the murder of Simmons in December of 2004; the case ended in a mistrial due to a hung jury.Â  Ward was tried again in June of 2005, this time with Tremayne Washington.Â  The two were tried together as accomplices under the theory that both were guilty because â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â 
 
At this second trial, numerous witnesses testified regarding the shooting.Â  One witness, James Murphy, remembered that Simmons fell to the ground as soon as the gunfire began but before any shots came from the truck in which Ward rode.Â  Murphy stated that he thought he saw shots fired from the passenger side of the truck.Â  Catrell Douglas, the driver of the truck, testified that Ward fired gunshots out of the window.Â  Although co-defendant Washington did not testify during the second trial, the jury heard testimony from Wardâ€™s first trial, wherein Washington indicated Ward had fired shots toward the other vehicle.Â 
 
When investigators searched the truck, they found an empty holster, a shell casing, an unfired bullet, and magazines, but did not find a gun.Â  At trial, no weapon was introduced into evidence, though records revealing that co-defendant Washington owned a 9-millimeter pistol were entered.Â 
 
The jury convicted both Ward and Washington, and they were sentenced to thirty yearsâ€™ imprisonment.Â  This appeal followed.
LAW/ANALYSIS
Ward argues the trial court erred by (1) refusing to grant a mistrial after the prosecutor insinuated the crime revolved around gang activity, (2) permitting autopsy photos to be admitted, (3) charging the jury that â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all,â€ (4) refusing to grant a directed verdict in Wardâ€™s favor, and (5) allowing the State to play a recording of a co-defendantâ€™s testimony from a prior trial.Â  We address each issue in turn below.
I.  Insinuation of Gang Activity
Ward first argues he is entitled to a new trial because the State repeatedly suggested that he was a gangster, and this insinuation infected the trial with prejudice that denied him due process of the law.Â  We disagree.
 
The comments about which Ward complains first occurred during opening statements when the prosecutor described the victim as someone who â€œwas not a drinker, was not a drug user, [and] was not a gang banger.â€ Unlike the victim, Ward and his co-defendant were described by the prosecutor as drinkers who â€œwere beating their chest[s] and they [had] something to prove that night.â€ According to Ward, this contrasting description of the victim and the defendants implied that the defendants were â€œdrinking and gang banging at the club.â€Â  Ward also complains that the prosecutor described the fight as being between â€œa gang ofâ€ people from the Cherry Hill community and â€œa bunch of Petersfield people,â€ and later told the jury that Ward was from Petersfield.Â  However, Ward made no objection to the solicitorâ€™s opening argument.
Later in the trial, Kevin Dunmeyer testified that when he attempted to get into his vehicle, there â€œwas a gang of guys at my door.â€Â  In response to this testimony, the prosecutor asked, â€œA gang of guys at your door.Â  Where was this gang of guys from?â€Â  Dunmeyer answered, â€œ[The] Petersfield area.â€Â  Again, Ward did not object to this testimony.
Sometime after Dunmeyer testified, a crime scene investigator testified about the discharge of shell casings.Â  The prosecutor asked if the way bullets ejected depended on whether the weapon was held â€œstraight upâ€ or in a â€œgangster hold.â€Â  This time, Ward objected.Â  Then, during the cross-examination of a defense expert, the prosecutor again asked about a method of shooting known as â€œgangster style.â€Â  Wardâ€™s co-defendant objected, and the trial court sustained the objection, advising the jury to disregard the comment.Â  After the defense expert testified, no other witness was called to the stand.Â  Ward moved for a mistrial based on the Stateâ€™s implication that the defendants were gangsters.Â  The trial court denied the motion, but directed the prosecutor to refrain from mentioning gangs in his closing.Â 
 
â€œThe decision to grant or deny a mistrial is within the sound discretion of the trial judge.â€Â  State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 376, 580 S.E.2d 785, 793 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  A mistrial should only be granted when â€œabsolutely necessary,â€ and a defendant must show both error and resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a mistrial.Â  State v. Stanley, 365 S.C. 24, 34, 615 S.E.2d 455, 460 (Ct. App. 2005).
Here, we find no abuse of discretion.Â  Ward failed to object to most of the references about which he now complains.Â  In fact, the only objection preserved for our review came when the prosecutor asked the crime scene investigator if the ejection of bullets depended on whether the shooter held the weapon â€œstraight upâ€ or in a â€œgangster hold.â€ Â The other references came in without objection or were objected to by Wardâ€™s co-defendant, and therefore are not preserved for review.Â  See Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 324 n.3, 487 S.E.2d 187, 190 n.3 (1997) (explaining that appellant cannot bootstrap an issue for appeal by way of a co-defendantâ€™s objection).Â  We do not believe the isolated reference to which Ward objected warranted the grant of his motion for a mistrial, nor do we believe the combination of references which were unobjected to would require the trial court to grant the motion.Â 
 
Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary (8th Ed. 2004) defines a gang as â€œ[a] group of persons who go about together or act in concert, esp. for antisocial or criminal purposes.â€Â  Certainly, the groups of people on both sides of this altercation outside of Club Diamante could be referred to as gangs considering their actions that evening.Â  Furthermore, the term â€œgangster styleâ€ described the way the gun may have been fired â€“ from a horizontal position rather than from the normal, vertical position.Â  See Urban Dictionary, available at http://www.urbandictionary.com (â€œTo hold a gun horizontally instead of the way it is normally supposed to be held vertically.â€).Â  Because the Stateâ€™s references to gangs were not completely gratuitous and were unobjected to for the most part, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant a mistrial.
II.  Autopsy Photographs
Ward next argues the trial court erred in permitting the prosecution to enter photographs of the victimâ€™s wounds into evidence.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
The relevance, materiality and admissibility of photographs are matters within the sound discretion of the trial court, and a ruling regarding photographsâ€™ admissibility will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion. Â State v. Rosemond, 335 S.C. 593, 596, 518 S.E.2d 588, 589-90 (1999).Â  â€œTo constitute unfair prejudice, the photographs must create â€˜an undue tendency to suggest a decision on an improper basis, commonly, though not necessarily, an emotional one.â€™â€Â  State v. Jackson, 364 S.C. 329, 334, 613 S.E.2d 374, 376 (2005) (quoting State v. Alexander, 303 S.C. 377, 382, 401 S.E.2d 146, 149 (1991)).Â  â€œ[P]hotographs which are calculated to arouse the sympathies or prejudices of the jury should be excluded from the guilt phase of a [trial] if they are irrelevant or not substantially necessary to show material facts or conditions.â€Â  State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 288, 350 S.E.2d 180, 185 (1986).
Here, the trial court allowed two photographs which illustrated graze wounds on the victimâ€™s back.Â  Ward objected, arguing the probative value of the photographs was outweighed by their prejudicial effect.Â  The trial court overruled the objection, finding the juryâ€™s knowledge of the graze wound was necessary to rebut the defenseâ€™s arguments about the angle of the shot, and therefore the photographsâ€™ probative value outweighed their prejudicial effect.Â  This determination is left to the discretion of the trial court, and the record evinces no abuse of that discretion.
III.  Jury Charge on â€œThe Hand of One Is the Hand of Allâ€
Ward also argues the trial court erred by charging the jury that â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€Â  We disagree.
The trial court is required to charge only the current and correct law of South Carolina.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 665, 594 S.E.2d 462, 472-73 (2004).Â  â€œThe law to be charged must be determined from the evidence presented at trial.â€ Â State v. Knoten, 347 S.C. 296, 302, 555 S.E.2d 391, 394 (2001).Â  If any evidence supports a requested jury charge, the trial court should grant the request.Â  State v. Brown, 362 S.C. 258, 262, 607 S.E.2d 93, 95 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  
 
Under â€œthe hand of one is the hand of allâ€ theory, â€œone who joins with another to accomplish an illegal purpose is liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of the common design and purpose.â€Â  State v. Langley, 334 S.C. 643, 648, 515 S.E.2d 98, 101 (1999).Â  Ward argues this theory should not have been charged to the jury because there was no evidence of a common plan or scheme between Ward and his co-defendant.Â  However, evidence revealed that both defendants were with the group of men who confronted Dunmeyer at his truck after the fight spilled outside of the club.Â  As Dunmeyer attempted to run away from the mob, a witness testified that Wardâ€™s co-defendant said, â€œsome bitch is going to die tonight,â€ and â€œwe will handle that.â€Â  The co-defendant and Ward then got into the truck that chased after the car in which Dunmeyer rode.Â  Witnesses also testified that Ward shot his gun toward the other car, and the victim was killed by a stray bullet from this shoot out.Â  After the shooting, the defendants slept at a friendâ€™s house, and Wardâ€™s co-defendant washed his hands with bleach in the morning.Â 
 
The evidence at trial supported the theory that Ward and his co-defendant joined together to accomplish an illegal purpose, and therefore it was appropriate for the trial court to instruct the jury that if it found such a joint endeavor existed, each defendant was liable criminally for everything done by his confederate incidental to the execution of that endeavor.Â  See id.Â Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s charge to the jury that â€œthe hand of one is the hand of all.â€ 
 
IV.  Directed Verdict
Ward next argues the trial court erred in failing to direct a verdict in his favor.Â  We disagree.
â€œOn appeal from the denial of a directed verdict, an appellate court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the State.â€ State v. Padgett, 354 S.C. 268, 270-271, 580 S.E.2d 159, 161 (Ct. App. 2003). Â When ruling on a directed verdict motion, the trial court is concerned with the existence or nonexistence of evidence, not its weight. Â State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002). Â â€œA defendant is entitled to a directed verdict when the State fails to produce evidence of the offense charged.â€ Padgett, 354 S.C. at 271, 580 S.E.2d at 161.Â  â€œHowever, if there is any direct evidence or any substantial circumstantial evidence reasonably tending to prove the guilt of the accused, [the appellate court] must find the case was properly submitted to the jury.â€Â  Id. 
 
The gist of Wardâ€™s argument that he is entitled to a directed verdict harkens back to his argument regarding the jury charge:Â  Ward believes there is insufficient evidence to show he and his co-defendant were acting in concert.Â  As explained above, evidence was presented to show that the two were involved in the fight with Dunmeyer; that as Dunmeyer fled, Wardâ€™s co-defendant threatened to kill someone that night; and that moments after that threat, Ward and the co-defendant got into a truck from which gunfire erupted towards the vehicle in which Dunmeyer rode.Â  Furthermore, the driver of the truck as well as the co-defendant stated that Ward was shooting out of the passenger side window of the truck. Â Accordingly, there was some evidence that Ward shot the victim as he fired his weapon toward the other vehicle, and the trial court did not err in sending the case to the jury.
V.  Co-Defendantâ€™s Testimony
Finally, Ward argues the trial court erred by allowing the State to play a recording of the testimony given by Wardâ€™s co-defendant during Wardâ€™s first trial.Â  At trial, however, Ward never argued that this former testimony was inadmissible, but instead specifically agreed that the testimony was admissible.[1]Â  Because the issue was never raised or ruled upon by the trial court, it is not preserved for our review. Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€). 
 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we find the trial court did not err in denying Wardâ€™s motions for a mistrial and directed verdict.Â  We also find no error in the admission of the autopsy photographs or with the jury being instructed that the hand of one is the hand of all.Â  Finally, we find Ward failed to preserve any argument with regard to his co-defendantâ€™s testimony.Â  Accordingly, Wardâ€™s murder conviction is
 
AFFIRMED.
GOOLSBY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.

[1] On appeal, Ward admits he acquiesced to the playing of the former testimony; however, he points out that he later argued â€œthat the prosecution had tried the case differently than in the first trial.â€Â Â Â  According to Ward, this argument related back to â€œa lack of the same motive for cross-examination in the first trial as in the second trial,â€ so the issue was raised to and ruled upon by the trial court.Â  We disagree.Â  The record reveals that at the end of the trial, when Ward made his motion for a directed verdict, he argued that the State should be estopped from taking a position in this trial that was different from the position in the first trial.Â  Specifically, he complained that in the first trial, Ward was tried solely as a perpetrator and not as an accomplice, so the defense presented evidence that Tremayne Washington (his co-defendant in the second trial) washed his hands in bleach after the shooting.Â  In the second trial, the State presented the evidence of the hand-washing.Â  However, Ward never argued the trial court erred in allowing his co-defendantâ€™s testimony to be played during his current trial, nor did he argue that the change in the Stateâ€™s strategy prevented him from thoroughly cross-examining his co-defendant during that first trial.Â  Thus, his estoppel argument in no way encompassed the argument he makes on appeal.

title: MID-SOUTH MANAGEMENT v. SHERWOOD DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION
description: Mid-South and other parties in a joint venture appeal from the master-in-equity's order finding the parent companies of Sherwood Development were not liable to pay the judgment Sherwood owed to Mid-South.  We affirm.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				MID-SOUTH MANAGEMENT COMPANY INCORPORATED And WILLIAM C. BUCHHEIT TRUST A, as Partners Of Spartanburg Beach Cove Associates, a General Partnership and a Joint Venturer Of Beach Cove Associates Joint Venture, And BEACH COVE ASSOCIATES JOINT VENTURE, Appellants,
				v.
				SHERWOOD DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION, a Joint Venturer of Beach Cove Associates Joint Venture; COASTAL FINANCIAL CORPORATION, COASTAL FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK; COASTAL MORTGAGE BANKERS AND REALTY CO., INC.; JOHN DOE, which represent unidentified shareholders of Sherwood Development Corporation; MICHAEL C. GERALD and JAMES T. CLEMMONS, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Horry County
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Master-in-Equity
Opinion No. 4271
Heard December 7, 2006 â€“ Filed June 29, 2007
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Michael B.T. Wilkes and D. Alan Lazenby, of
				Spartanburg, Michael Warner Battle, of 
				
				Conway,for Appellant.
				Robert E. Stepp, and Amy Hill, of
				
				Columbia, for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM: Â Mid-South Management Company, Inc., William C. Buchheit Trust A, and Beach Cove Associates Joint Venture (collectively, â€œAppellantsâ€), appeal from the master-in-equityâ€™s order finding the parent companies of Sherwood Development Corporation were not liable to pay Appellantsâ€™ judgment against Sherwood.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Spartanburg Beach Cove Associates is a general partnership with Mid-South and the William C. STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œAn action to pierce the corporate veil is one in equity. Â Thus this court may take its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Dumas v. Infosafe Corp., 320 S.C. 188, 192, 463 S.E.2d 641, 643 (Ct. App. 1995); see Sturkie v. Sifly, 280 S.C. 453, 456-57, 313 S.E.2d 316, 318 (Ct. App. 1984) (finding that an action to pierce the corporate veil is one in equity and the appellate court takes its own view of the preponderance of the evidence).Â  â€œThe broad scope of review applicable to appeals in equity actions does not, however, require an appellate court to disregard the findings below or ignore the fact that the trial judge is in the better position to assess the credibility of the witnesses.â€Â  Hunting v. Elders, 359 S.C. 217, 223, 597 S.E.2d 803, 806 (Ct. App. 2004), cert. dismissed (Oct. 5, 2005).Â  
 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants contend the master erred in not finding Sherwoodâ€™s parent companies liable for the judgment Appellants obtained against Sherwood.Â  Appellants assert Sherwoodâ€™s parent companies should be liable because: Â (1) Sherwoodâ€™s corporate veil should be pierced; (2) Sherwood was the mere instrumentality or alter-ego of the parent companies; or (3) the amalgamation of corporate interests, entities, and activities blurs the legal description between the corporations and their activities.Â  We disagree.
I.  Piercing the Corporate Veil
Appellants maintain the master erred in failing to pierce Sherwoodâ€™s corporate veil and finding the parent companies liable for Sherwoodâ€™s obligations.Â  We find Appellants have failed to prove the necessity for piercing the corporate veil of Sherwood.
It is generally recognized that a corporation is an entity that is separate and distinct from, and its debts are not the individual debts of, its officers and stockholders.Â  Hunting, 359 S.C. at 223, 597 S.E.2d at 806 (citing DeWitt Truck Brokers, Inc. v. W. Ray Flemming Fruit Co., 540 F.2d 681, 683 (4th Cir. 1976)).Â  Although the corporate entity may be disregarded in some situations, piercing the corporate veil is not a doctrine to be applied without substantial reflection.Â  Baker v. Equitable Leasing Corp., 275 S.C. 359, 367, 271 S.E.2d 596, 600 (1980) (â€œHowever, â€˜piercing the corporate veilâ€™ is not a doctrine to be applied without substantial reflection.â€).Â  Courts are generally reluctant to disregard the corporate entity:Â  
 

	If any general rule can be laid down, it is that a corporation will be looked upon as a legal entity until sufficient reason to the contrary appears; but when the notion of legal entity is used to protect fraud, justify wrong, or defeat public policy, the law will regard the corporation as an association of persons.Â Â  
	

Sturkie, 280 S.C. at 457, 313 S.E.2d at 318.Â  Thus, courts generally disregard the corporate entity only where equity requires piercing the corporate veil to assist a third party.Â  Woodside v. Woodside, 290 S.C. 366, 370, 350 S.E.2d 407, 410 (Ct. App. 1986) (â€œThe corporate form may be disregarded only where equity requires the action to assist a third party.â€).Â  The burden of proof is on the party asserting that the corporate veil should be pierced.Â  Id.
Our courts have outlined a two-prong test to determine whether a corporate veil should be pierced.Â  The first part of the test requires an eight-factor analysis and looks to observance of the corporate formalities by the dominant shareholders. Â Sturkie, 280 S.C. at 457-58, 313 S.E.2d at 318. Â â€œThe second part requires that there be an element of injustice or fundamental unfairness if the acts of the corporation be not regarded as the acts of the individuals.â€Â  Id. Â In determining whether the corporate formalities were observed under the first prong of the Sturkie test, the courts consider eight factors:

	(1) whether the corporation was grossly undercapitalized;
	(2) failure to observe corporate formalities;
	(3) non-payment of dividends;
	(4) insolvency of the debtor corporation at the time;
	(5) siphoning of funds of the corporation by the dominant stockholder;
	(6) non-functioning of other officers or directors;
	(7) absence of corporate records;Â  and
	(8) the fact that the corporation was merely a faÃ§ade for the operations of the dominant stockholder.

Dumas, 320 S.C. at 192, 463 S.E.2d at 644.Â  â€œThe conclusion to disregard the corporate entity must involve a number of the eight factors, but need not involve them all.â€Â  Id. [4] Â  
 
Under the second prong of the Sturkie test, the party seeking to pierce the corporate veil must prove injustice or fundamental unfairness if the corporate veil is not pierced.Â  Multimedia Publâ€™g of S.C., Inc. v. Mullins, 314 S.C. 551, 553, 431 S.E.2d 569, 571 (1993).Â  â€œThe essence of the fairness test is simply that an individual businessman cannot be allowed to hide from the normal consequences of carefree entrepreneuring by doing so through a corporate shell.â€Â  Id. at 556, 431 S.E.2d at 573.Â   
A. Corporate Formalities
Reviewing the eight factors to be considered in the first prong of the Sturkie test, we find Appellants did not meet their burden of proving that Sherwood failed to observe corporate formalities.Â  Sherwood was able to meet all capital calls totaling approximately $2.5 million, it observed corporate formalities by having meetings and keeping records, it had functioning officers and directors, and, although it did not have the money to pay its portion of the settlement at the time of this action, there is no evidence that Sherwood was insolvent because it did not have any outstanding debt nor was it otherwise unable to seek additional funding from its parent companies.Â  The repayment of the loan to the parent corporations out of the sole distribution to Sherwood did not amount to the â€œsiphoningâ€ of funds.Â  There was no evidence that Sherwood was â€œmerely a faÃ§adeâ€ for the parent companies.Â  The failure of Sherwood to pay dividends to its shareholders did not amount to fraudulent behavior where the Joint Venture never made a profit and the sole distribution was used to repay a debt to the parent companies.Â  Accordingly, Appellants failed to prove Sherwood did not observe corporate formalities. 
 
B. Fundamental Unfairness
Even assuming Sherwood failed to observe corporate formalities, Appellants failed to prove that failure to pierce the corporate veil would result in fundamental unfairness.Â  
 
The heart of a piercing the corporate veil dispute lies in proving the second prong of the Sturkie test, which requires a showing of fundamental unfairness in recognizing the corporate entity.Â  The main purpose of piercing the corporate veil is to prevent the likelihood of injustice or unfairness if the limited liability enjoyed by the corporate entity is sustained.Â  Sturkie, 280 S.C. at 458-59, 313 S.E.2d at 318.Â  The burden of proving this fundamental unfairness requires the plaintiff to â€œestablish that (1) the defendant was aware of the plaintiffâ€™s claim against the corporation, and (2) thereafter, the defendant acted in a self-serving manner with regard to the property of the corporation and in disregard of the plaintiffâ€™s claim in the property.â€Â  Dumas, 320 S.C. at 192, 463 S.E.2d at 644.Â  The actual knowledge requirement has been clarified to mean that a person is â€œâ€˜awareâ€™ of a claim against the corporation if he has notice of facts which, if pursued with due diligence, would lead to knowledge of the claim.â€Â  Hunting, 359 S.C. at 229, 597 S.E.2d at 809.
First, we must determine the â€œplaintiffâ€™s claimâ€ that is at issue in this action.Â  Appellants assert the â€œclaimâ€ is the likelihood of damages resulting from the potential suit by the homeowners and Sherwood should have taken steps to insure any judgment received by the homeowners could be covered.Â  Sherwood, on the other hand, contends the â€œclaimâ€ is the request by Spartanburg for contribution of money to satisfy Sherwoodâ€™s one-third liability for the amount the Joint Venture was required to pay to settle the homeownersâ€™ claims.Â  Much of the litigation and the Record on Appeal are devoted to attempting to show what Sherwood knew, should have known, or did not know regarding the homeownersâ€™ claims and the potential liability from those claims.Â  However, we find based on the clear language used in numerous cases, the claim to be considered is the claim asserted by Appellants and not the claim asserted by the homeowners against the Joint Venture.Â  See Dumas, 320 S.C. at 192, 463 S.E.2d at 644 (stating that â€œthe defendant was aware of the plaintiffâ€™s claim against the corporationâ€) (emphasis added); Sturkie, 280 S.C. at 459, 313 S.E.2d at 319 (reviewing the plaintiff receiverâ€™s claim against the corporation). 
 
Based on the record before us, Sherwood would have been aware of Appellantsâ€™ claims no earlier than when the Joint Venture agreed to pay $835,000 towards settlement of the homeownersâ€™ lawsuit.Â  The settlement was reached on February 3, 1997.Â  Prior to this time, Sherwood was under a belief that there would be no requirement of contribution from the Joint Venture and that insurance and other parties would be responsible as had previously taken place when a similar subsidiary of Coastal was involved in a lawsuit and was not responsible for payment of any damages. Â At the time of the settlement, Sherwood should have known that it would be responsible for one-third of the resulting settlement amount.Â  
 
The record is devoid of any evidence of self-serving behavior on the part of Sherwood after February 1997.Â  Nothing in the record indicates Sherwood transferred money, property, or other assets out of the corporation after February 1997.Â  Spartanburg knew of Sherwoodâ€™s resistance to contributing to any proposed settlement based on Sherwoodâ€™s belief that insurance and other parties should be responsible.Â  In addition, Spartanburg turned down a $100,000 proposed payment by Sherwood, contingent on approval by Coastal Mortgage.Â  
 
As to any unfairness, we find Appellants knew at all times that Sherwood was a corporation and enjoyed limited liability.Â  Myers testified that she dealt with Sherwood and not any of the parent companies.Â  Sherwood had previously warned Appellants that it may be forced to cease operations if the operating deficits continued to accrue.Â  This is not a case in which the defendant acted in bad faith or with deceit to take advantage of the plaintiff.Â  The Joint Venture was a business deal among sophisticated parties, and Sherwood contributed over $2 million to the venture due to its continuous losses.Â  Accordingly, we find there is no evidence in the record demonstrating any fundamental unfairness resulting from recognizing the limited liability given to Sherwood as a corporation.
However, even assuming Appellants are correct that the â€œclaimâ€ in this case was the likelihood of the Joint Venture being liable to the homeowners, we find Sherwood was not aware of the claim until the suit was filed in August 1993.Â  As discussed in the facts above, Gerald was notified sometime in the fall of 1992 by the homeownersâ€™ association that it hired an attorney due to defects with the parking garage.Â  However, the uncontroverted evidence by Gerald was that he thought the issue with the parking garage was being resolved.Â  In addition, he was told that the attorney for the homeownersâ€™ association planned to look around and see â€œif he could make that $200,000 case more like a $2 million case.â€Â  However, nothing in this statement would put Gerald or Sherwood on notice of the upcoming lawsuit over stucco and water intrusion damage.Â  Gerald testified that when he received the complaint in August 1993, he was shocked, and it was the first time he had any knowledge of the homeownersâ€™ specific allegations.Â 
 
Appellants attempt to argue Sherwoodâ€™s self-dealing and unfair behavior was the transfer of the $330,000 from Sherwood to its parent company to repay a debt sometime after March 1993.Â  Appellants maintain Sherwood acted improperly by not setting aside an amount in reserve for the potential homeownersâ€™ litigation.Â  However, the testimony by Gerald and Myers reveals that no one from Spartanburg or the other Appellants ever discussed setting up a reserve with the proceeds received from the commercial sale.Â  In addition, Spartanburg distributed its share of the proceeds to its partners and made no attempt to establish a similar reserve that it now demands Sherwood should have done.Â  We find Appellants have presented insufficient evidence that Sherwood acted in a self-serving manner with regard to the property of the corporation and in disregard of Appellantsâ€™ claim in the property.Â  
 
Again, Appellants have failed to demonstrate the unfairness resulting from recognizing the corporate entity in order to pierce the corporate veil of Sherwood, even considering the transfer of the $330,000 to its parent company.Â  As discussed above, these are sophisticated parties who entered into a risky development with the expectation of making a profit that ended in the reality of significant losses.Â  
 
Regardless of the date of the â€œclaimâ€ against Sherwood, we find Sherwood and its parent companies did not act in a self-serving or unfair manner.Â  We agree with the master in this case that no injustice or fundamental unfairness results from allowing Sherwood to maintain its corporate status and its shareholders to enjoy the limited liability that accompanies being part of a corporation.
II.  Other Grounds
Appellants aver that Sherwoodâ€™s parent companies should also be held liable under either: (1) an alter-ego or instrumentality theory; or (2) an amalgamation of interest or blurred identity theory.Â  We disagree.
a.  Alter-Ego or Instrumentality Theory
Appellants maintain the master committed error by failing to recognize that Sherwood was the mere instrumentality of its parent companies and in failing to find the parent companies, therefore, liable for Sherwoodâ€™s debts.Â  We disagree.
Our supreme court has recently addressed the application of the alter-ego theory in Colleton County Taxpayers v. School District of Colleton County, 371 S.C. 224, 237, 638 S.E.2d 685, 692 (2006). Â In that case, a non-profit corporation was created by the Colleton County School District to raise funds for renovating existing public school facilities.Â  In determining whether the corporation was the alter-ego of the school district, and thus, subject to the general obligation debt limit imposed on school districts by the South Carolina Constitution, the court stated:

	An alter-ego theory requires a showing of total domination and control of one entity by another and inequitable consequences caused thereby.Â  
	Peoples Fed. Sav. & Loan Assoc. v. Myrtle Beach Golf & Yacht Club, 310 S.C. 132, 148, 425 S.E.2d 764, 774 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Control may be shown where the subservient entity manifests no separate interest of its own and functions solely to achieve the goals of the dominant entity.Â  
	
	Id.Â  However, this theory does not apply in the absence of fraud or misuse of control by the dominant entity which results in some injustice.Â  
	
	Id. 

Colleton County Taxpayers, 371 S.C. at 237, 638 S.E.2d at 692.Â  The Colleton County court went on to reference Baker v. Equitable Leasing Corporation, 275 S.C. 359, 367-68, 271 S.E.2d 596, 600 (1980), for the theory that control, in and of itself, is not sufficient to find that a subservient corporation is the alter-ego of the dominant one; one must show that the retention of separate corporate personalities would promote fraud, wrong or injustice, or would contravene public policy.Â  Id.Â  Noting that there was no evidence of dominance and control, the court found the corporation was not the alter-ego of the school district.Â  Id. at 238, 638 S.E.2d at 692.  
In the present case, the master found the alter-ego or instrumentality theory was not appropriate for piercing the corporate veil because, up to that point, our courts had only applied the theory when:Â  (1) recognizing the attorney as the alter-ego of the client; (2) determining whether an employer is liable for the bad acts of its employee; and (3) determining lender liability.[5]Â  The master found that the Sturkie test for piercing the corporate veil was the only way to evaluate corporate structure.Â Â  
 
Nothing in the Colleton County Taxpayers case limits application of the alter-ego theory solely to the situations listed by the master.Â  In fact, the case cites Baker, a veil-piercing case, to support its finding that the alter-ego theory does not apply in the absence of fraud or misuse of control resulting in injustice.Â  Colleton County Taxpayers, 371 S.C. at 237, 638 S.E.2d at 692; see Baker, 275 S.C. at 367-68, 271 S.E.2d at 600 (noting that piercing the corporate veil is normally only allowed where retaining separate corporate entities would result in fraud, wrong or injustice or would contravene public policy).Â  Although Colleton County Taxpayers was decided after the master determined the underlying case and the master did not have the benefit of reviewing it, it appears that the alter-ego theory also applies in corporate situations.Â  
 
Nevertheless, we find the alter-ego theory is inapplicable to the present case.Â  While Sherwoodâ€™s officers also held positions in the parent companies, Sherwood maintained separate corporate records.Â  As previously discussed, we find nothing inappropriate about Sherwoodâ€™s transfer of money to its parent companies to repay a debt.Â  Nothing in the record indicates that the â€œdominantâ€ companies misused their control over Sherwood to promote fraud.Â  The record reflects that Sherwood was incorporated to limit liability, not to promote fraud.Â  As Professor Freeman testified at the trial, â€œjust because a business fails doesnâ€™t mean that thereâ€™s been fraud.â€Â  Because there is no evidence in the record to support a finding that Sherwoodâ€™s parent companies abused their control over Sherwood or that a fraud was committed, the alter-ego theory is inapplicable in the present case.Â  Accordingly, the master did not err in finding the parent companies were not liable for the judgment against Sherwood.
b.  Amalgamation of Interest or Blurred Identity Theory
Appellants maintain the court erred in failing to find the parent companies liable under an amalgamation of interest theory where the companiesâ€™ interests, entities, and activities blur the identity of the various companies.Â  We disagree.
In Kincaid v. Landing Development Corporation, this court found a sibling company liable for the obligation of another sibling company due to the evidence revealing an â€œâ€˜amalgamation of corporate interests, entities, and activities so as to blur the legal distinction between the corporations and their activities.â€™â€Â  Kincaid v. Landing Dev. Corp., 289 S.C. 89, 96, 344 S.E.2d 869, 874 (Ct. App. 1986) (quoting the trial courtâ€™s order).Â  In Kincaid, the Landing Development Corporation (LDC), Resort Management Group, Incorporated (RMG), and Resort Construction Corporation (RCC) were all sibling corporations and were sued for negligent construction and breach of warranty. Â Id. at 91, 344 S.E.2d at 871. Â On appeal RMG argued the trial court should have directed a verdict in its favor as it was simply the marketing and sales company.Â  Id. at 96, 344 S.E.2d at 874.Â  However, the Kincaid court found the three companies shared officers, shareholders, and location.Â  In addition, the evidence showed RMG was the â€œproject managerâ€ and was the company who the defendant called to attempt to remedy problems.Â  Finally, company letterhead said:Â  â€œResort Management Group Inc.,â€ with a notation, â€œA Development, Construction, Sales, and Property Management Company.â€Â  Id.Â Â Â  
 
In Kincaid, this court found sibling companies jointly liable for negligent construction.Â  Kincaid was not a situation in which one company owed a judgment and the court imposed liability upon the parent company or a shareholder.Â  Thus, Kincaid is inapplicable to the present action.Â  
 
In addition, there is no evidence in the record that Spartanburg or the other Appellants could confuse Sherwood with its parent companies.Â  At all times, Appellants dealt only with Sherwood and not Coastal Mortgage.Â  Sherwood had separate letterhead and Myers testified she knew she was dealing only with Sherwood and not Coastal Mortgage.Â  Accordingly, even if the Kincaid amalgamation of interest theory could be used to find a shareholder liable for debts of a corporation, we find Appellants failed to present sufficient evidence to find Sherwoodâ€™s parent companies liable for its judgment.
CONCLUSION
We hold the master correctly found there was no fundamental unfairness in the way Sherwood conducted business and find Appellants failed to prove a sufficient number of the Sturkie factors to justify piercing the corporate veil.Â  We further find the alter-ego and amalgamation of interest theories are inapplicable to hold Sherwoodâ€™s parent companies liable for the judgment given the circumstances of this case.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the master is
AFFIRMED.
